IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Frontotemporal dementia (FTD) is a neurodegenerative disease that is one of the most common dementias for people under 60, and circadian disruptions are prevalent among patients with neurodegenerative diseases, including FTD. Since humans and flies share conserved molecular mechanisms underlying neurodegenerative and circadian processes, this work will offer valuable insights into the mechanisms connecting circadian dysfunction and FTD and may ultimately lead to novel biomarkers and treatment options for FTD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE Cardiovascular disease remains the number one cause of death in the United States. Despite lipid-lowering therapy, many patients remain at high risk of a cardiovascular event, and inflammation has been identified as a major residual risk factor. Our proposal aims to identify metabolic pathways contributing to inflammation resolution in atherosclerotic plaque and why they fail with disease progression, with the ultimate goal of discovering novel therapeutic strategies for treatment of cardiovascular disease.

PHR: Project narrative Adolescent binge drinking can lead to long-term deficits in behavioral flexibility and functional connectivity across brain regions. This project will study the role of perineuronal nets, which are extracellular matrix structures, in alcohol’s long-lasting effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The Boston Bacterial Meeting (BBM) brings together bacteriologists at varying career stages and from distinct subfields of bacteriology and provides an opportunity for them to meet, hear the latest research, discuss new ideas and methods, and initiate collaborations. BBM is especially important in that it specifically promotes the careers of young scientists by allowing them to present their own research, be introduced to work done across disparate fields of bacteriology, and by providing an opportunity for them to network in the local scientific community. By including basic scientists, healthcare professionals, and industry researchers, BBM helps disseminate recent work, and foster creative collaborations that produce new ideas for infectious disease treatment and prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research will explore the link between early life adversity, mast cells, and lifelong chronic inflammatory disease, through a mechanism involving modulation of cholesterol metabolism and heightened pro- inflammatory granule mediator production. These findings will contribute to the current understanding of ELA associated inflammatory and metabolic diseases and will be utilized for development of novel intervention strategies. Through this study, the applicant will broaden their technical and analytical skills, which will be critically useful during their career as they become an impactful, interdisciplinary, and translational scientist.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH The prognosis for GBM patients remains dismal and there is an urgent unmet need for novel therapies. The first oncolytic virus to be approved by the FDA is an oncolytic HSV whose use is prescribed for melanoma patients is HSV-1 derived. Japan has also recently conditionally approved use of an oncolytic HSV for GBM patients. Thus there is a lot of interest in developing this treatment modality. To increase the utility of this novel approach for brain tumor patients we propose to create and optimize a oncolytic HSV for therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Vitamin D is a critical factor that affects the intestine by enhancing calcium absorption, protecting the intestinal barrier, reducing gut inflammation, and reducing colon cancer risk. The intestinal effects of vitamin D change across the lifespan, leading to intestinal vitamin D resistance in older adults. We will use state of the art genomic technology to understand how intestinal resistance develops and test a strategy to promote intestinal calcium absorption to prevent adult- and age-related bone loss.

ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: Project Narrative Fatty acid binding protein 5 is a lipid chaperone implicated in pain modulation and is a promising target for the development of next-generation analgesics. This study seeks to identify a novel function for this protein in lipid- mediated pain hypersensitivity. The outcome of this study will greatly improve our understanding of fatty acid binding protein 5 function and may lead to novel therapeutic strategies to treat pain.

PHR: Project Narrative In this proposal we will explore the mechanisms by which Nrf2 preserves -cell mass and acts as a common node for the eicosanoid and incretin signaling pathways, and we will test the exciting therapeutic potential of activating combinations of these pathways to treat diabetes. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Invasive fungal infections in immune compromised patients such as those undergoing chemotherapy or high dose corticosteroid treatments are a major impediment to human health. Infections by moulds are particularly problematic and often resistant to contemporary antifungal therapy. This proposal will further develop a novel small molecule with potent antifungal activity against human pathogenic moulds.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Any animal nervous system is composed of two types of cells, neuron and glia, each of critical importance of the function of the brain. The aim of this grant proposal is to explore unitary principles of nervous system development. Using a simple invertebrate model system as a test case, we test here the hypothesis that an evolutionarily conserved class of transcription factors, called homeobox genes, are regulators of glial cell fate specification throughout the entire nervous system of an animal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed studies aim to reveal the structures and functions of various forms of N-methyl-D-aspartate receptor (NMDAR) ion channels, which play a significant role in brain function and development. These studies are relevant to public health because dysfunctional NMDARs are implicated in neurological disorders such as Alzheimer’s disease, depression, and stroke. Understanding what types of NMDARs are present in the brain and how they recognize compounds and regulate their activity will facilitate the development of therapeutic strategies for neurological disorders and diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Single-cell RNA sequencing is powerful technology that can be used to study the cellular makeup of tissue and cell type-specific gene regulation during growth, development, and in disease. In this proposal, we seek to use mosaic human brain tissue comprised of a mixture of cells with and without a genetic variant that causes a rare brain malformation to study the effect of the variant on gene regulation in different types of brain cell types. The long-term goal of the work is to illuminate transcriptomic changes associated with the pathogenic variant that may direct us toward novel and targeted therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative Opioid-use disorder (OUD) and associated overdoses and deaths remain at epidemic levels. This project examines functional connectivity patterns associated with subsequent relapse to illicit opioids during treatment for OUD. This is critical to improve understanding of brain mechanisms of relapse and is an essential precursor to the development of improved, evidence-based interventions based on known neurobiology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: Glioblastoma WHO grade IV (GBM) is the most common primary malignant brain tumor in adults with a grim prognosis. The current proposal explores an innovative, novel mitochondrial energetic pathway that is entertained by OGDH in model systems of GBM. Targeting OGDH through the novel compound, CPI613, extends animal survival and enhances the standard of care for GBM and therefore may be a novel treatment for this detrimental disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Lassa virus (LASV) is a mammarenavirus highly prevalent in Western Africa, where it is estimated to infect several hundred thousand people yearly, resulting in a high number of Lassa fever (LF) cases, a hemorrhagic fever (HF) disease associated with high morbidity and mortality; there are no US FDA-approved LASV vaccines, and current anti-LASV therapy is limited to off-label use of ribavirin which has limited efficacy. LF has been included on the revised list of priority diseases for the WHO R&D Blueprint, underscoring an urgent need for vaccines to combat LF. The central goal of this application is to test the hypothesis that specific reorganization of the LASV genome can result in live-attenuated vaccine candidates with excellent safety and protective efficacy profiles, while exhibiting an unbreachable attenuation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE During brain development astrocytes promote the formation and maturation of synapses, showing regionally specialized effects. This work investigates the factors that drive functional and molecular regional specializations of astrocytes in the brain, and how this impacts neurons and synapses. Multiple neurodevelopmental disorders including autism display alterations in neuronal and synaptic function, and the findings of this work will uncover pathways that can be targeted to correct these deficits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Failure of pancreatic β-cells to secrete insulin in response to glucose is a hallmark of diabetes pathogenesis. Under normal conditions, glucose stimulates synthesis of the insulin protein, but prolonged exposure to high glucose during the development of diabetes impairs this critical β-cell function. By discovering new mechanisms by which glucose regulates production of the hormone insulin, this project has the potential to identify novel targets for the development of treatments to halt or delay diabetes progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: HENRY FORD HEALTH + MICHIGAN STATE UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Polygenic scores (PS) are a mathematic way to try to measure genetic tendency towards a trait, considering a person’s entire genetic makeup, not just one or two genes. So far, PS have mostly been tested in white people and focused on risk of disease, but a major issue in medicine is that individuals often respond differently to medications (some of this being due to differences in genetics) and this is sometimes a particular concern for African American patients who are under-represented in clinical trials and genetic research. The goal of this project is to learn how to create PS for African Americans that can help doctors know which medicines will work best for individual patients based on their genetics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A diversity of perspectives enriches scientific research, but unfortunately, the existing STEM/health workforce, particularly with respect to research, is among the least diverse. The Promoting Underrepresented and Marginalized Populations’ Advancement in the Sciences (PUMAS) program was conceived to address this issue by providing twelve summer research opportunities in our laboratories for community college students from groups that are traditionally underrepresented in the sciences. The program aims to increase the scientific skills, knowledge, personal confidence, and scientific networks of underrepresented college-aged youth in support of their continued education and eventual careers in STEM, particularly biomedical research and health-related fields.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative On average a third of the world is infected with the protozoan parasite Toxoplasma gondii that causes chronic inflammation in the brain. This proposal will address the activation of CNS resident astrocytes to determine the subsets involved in crucial aspects of neuroinflammation. Knowledge gained from this work will inform not only our understanding of the balance of infection in the brain but also processes that are involved in many neurological neuroinflammatory diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: FEDERATION OF AMER SOC FOR EXPER BIOLOGY
PHR: Project Narrative TGF-β family signaling pathways act as central mediators of embryonic development, organ homeostasis, and the body's ability to repair successfully after injury. Importantly, perturbations in the TGF-β signaling axis are linked to a long and growing list of diseases of cardiovascular, respiratory, and skeletal systems, a multitude of cancers, and physiological changes during aging, providing fertile ground for the identification of novel targets and promising new therapies that can fundamentally impact the health of a broad segment of the population. The 2024 FASEB SRC TGF-β Superfamily Conference: Signaling in Development and Disease aims to exploit these exciting discoveries and provide a timely and relevant forum for their presentation, appreciation, analysis, and discussion to inspire and stimulate progress toward ever more effective and targeted therapeutics for TGF-β signaling disorders, while promoting the career development goals of participants, particularly those who are early career scientists, new to the TGF-β field, and/or members of underrepresented groups.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project examines how red blood cells contribute to the severe inflammatory response that occurs after exposure to cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB) since this response impairs the function of all most every organ in the body, especially in infants. We will test if reducing the exposure to blood products reduces CPB induced inflammation. The resulting data will be used to help new ways of protecting children during cardiac surgery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Evident in its name, Helicobacter pylori is a helical-rod shaped bacterium that colonizes the human stomach causing clinical outcomes that range from mild gastritis to peptic ulcer and gastric cancer. We discovered genes that promote helical cell shape through modification of the cell wall. Study of how these cell wall modifications promote helical cell shape and the ability of the bacterium to live in its niche will help us better understand how this bacterium causes disease and uncover new ways to inhibit infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A recurring difficulty in the treatment of drug addiction is the reinstatement of drug use even after a lengthy abstinence period. The purpose of this proposal is to exploit recent technical advancements in order to analyze and discover the neuronal adaptation in specific neural circuitry in the prefrontal cortex for the self-administration of cocaine. We believe that the exploration of the circuit mechanisms for drug seeking after withdrawal will be extremely useful for creating a framework for researching drug addiction in a circuit-specific manner and for devising a treatment strategy for drug addiction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Engineering a patient’s own immune cells to fight cancer is one of the most promising new advances in cancer therapy, yet this strategy has been limited by a lack of tumor-specific surface targets. Here we aim to advance the development and capabilities of a technology we invented, called “structural surfaceomics”, to characterize the set of potential tumor-specific surface antigens defined by their 3-dimensional protein conformation. The long term goal of this proposal is to directly spur the development of new cancer therapies for patients currently in need.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The rates of dual use of cigarettes and electronic cigarettes are increasing, but there are no evidence-based treatments for such dual users. This innovative research will compare the effectiveness of two cessation medications (varenicline vs. nicotine patches), two counseling interventions (focusing on quitting smoking and quitting e-cigarettes vs. focusing exclusively on quitting smoking), and two counseling durations (1 vs. 4 sessions) in helping dual users quit smoking. These findings could inform clinical treatment decisions for dual users.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project develops and evaluates the efficacy of Digitally Prompted Parenting (DPP), a text- message parent-based intervention (PBI) for parents of incoming college students that is designed to prevent heavy episodic drinking and the development of risky drinking behavior that often occurs in the first semester in college. Unlike existing PBIs which are delivered before students arrive on campus, DPP leverages existing parent-student communication via texts prompting parents to send tailored risk-reducing messages on days and times when alcohol use is common among college students. The brevity of text messages and the simplicity of the task that parents are asked to engage in makes DPP cost-effective and easy to disseminate, while increasing the likelihood that parents engage with and implement the intervention content in a way that translates into stronger effects on drinking relative to the more demanding and time-consuming standard PBIs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE This conference is organized as a response to well-articulated research needs expressed by retired gold/uranium miners and community leaders in South Africa since May 2021, as well as by UNM HSC COP and UNM METALS SRP community partners, the Navajo Nation (Diné Bikéyah) and the Pueblo of Laguna (K’awaika). The conference will unite in-person African and Native people affected by uranium developments worldwide and share community engagement goals and practices of the UNM METALS Superfund Research Center (SRP) in support of NIEHS’s programmatic mission. The conference will bring together community knowledge holders, researchers to discuss findings of ongoing environmental health and risk assessment research conducted in their respective communities, cultivate collaborative community partnerships for future research as well as actions promoting healing, social networking, and environmental justice for marginalized people exposed to uranium mining.

PHR: Narrative α-Synucleine aggregates into ﬁbrils in many neurodegenerative diseases such as Lewy body dementias (LBDs), multiple system atrophy (MSA), and Parkinson’s disease (PD). IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The 4th International Symposium to Advance Total Worker Health® will have a high public heath impact by meeting the national and international needs for increasing research and practice in Total Worker Health (TWH). We will meet this objective by hosting a TWH education planning workshop in the first project year to identify gaps and opportunities for TWH training and to inform the themes of the Symposium. Our primary objectives are to convene stakeholders across academia, industry, labor, and government to explore research and case studies in TWH, to establish partnerships and collaborations that advance TWH, and to build capacity by providing the necessary knowledge and skills to professionals, employers, workers, policymakers, community groups, and students.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Growing evidence suggests the cognitive symptoms underlying many psychiatric diseases, including substance use disorder, result from disruption to cue-reward memory. This project will reveal the function of 5 critical amygdala output pathways in cue-reward learning and decision making and, in so doing, reveal a circuit motif for cue-reward memory that will enable both basic and clinical advance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: We proposed a novel therapeutic treatment for diabetic retinopathy, a leading cause of vision loss in working adults. Our strategy uses direct ocular delivery of a new class of drugs that activate nuclear receptors present in most cells of the retina called Retinoid X Receptor (RXR) agonists. We will test if RXR agonists can delay or reverse diabetes-induced retinal damage and investigate the mechanism of RXR-based therapy at cellular and molecular levels.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Recent human neuroimaging studies have revealed systematic differences in how the brain represents perceptual experience versus memories of perceptual experience. IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Maternal cardiovascular and hemodynamic adaptations during pregnancy are critical for accommodation of the developing embryo and fetus. Insufficient changes in cardiovascular function can lead to numerous pregnancy complications and represent a major risk for maternal and fetal health. We aim to develop a dynamical model of cardiovascular function in pregnancy that will serve as a tool to aid understanding of cardiovascular maladaptations in pregnancy and guide personalized therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Biology of Aging program at the Gerontological Society of America (GSA) 2024 Seattle meeting is organized in accordance with the GSA’s mission to promote interactions between biologists and other scientists of diverse disciplines focused on aging, age-related disease and disability; and the social, psychological, and public policy impacts of an aging society. The goals of the Biology of Aging program are to (1) present cutting-edge advances in biology of aging research that provide new avenues for translation to human well-being and extension of healthy human lifespan and (2) to expand the diversity of scientists actively participating in biology of aging research. Our program shows that 31% of our speakers are early-stage investigators, 42% are women, and 29% are from underrepresented minority groups.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: Project Narrative Despite the known association between the quality of participant relational engagement with service providers and clinical outcomes, limited studies have examined caregiver Relational Responsiveness (RR) as a mechanism to achieve maltreatment prevention program outcomes. Using a realist-informed mixed method approach, this study will examine RR’s role in mediating the effects of a community-based maltreatment prevention program, the Family Success Network (FSN) on protective factors against maltreatment and the contexts within which RR’s mediation effects are activated or inhibited. This study will advance the Healthy People 2030 priority area of injury and violence prevention by building the base for the science of caregiver engagement in maltreatment prevention programs and thereby advancing the knowledge of innovative strategies for the prevention of violence.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: CE23-003 - Caregiver Relational Responsiveness (RR): An Understudied Fidelity Construct as a Mechanism to Increase Protective Factors Against Maltreatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Asthma is the third leading cause for hospitalization in children and the leading cause of school absenteeism in the United States and minority children living in low-income communities have an increased burden of asthma. Effective interventions require a multi-level approach and successful implementation requires engaging community stakeholders to develop sustainable systems of care that reach high-risk children where “they live, learn, and play”. Asthma CHAMPS will implement a school- based multi-level intervention that has high potential to reduce asthma morbidity among Baltimore City children and to serve as a model approach that can be adapted to similar urban centers to eliminate asthma disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Overall PPG Narrative: Molecular mechanisms of filoviral-host interactions Ebola virus and Marburg virus are important emerging pathogens with significant potential to impact global public health. Host-viral interactions contribute to disease course and dictate the impact of infection but are incompletely defined for filoviruses. We will address this gap through a multidisciplinary approach that will identify, validate, and characterize filoviral proteins and associated host factors to shed light on critical interactions that drive viral replication and new therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: JOHN D DINGELL VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative The research in this application will first characterize the delayed and progressive emergence of CTE- and psychiatric-like pathologies in a humanized mouse model of repetitive mild TBI. TBI is a major health problem among Veterans and its negative effects are amplified by numerous co-morbid conditions that are known to follow this injury to include cognitive dysfunction, alterations in vision and sleep and psychiatric conditions. An effective treatment for TBI is not available so we will also test new mechanistic-based therapies to protect against the chronic pathologies associated with TBI. Work in this application is aimed at BLRD and VA ORD research objectives to increase the understanding of chronic injury to the brain with emphasis on the long-term effects of co-occurring conditions, and to test new treatments for these conditions.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA NEW JERSEY HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: The number of new traumatic brain injury (TBI) cases for U.S. Military forces has more than doubled in the last five years and will continue to grow. TBI increases impulsivity and the risk for suicidality. Moreover, impulsivity is a risk factor for suicide. This proposal is part of a Collaborative Merit Award for TBI application that will investigate the mechanisms by which TBI enhances suicidality in Veterans. This specific application will test the hypothesis that neuroinflammation and degeneration of serotonergic neurons in the raphe nucleus leads to increased impulsivity in an animal model of TBI. This work extends previous results showing that serotonin is important for decision-making and pontine neurons in proximity to serotonergic neurons degenerate after TBI. The predicted results will identify a key mechanism by which TBI enhances impulsivity and suicide risk, allowing for therapeutic targeting to ultimately benefit Veterans quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: INTERNATIONAL AGENCY FOR RES ON CANCER
PHR: EASTER Application identifier 1161104 Project Narrative We propose to adapt, apply, and evaluate two emerging technologies: a) artificial intelligence (AI) supported spectroscopic detection of high-risk human papillomavirus (hrHPV) in urine for cervical cancer screening and b) AI supported cervical image interpretation for diagnosis and treatment guidance. Together these will represent a fluent, user-friendly and affordable system for cervical cancer screening, diagnosis and treatment selection (ablation or excision) specifically for low and middle income countries (LMICs). Our team comprising of clinicians experienced in conducting field trials in LMICs, internationally recognized inventors in cervical precancer treatment technologies, biomedical engineers in spectroscopy, AI software developers and molecular biologists will work together on an existing spectroscope and device prototype to deliver a comprehensive AI-based solution to cervical cancer screening and treatment in LMICs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: LUNDQUIST INSTITUTE FOR BIOMEDICAL INNOVATION AT HARBOR-UCLA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Persistent bloodstream infections are life-threatening emergencies that pose significant challenges to effective treatment. A disease mystery is central to these infections: the causative pathogen is susceptible to antimicrobials in laboratory testing—but not in the human being. Persistent bloodstream infections caused by Staphylococcus aureus and Candida albicans are increasingly common, but there are few therapeutic options and patients frequently succumb. In this U19 Center, we will use state-of-the-art technologies in synergistic research to understand the host-pathogen interactions driving persistence. In turn, these data will be analyzed using powerful computational methods to detect hidden patterns within large complex datasets. As a result, new approaches to identify and treat high risk patients can be developed and applied to improve and save lives. These goals are ideally aligned with priorities of the National Institutes of Health and Centers for Disease Control & Prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Prisons concentrate people who inject drugs and people living with HIV, especially in the Commonwealth of Independent States of the former Soviet Union, where the HIV epidemic and drug injectors and their sexual partners remains volatile. Introducing and expanding an evidence-based HIV prevention strategy like opioid substitution therapy within the prisons in a legal, political, and cultural context is fraught with barriers that involve the client, prison staff and the criminal justice infrastructure. Implementation science strategies are effective approaches to study and promote intervention effectiveness that simultaneously works to overcome barriers at each level.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: JOHN D DINGELL VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: There is an opioid crisis in the U.S. with significantly increasing mortality risk associated with chronic prescription opioid medication use. Chronic prescription opioid use also increases the risk for sleep apnea and the risk for death in those with both sleep apnea and opioid medication use. However, the exact pathways by which opioids promote sleep apnea remain unknown. There are limited therapies for this disorder. Our research will elucidate the mechanisms by which chronic prescription opioids users develop sleep apnea and will also determine whether oxygen or acetazolamide will reduce or eliminate opioid-related sleep apnea via different pathways. A cumulative effect of our research will fulfil our long-term goal of using novel alternative therapies to alleviate sleep apnea and its associated life-threatening complications in Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: LUNDQUIST INSTITUTE FOR BIOMEDICAL INNOVATION AT HARBOR-UCLA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: IMMUNOMIC AND EPIGENOMICS CORE (IEC) PROJECT NARRATIVE Candida albicans candidemia (CAC) is the most common invasive fungal species in hospital settings worldwide. Similarly, methicillin-resistant strains of Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) can cause invasive and life-threatening infections despite treatment with standard anti-infective therapies. The proposal aims to understand the epigenetic changes in patients infected by MRSA or CAC and the immunologic functions shaping antibiotic- persistent from resolving outcomes. The IEP will provide technical and scientific support in designing and implementing the assays to measure epigenomic and transcriptomic profiles along with immune cells in patients infected by MRSA or CAC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: LUNDQUIST INSTITUTE FOR BIOMEDICAL INNOVATION AT HARBOR-UCLA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: BDM CORE NARRATIVE The primary functions of the Bioinformatic and Data Management (BDM) Core are to provide 1) data management, 2) bioinformatic and 3) biostatistical analysis support to all the Projects and Cores of this program. The Core is required for proper analysis of data generated within each project, for networking of data across projects for complex analyses by the Computational & Predictive Modeling Core (CPM), and for ensuring the NIH-funded research data is findable, accessible, interoperable, and reusable (i.e., the FAIR principles). Services will be provided in the following areas:  · Data monitoring and management.  · Database infrastructure and storage.  · Data upload into public domain repositories.  · Development and implementation of bioinformatics tools and software to create a central data  processing platform of high throughput biological data.  · Selection of study populations using judicious matching algorithms for enhanced reproducibility of  results and mitigation of confounded conclusions.  · Biostatistical design and standard analysis of project studies.  · Assistance with manuscript preparation.  · Education and career development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Combined radiation and checkpoint treatment has shown clinical potential for advanced malignancies including melanoma, however, responses outside the radiation field (abscopal effect) still occur in only a minority of patients. This proposal may provide important insight into a novel mechanism for anti-cancer T cell stimulation which is less toxic and has higher local and distant response rates than current approaches. In addition, it may lead to a re-evaluation of the need for and benefit of surgical removal of the tumor-draining lymph nodes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Recruiting the immune system to recognize and attack tumors is a promising way to treat a wide range of malignancies. However, only a small portion of the cancer cell surfaces can be recognized by immune cells as cancerous. The goals of this proposal are to identify molecular features exclusive to malignant cells and develop tools to mount an antitumoral immune response against them.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: LUNDQUIST INSTITUTE FOR BIOMEDICAL INNOVATION AT HARBOR-UCLA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Staphylococcus aureus and Candida albicans are both organisms that are commonly found on healthy individuals without causing problems but lead to deadly infections in some. The Computational & Predictive Modeling Core will lead the development of new computational algorithms for pattern matching across datasets, to identify commonalities across different types of measurements and between both types of infections. Doing so will improve our ability to predict the outcome of infection and our understanding of how these infections become life-threatening.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pulmonary fibrosis represents a global clinical burden that affects over 5,00,000 people and can occur as a result of chemical injury, chronic disease, or respiratory infection. This project aims to establish a spatiotemporal atlas of the cellular subtypes, interaction networks, and matrix architectures that mediate pathological progression of pulmonary fibrosis as well as post-fibrotic repair, including mesenchymal subpopulations. This systems-level analysis of pulmonary fibrosis will help identify novel targets for both clinical prognosis and therapeutic development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overall goal of the proposed study is to better understand the molecular pathogenesis of immune thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (iTTP) using various biochemical, molecular and cellular biological tools, and animal models, as well as iTTP patients. The project will focus on identifying the structural signatures and mechanism of action of human monoclonal IgG antibodies isolated through single B cell Ig sequencing, and uncovering the potential role of ANKRD26/36 gene family in the zebrafish and murine models of iTTP. We believe that the results of the proposed study may change how we manage patients with iTTP in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative NLRP6 Inflammasome has been reported to play dual roles in defense against pathogen evasion and promoting autoinflammatory syndromes resulting from excessive signaling. Fine-tuning the NLRP6 inflammasome activity through essential cellular processes remains poorly understood, which is critical for homeostasis of NLRP6-expressing tissues. This proposal will investigate the role of nuclear import receptors in the regulation of NLRP6 inflammasome activity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: LUNDQUIST INSTITUTE FOR BIOMEDICAL INNOVATION AT HARBOR-UCLA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Persistent bloodstream infections caused by Staphylococcus aureus are life-threatening emergencies that are increasingly common. An essential unanswered question is at the root of these infections: the pathogen is susceptible to antibiotics in laboratory testing—but not in the human being. There are few therapeutic options in these cases and patients frequently succumb. In this research, we will use state-of-the-art technologies in systems-based research to understand the host-pathogen interactions driving persistence. Powerful computational methods will be used to detect hidden patterns within large complex datasets. As a result, new approaches to identify and treat high risk patients will be discovered and applied to improve and save lives. These goals ideally align to National Institutes of Health priorities.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Over the last two decades, the field of IDD has become increasingly interdisciplinary, biobehavioral, and translational. The Gatlinburg Conference on Research and Theory in Intellectual and Developmental Disabilities has historically provided a unique venue for the exposition and discussion of the latest biobehavioral research findings, methods, and theoretical frameworks in IDD research. The conference has held a key place in the development of the IDD field. It has launched new interdisciplinary collaborations relevant to IDD, has nurtured and supported the careers of a diverse pool of junior researchers working in IDD, and has been the most critical venue for the bringing constructs and findings from basic science disciplines to the IDD research community. Ultimately, the conference shapes the biobehavioral scientific agenda of the IDD field and accelerates efforts to translate research results into innovative programs of treatment and prevention that will improve the lives of people with IDD and their families.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human gammaherpesviruses establish life-long infection in their host by latently infecting resting memory B- cells, however, the mechanism of how this cellular reservoir is established and maintained remains unclear. Polo-like kinase 1 (PLK1) is an important kinase involved in cell cycle control, which we recently discovered to have a critical role in both initiation of γ-herpesviruses latency and survival of viral-infected cells. Further dissection of PLK1’s role in regulation of γ−herpesviruses reservoirs will be valuable for devising therapies that can completely eliminate the pathogens and, in turn, prevent any related malignancies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Acinetobacter baumannii is one of the few types of bacteria that has become resistant to every antibiotic available. New treatments are desperately needed, since the death rate from these infections that are resistant to all antibiotics is high, and no new antibiotics that can kill A. baumannii are in development. The purpose of the current grant is to use the immune system to treat these infections using a vaccine made up of special proteins called antibodies.

PHR: Project Narrative There is an acute shortage of well-trained MD and PhD investigators performing high impact cardiovascular research to combat the burden of cardiovascular disease. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The effects of music on memory in naturalistic settings are not yet well understood. In this  project, we aim to study how memory for films is affected by the presence or absence of the film  score and whether these effects can be measured neurally. This work will help develop new  neural measures of music-evoked episodic memory as well as expand our understanding of music's  effect on memory under natural conditions.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research is highly relevant to public health because hematogenously disseminated candidiasis is a frequent hospital acquired infection that results in a high degree of mortality in adults and neonates, even with currently available treatment. Discovering C. albicans and host immune signatures associated with lethality and persistence during candidemia holds promise to provide new insight into the pathogenesis of disseminated candidiasis. Furthermore, this information may be used to develop new diagnostic or therapeutic strategies against this frequently fatal disease.

PHR: NARRATIVE Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and associated lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) are a major cause of morbidity in aging men. There are limited medical options to treat patients with BPH/LUTS and no new medical treatments have been developed in nearly 30 years. This project will test the efficacy and consequences of TNF- antagonists in BPH/LUTS patients with large prostate volumes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement: Science-based evaluation of the safety of electronic cigarettes (e-cigs) and comprehensive risk-benefit analysis of vaping vs. smoking are urgently needed to inform the FDA’s regulation of tobacco products as well as advise the general public on the health consequences of e-cig use relative to cigarette smoking. This project will make an important scientific contribution to the fields of tobacco research, regulatory science, and public health by identifying molecular changes linked to risk of disease in cells and tissues of healthy adults who are regular users of e-cigs, cigarette smokers, or users of both products (dual users). Our research findings will be translated to lay messages, which can help educate the general public of the ‘pros’ and ‘cons’ of e-cig use relative to smoking.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Every day, humans must synchronize or entrain their internal body clock to the daily light-dark cycle for optimal physiological functioning. This proposal will uncover the influence of diet on the ability to entrain, circadian timing, and the consequences of an inability to entrain quickly. The findings from this project will not only be potentially paradigm shifting in the field of human circadian rhythms, but will also be critical to the cardiometabolic health and well-being of every individual.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Palatogenesis involves growth of bilateral embryonic palatal shelves, vertically next to the tongue, followed by elevation above the tongue in order to fuse; failure of this process leads to cleft palate, a common birth defect that can occur alone or as part of many syndromes. The dynamics of the elevation process are not understood; therefore, we aim to study normal and abnormal palatal shelf elevation as well as the effect of maternal folic acid supplementation, using novel mouse mutants, cellular and molecular analyses, and in utero time-lapse imaging. Knowledge of palatal shelf elevation dynamics at the tissue, cellular and molecular levels will help identify the etiology and potential therapeutic strategies in patients with orofacial clefts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative (Relevance Statement): The Sonic Hedgehog (SHH) signal transduction pathway is an essential regulator of organ and tissue development that when corrupted leads to developmental disorders and cancers. The goals of my research are to define the mechanisms by which SHH is deployed from its site of synthesis to reach cellular targets with temporal and spatial precision for induction of specific responses in receiving cells. Knowledge obtained from the proposed studies will enhance our understanding of the mechanisms controlling an essential developmental process and may reveal novel methods of targeting the SHH pathway in disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Candidemia is the most common invasive fungal species in hospital settings worldwide, causing about 65% of systemic candidiasis infections. The mortality rate for these infections is 40% despite treatment with antifungal therapies. The goal of this research is to determine if pathogen-induced epigenetic changes exist in patients infected by C. albicans and MRSA that drive immunologic functions shaping antibiotic-persistent from resolving and survival outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Reversal of latent HIV-1 to its transcriptionally active form represents possibly the only way in which a latent HIV-1 infected cell can be identified. Our proposed studies aim to examine the role of a dietary hormone, insulin, on promoting latent HIV-1 transcription. In the long-term, the proposed studies will hope to provide a rationale for studying current and future HIV-1 cure therapies in persons living with HIV-1 who also have Type 2 Diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health as many patients with Chronic Overlapping Pain Conditions (COPCs) often complain of general hypersensitivity to touch, sound and everyday light. This research will identify neural signatures of hypersensitivity among chronic pain patients through investigating functional (F99) and casual (K00) interactions between sensory and pain processing brain regions to enhance our understanding of COPCs and lead to future studies on how to adjust altered sensory processing through interventions. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH's mission that pertains to uncovering new knowledge through translational neuroscience research that will help detect and reduce the burden of hypersensitivity among patients with chronic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: We hypothesize that the cornea routinely suffers minor traumas from, for example, aggressive eye rubbing, which lead to quickly repairable injuries of the plasma membrane of corneal cells. These repairable injuries allow a burst calcium of to enter the cells, which in turn triggers signaling events that result in intercellular calcium waves. We propose to examine the signaling pathways that lead to this corneal calcium wave response along with the physiological consequences of those calcium waves, and how they contribute to corneal health in normal and diabetic corneas.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Polycystic ovary syndrome is one of the most common endocrinopathies in women, presents with anovulation in adolescence, and reproductive dysfunction is related to excess weight. After a 4-month observation period of either no medication or metformin treatment, females aged 12-35 years with obesity and polycystic ovary syndrome will receive 10 months of a glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor agonist to induce metabolic changes, weight loss and improve reproductive abnormalities. We will assess the relationship between weight loss and reproductive function, as well as identify if age, hormonal and metabolic measures and such insulin sensitivity and insulin secretion predict the response to glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor agonist therapy.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Roughly 25% men over the age of 50 will suffer an osteoporotic fracture during their senior years, and the 1- year mortality rate following a hip fracture is nearly 2× as high for men as for women. One-fifth of those who were ambulatory before their hip fracture require long-term care afterward. Beyond their age, other lifestyle factors make veterans particularly susceptible to osteoporosis, including smoking, alcohol consumption, and an inactivity. Moreover, many Vietnam veterans were exposed to environmental factors during the war, such as the dioxin TCDD (found in Agent Orange), which put them at much greater risk for osteoporosis. Recently, the VA amended its adjudication regulation to establish a presumption of service connection for osteoporosis for former Prisoners of War (POWs) who were detained or interned for at least 30 days, and more recently, for those diagnosed with posttraumatic stress dis-order (PTSD), and whose osteoporosis is at least 10% disabling. There is a clear need to identify new treatment options for veterans that suffer from low bone mass disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Chlamydia infections have a large negative impact on women’s reproductive health. We propose to catalogue the cellular and gene expression events occurring from initial infection, to resolution, to fibrotic damage post bacterial clearance in a female mouse model of upper genital tract infections. These studies will provide a unique resource for the characterization of infection-associated inflammatory processes and fibrotic damage during Chlamydia infections.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Overall The DC CFAR's mission is to intensify our multi-institutional effort to promote and support research that contributes to ending the HIV epidemic in Washington, DC and beyond in partnership with government and community. IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Extremity trauma has been a significant combat casualty for military personnel, comprising 58% to 88% of combat wounds, in recent US armed conflicts. These injuries often result in long term functional disabilities and predispose soldiers to chronic pathologies like post-traumatic osteoarthritis. As such, these injuries are a large burden for military personnel, their families, and the whole of the DOD and VA systems. The proposed work will develop new regenerative engineering interventions in combination with rehabilitation therapies that will improve long term functional outcomes for patients after multi-tissue trauma. The outcomes from this work will provide scientific rationale into how quickly the patient can begin to use the limb, how much load to support, and how to implement physical therapy protocols. This information will be disseminated through publications and direct consultation with physical therapist at the Center for the Intrepid and Atlanta VAMC—resulting in improved daily function and ultimately the quality of life of service members, veterans, and their families.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative: Decreasing food intake through Dietary Restriction (DR) is a well-studied intervention that extends lifespan across taxa. This project focuses on how the perception of food through mechanosensation, or food touch, can diminish the benefits of DR in the nematode C. elegans. The resulting data will provide insight into how multiple modes of food perception are integrated by the nervous system to effect health and longevity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Osteoarthritis (OA), the leading cause of disability in the United States, has no effective therapy to slow or prevent disease progression. Oxidative stress plays a central role in the development of OA, however attempts to mitigate oxidative stress with antioxidants have been limited by poor bioavailability and limited stability within the joint. Thus, the objective of this proposal is to utilize a cartilage-targeting nanomaterial with antioxidant-like properties that overcomes limitations of conventional therapies to effectively mitigate oxidative stress, thereby reducing damage to joint structure and preserving joint function in post traumatic OA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Patients with diabetes diagnosed with colorectal cancer are at high risk for excess morbidity and mortality and are disproportionately Non-Hispanic Black and Hispanic. Federally qualified health centers, who primarily serve priority populations, struggle to implement and sustain colorectal cancer screening. This study proposes to identify and overcome multi-level factors affecting optimal use of CRC preventive screening options for patients with elevated medical and social risks throughout the U.S.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Wnt signaling is conserved across animals and plays a role in many different developmental processes and diseases, which requires that the same signal activates different sets of genes in different contexts. It is largely unknown how it is possible for a single signal to have different effects and whether these mechanisms are conserved across species and during disease. In this study, I aim to identify the regulatory mechanism that impact the output of Wnt signaling using Hydra vulgaris, which offers the advantage of a simplified system for addressing a complex question.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative As antibiotic resistance continues to remain a growing global health concern, it is vital that novel targets for bacterial antibiotics are identified. Bacterial cell-wall glycoconjugates are central to virulence and bacterial viability and are constructed sequentially by glycosyltransferases (GTs). The outcomes of the proposed project will deepen our understanding of the modes of action of GTs in the biosynthetic pathway of glycoconjugates, providing the necessary structural and biochemical information for new therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The study proposed in this application exhibits substantial promise to quantify motoneuron physiology in the underrepresented population of females and identify a mechanism behind sex differences in motoneuron discharge. Additionally, this is the first quantitative study to examine motoneuron discharge properties across the menstrual cycle. The proposed paradigm is positioned to increase knowledge on female motoneuron physiology, and aid in the understanding of what causes sex differences in the progression of neurological disease.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Sterile processing departments (SPDs) clean and repack reusable surgical instruments. Unfortunately, about 15% of surgical instrument trays have problems that can lead to a range of safety and efficiency problems. We propose to extend our previous Work Systems Analysis to develop interventions, improve data-analytic approaches, and study administrative decision making, across multiple SPD facilities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Perivascular fibrosis, which is the progressive accumulation of non-cellular extracellular matrix, decreases normal vascular function and increases vessel stiffness. The studies in this proposal focus on the contribution of a unique population of resident vascular stem cells in the development of fibrosis as these cells lose their stemness phenotype and switch to a phenotype for producing matrix in the setting of vascular disease. We aim to define the mechanisms that control the phenotype of these vascular stem cells in the setting of vascular disease, to define the response to vascular injury and the role of these stem cells in a novel adult mouse model that demonstrates remarkable wound healing without fibrosis, and to define the anti-fibrotic effect of statins using cultured cells and mouse models of vascular fibrosis, which will lead to highly translatable findings that guide the clinical application of statins in the treatment and prevention of fibrotic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: Human neurotropic herpesviruses are linked to poor outcomes in Alzheimer's Disease patients. However, a direct link between neurodegenerative alterations and viral infections remains uncharacterized. In this proposed work, we will extend our exciting findings of infection-dependent alterations in drivers of Alzheimer's Disease in a novel 3D cerebral cortical human cell model. Characterization of the biological mechanisms controlled by these viruses will represent a major advance in efforts to combat this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The co-occurrence of posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and hazardous drinking (HD) can be particularly devastating; though evidence-based treatments exist, many individuals with this co-occurrence drop out from or do not or cannot access specialty care. Text-messaging is a mode of intervention delivery that is low-cost, low-burden, and accessible to most people; development and testing of self-directed text message interventions that use evidence- and theoretically-based strategies to reduce PTSD and HD symptom burden is highly needed. Such interventions have the potential for great clinical significance via providing additional, novel treatment options that are readily scalable and have wide reach and thus can have a large impact on individual and public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance Although there is a substantial burden of hypertension and stroke among older adults in Nigeria, there are significant gaps in implementing evidence-based blood pressure/stroke prevention interventions. The study will engage young people and their older adult caregivers using music-inspired strategies to increase uptake of essential BP/stroke prevention services. Given the ubiquitous and high relevance nature of music, the findings from this study will be relevant to other resource-constrained settings experiencing a high burden of hypertension, stroke, and traditionally underrepresented in implementation research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Clonal hematopoiesis (CH) mutations are acquired mutations in the blood present in the majority of older individuals that may contribute to worse oncologic outcomes in patients with solid malignancy. In this project we will use individual genetic and clinical data to determine whether CH mutations and cancer therapies interact to result in worse cancer treatment toxicity and outcomes and to investigate whether there are clinical markers to determine which individuals may be most at risk for these adverse outcomes. Completion of this project will provide key insight regarding the importance of CH mutations in patients with solid malignancy and guide future investigations regarding whether knowledge of CH mutations in patients with solid malignancy can improve cancer care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Childhood cancer survivors are at an inordinately high life-long risk of anthracycline-related cardiac dysfunction (CD) and radiation-related subsequent neoplasms (SNs). Although there is a dose-response relation between these therapeutic agents and CD or SN, there is significant inter-patient variability in risk, suggesting the moderating role of genetic predisposition. This Outstanding Investigator Award application breaks new ground by harnessing and merging novel concepts from the field of molecular biology, pharmacogenomics and cancer survivorship to identify childhood cancer patients by their personal risk of CD or SN, such that personalized management approaches can be instituted to mitigate this burden of morbidity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative How the exact same DNA sequence that is present in every cell gives rise to cellular diversity has been at the center of biological research for many decades. This process involves the orchestrated recruitment of hundreds of regulatory factors to precise DNA and RNA regions in the nucleus, yet, it remains unclear how these numerous regulatory components reliably assemble, interact with their targets, and quantitatively control gene expression. Here we will develop highly innovative methods to measure the combinatorial and 3-dimensional spatial assembly of hundreds of molecules, their dynamics across time, and their quantitative role in gene regulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Even in the context of viral suppression, WLWH have higher rates of cognitive impairment (CI) and stronger associations with many of the underlying CI biopsychosocial risk factors as well as unique sex-specific risk factors. We aim to examining putative biological pathways involving immune activation and neurobiological pathways (i.e., depletion of neurotransmitters, increased neurotoxic metabolites, and neuronal damage) to identify the markers that can be tightly linked to the clinical course of CI phenotypes in WLWH. This project examines also the role of psychosocial factors in impairing cognitive functions by exacerbating immune activation and neurobiological pathways directly and indirectly through ART levels adherence among WLWH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) has a high mortality rate and its incidence exhibits significant sexual dimorphism, as males have a higher risk for developing HCC than females. This proposal will utilize a new model that we developed of diet-induced progression of NASH to HCC that recapitulates key changes observed in the human disease to examine previously unrecognized roles of sphingosine kinase 2, an enzyme that regulates the balance of bioactive sphingolipid metabolites, in sexual dimorphism of HCC. The proposed studies have strong mechanistic and translational significance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Getting and keeping people with HIV (PWH) on HIV treatment and virally suppressed (i.e., can no longer transmit the virus) is critical to ending the HIV epidemic in the US, but many PWH still face numerous barriers accessing HIV care, especially if they experience complex needs like poverty or untreated mental health conditions. This study evaluates a set of low-barrier care strategies adapted for Ryan-White-funded HIV primary care clinics designed to make it easier for PWH with complex needs to get into care. Results from this study will facilitate the use of low-barrier care strategies in new settings to reach more PWH who are currently out of care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Tibial shaft fractures are a common injury resulting in significant problems including inability to return to work and societal functions. The identification of how individuals load their limb over time and how physical therapy contributes to tibial loading is unknown. We propose to define how individuals increase load over time, how physical therapy loads the tibia, and how recovery is influenced by loading.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Structurally dissecting APOBEC3s for HIV-1 restriction and beyond The human immune system protects us against pathogens but can cause problems when the system goes awry. Implicated in both innate and adaptive immunity, the AID/APOBEC family of enzymes are cytidine deaminases with differential roles of still limited understanding. A subset of APOBEC3s (A3s) were initially discovered to potently restrict HIV-1, including A3G, A3F and A3H. However, A3 activity can be a double-edged sword. If not properly regulated, DNA-editing A3s that also have access to the nucleus can deaminate self-genomes, potentially instigating cancer. In this proposal we are leveraging our complementary strengths through a multi-disciplinary approach combining structural biology, biophysics, enzymology, chemistry and virology, to characterize the molecular interactions and differential specificities of A3s to nucleic acids and HIV-1 Vif, which will provide epitopes that once characterized will be target sites for future therapeutic development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative Dysregulation of neural progenitor proliferation during cortical development can lead to neuropediatric diseases, yet the mechanisms regulating proliferation of these cells remain poorly understood. We will focus on the disease-related gene ZBTB7A, to understand how disruption of epigenetic mechanisms modulating gene expression in NPs can lead to disease. Therefore, these studies will provide new insights into the epigenetic mechanisms regulating the development of the cerebral cortex, and how disruption of these mechanisms can lead to neuropediatric diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE My colleagues and I have identified many of the cellular components required to assemble β-barrel proteins, surface-exposed lipoproteins, and lipopolysaccharide in the outer membrane and we have provided evidence for a diffusive mechanism of phospholipid transport from the inner to the outer membrane. We wish to understand, in molecular detail, how these components function to assemble this asymmetric lipid bilayer outside of the cell in an environment that lacks ATP. We have used our knowledge of outer membrane biogenesis to demonstrate that the surface-exposed components are attractive new drug targets that not only kill the cell but also disrupt the outer membrane barrier, rendering strains more sensitive to existing antibiotics, and thus could be especially effective in combination therapies.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative The safety and health outcomes of hospitalized patients are contingent on having enough nurses staffed at the bedside to provide around the clock surveillance and deliver high-quality care; however, U.S. hospitals have historically chronically understaffed nurses. The COVID-19 public health emergency is further threatening the safety of hospitalized patients, with chronically overextended nurses reporting unprecedented rates of burnout and leaving hospital employment. Using multiple linked data sources of millions of patients, thousands of nurses, and hundreds hospitals during a pre-pandemic baseline, and 1 and 3 years after the pandemic onset, we evaluate the impact of the public health emergency on outcomes of hospital nurses; determine whether better nurse staffing and nurse-friendly work environments pre-pandemic buffered nurses from poor outcomes during the pandemic; and determine whether patient outcomes, measures of safety, quality, and value, track with changes in nurse outcomes in order to refine scientific understanding of potentially causal relationships and inform effective solutions to improve outcomes.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Learning from Hospital Preparedness during COVID: Chronically Under-Resourced Nurses and Patient Safety
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Healthcare Patient Safety and Quality Improvement Research[HSQR]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Osteonecrosis of the femoral head (ONFH) is a disease in which a segment of bone within the femoral head (the ball portion of the hip joint) dies, resulting in painful arthritis. There has been increasing interest in delivering autogenous bone marrow aspirate concentrate (BMAC) harvested from the patient’s own pelvis to treat early stage ONFH, to try to save the femoral head and avoid hip replacement surgery. The goal of this study is to conduct a prospective, randomized multicenter clinical trial to compare the outcome of patients who have ONFH undergoing core decompression alone (drilling of the femoral head) versus core decompression supplemented with the patients’ own BMAC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Fat reserves release hormones called adipokines that act on neural circuits to regulate decisions on several physiological processes including hunger, immunity, and reproduction. If not tightly coupled to energy status, adipokine release is detrimental to the organism and leads to obesity and metabolic disorders. By studying how fat stores communicate nutrient state to an organism we will elucidate the molecular and cellular mechanisms that underpin healthy energy balance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: OVERALL: PROJECT NARRATIVE The HD2A Research Adoption Support Center (RASC) assembles a uniquely qualified team with expertise in dissemination and implementation (D&I) science spanning substance use disorder and pain intervention research and practice, and across the four pillars of the US Health & Human Services National Overdose Prevention Strategy. Organized by four synergistic, dynamic cores, the RASC is steadfast and strategically focused on assessing, supporting and enhancing the D&I capability of the HD2A Innovation Projects—nimbly and adaptively responding to intervention research studies of any type, at any stage of development, in any setting, using any research design, and regardless of the intervention provider and/or its intended recipients. The RASC meets all stipulated requirements as outlined in the RFA, but has greater ambitions: To shift the paradigm in D&I science for substance use and pain intervention research, and thereby improve equitable access to the best health care available for persons and communities living with substance use disorders and pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Culturally grounded mental health prevention interventions hold significant promise to reduce suicide among American Indian/Alaska Native (AI/AN) youth, a group at highest risk in the nation. However, there is little research to understand how core components included in these interventions impact mental health outcomes and promote resiliency against suicide. The proposed study with White Mountain Apache Tribe research partners will focus on an innovative, culturally grounded AI youth suicide prevention intervention, “The Elders’ Resilience Curriculum,” to: a) identify core components that impact protective factors against suicide; b) develop a youth resilience theoretical model; c) culturally adapt measures to assess outcomes; and d) pilot a culturally acceptable and rigorous evaluation to inform future research and scaling of this intervention to other AI/AN communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Autophagy is a catabolic cellular process that maintains homeostasis and delays aging through the selective degradation of intracellular material. The bridge-like lipid transfer protein ATG2 is essential to this process and tissue specific ablation of this autophagy protein decreases organismal lifetime and increases age-related tissue deterioration. This project seeks to elucidate the mechanism by which ATG2 delivers lipids to directly expand the nascent autophagosome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Skeletal metastases are detected in >90% of patients with advanced prostate cancer and eventually are determinant contributors to their demise. Current standards of care extend life expectancy but do not cure the metastatic stage of this disease. While the events sustaining skeletal metastasis have not been fully defined, our preliminary studies implicate prostate cancer cells lacking the Androgen Receptor (AR) or with this receptor functionally blocked and expressing the cytokine Interleukin-1beta (IL-1β) in establishing a microenvironment conducive to tumor colonization and resistance to AR-targeting therapies. We intend to reveal the molecular mechanistic underpinning of this process and identify novel therapeutic targets to be pursued in combination to the AR- targeting therapeutics currently available.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Synthetic biology holds the promise of transforming the development of diagnostic and treatment strategies for various diseases. This project applies synthetic biology approaches to reprogram fate decisions toward progressive cellular deterioration, a key factor in many diseases, such as cancers, diabetes, and neurodegenerative diseases. Key insights obtained from this project will define foundations for chemical or gene- based strategies to treating diseases related to progressive cellular deterioration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Influenza A virus (IAV) infection and pneumonia represent the leading infectious causes of death in the United States, and disproportionately affect the elderly. Regulatory T (Treg) cells coordinate the resolution of lung injury, but the mechanisms underpinning the loss of pro-endothelial repair function in Treg cells from aged hosts remains unknown. We aim to uncover the transcriptional and functional changes that determine the gain and loss of pro-endothelial cell repair function in Treg cells following viral pneumonia throughout the lifespan.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE OVERALL Although potential new possibilities for human disease treatments are being discovered more rapidly than ever before, the translation of these possibilities into clinical application remains cumbersome and slow. Some of this inefficiency is due to uncertainties that arise because available animal models may not accurately and sufficiently represent details of the human disease. The pilot JAX Center for Precision Genetics (JCPG) is a multi-component Center that will build on a robust infrastructure designed to serve the biomedical community by refinement of a public-facing pipeline that operates to first identify pressing needs, and then design, create and distribute new mouse models that are specifically tailored to the disease characteristics of the patient population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Intervertebral disc degeneration is one of the greatest contributors to low back pain, yet how the intervertebral disc can generate pain remains poorly understood. This work will measure activation of sensory nerves involved in transmitting pain to the central nervous system, in an animal model of IVD degeneration. This would reveal new information about intervertebral disc “cross-talk” with the nervous system that may suggest novel interventions for treatment of discogenic pain.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Project Narrative Annually, over 250 million patients receive dental care and yet, little is known about diagnostic failures in dental clinics. Estimates from the medical profession suggest that between 10-15% of patients are misdiagnosed, and there are significant reasons to suggest that diagnostic failures are prevalent in dentistry too. In this study, we seek to identify diagnostic failures, and examine the link between diagnostic failures and clinical outcomes.

PROJECT_TITLE: Diagnostic Failures in Dentistry
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Healthcare Patient Safety and Quality Improvement Research[HSQR]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Transcatheter left atrial appendage occlusion with the Watchman device was developed and approved for reducing ischemic stroke risk in patients with atrial fibrillation who are not good candidates for long-term anticoagulation. As this technology becomes increasingly adopted in clinical practice, efficient methods for assessing the long-term safety and effectiveness of the Watchman device following regulatory approval are needed. This research will use a national registry of left atrial appendage occlusion, Medicare claims data, and qualitative data from patients to assess how different data sources and methodologic approaches can be utilized to evaluate outcomes related to the Watchman device in real-world practice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Cancer can be caused by a certain class of DNA mutations, called “structural variants”, that break apart DNA, then re-join it incorrectly. This can cause DNA to fold improperly and can contribute to genes being turned on inappropriately; however, when and where this leads to altered gene activation is not clear. This proposal will investigate when, where, and how structural variants cause DNA misfolding and inappropriate gene activation in cancer cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative  Deficits in cortical speech processing are hallmarks of heritable developmental disorders including auditory processing disorder, specific language impairment, and autism, which involve additive effects of many genes. The short-term goal of my research is to elucidate genetic contributions to communication sound processing in higher auditory cortex by comparing neural responses to vocalizations in songbirds, an animal model of speech processing, that differ in genetic background and have specific differences in vocal behavior. In the long term, my findings will fuel investigation into genetic mechanisms of sensory limitations in central auditory disorders that underlie deficits in processing vocal sounds and sound sequences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Over the past five years, our R35-supported research led to a new paradigm for the treatment of B-cell tumors: Unlike other cancer-types, B-cell malignancies are highly susceptible to targeted engagement of negative selection, a B-cell-intrinsic mechanism to protect against harmful autoantibodies and autoimmune disease. Contrary to established dogma, mechanisms of negative selection are not only active in preventing autoimmune disease but also represent an entirely novel class of therapeutic targets in B-cell malignancies. The main impetus of this renewal application is now to leverage these new concepts for the development of treatment strategies that will overcome conventional mechanisms of drug-resistance in B-ALL, CLL and mantle cell lymphoma.
