IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is a progressive and fatal disease with highly variable clinical course and limited treatment options. This proposal aims to develop and validate a multimodal, noninvasive imaging protocol to investigate a pathway-specific route for IPF therapy. The outcomes of this work have the potential to accelerate development of IPF interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Part of the NIH mission is to seek fundamental knowledge about the nature and behavior of living systems, and to apply that knowledge to enhance human health and lengthen life. Our proposed research is relevant to this mission because it seeks to understand novel yet conserved pathways of protein degradation in yeast and plants that can be developed as models to study ageing and provide information relevant to a wide range of human aggregation-prone pathologies, including Alzheimer’s, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, Huntington’s, Parkinson’s diseases, and related multi-system proteinopathies. As such, information obtained from our continued studies on the autophagic turnover of dysfunctional proteasomes (proteaphagy) and CDC48 (p97/VCP in humans) and from our discovery of novel autophagic receptors/adaptors should be directly relevant to efforts aimed at improving human health by helping identify novel therapeutic strategies for a host of amyloid-related diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE This work will identify the molecular receptors and sensory neurons that disease vector mosquitoes use to detect the body heat and humidity from human hosts, and establish their roles in promoting mosquito blood- feeding. As blood-feeding supports disease transmission, these basic science findings have potential relevance for vector control efforts by, for example, identifying molecular and cellular targets for developing new chemical repellents, masks or baits.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative Understanding the health and health care consequences of the COVID-19 pandemic, and whether universal access to affordable health insurance for poor and low-income persons mitigates these consequences, is essential to inform policymaking regarding how to protect Americans when they experience health or economic setbacks or when economic or public health crises strike. Access to affordable health insurance for poor and low-income persons currently differs across states because only 35 states and the District of Columbia adopted the Medicaid expansion to all working-age adults with incomes below 138% of poverty permitted under the Affordable Care Act (ACA). Using data from two highly regarded, representative national surveys— the National Health Interview Survey (NHIS) and the Medical Expenditure Panel Survey (MEPS)—we propose to assess the protective effects of the ACA Medicaid expansion on the following outcomes for adults and children following the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic: (1) health insurance coverage; (2) access to and use of health care, health care expenditures, and financial stress; and (3) health outcomes, including physical and mental health.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: The Medicaid expansion in the age of COVID-19: Effects on coverage, access, use, financial stress, and health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: There is a growing evidence base that mind and body practices are effective treatment for chronic medical conditions. Yet implementation into clinical care has not widely occurred. Electronic health approaches may also facilitate integration of mind and body practices into patient care. This award will be key to providing the dedicated protected time necessary to expand the candidate's research and increase her mentoring capacity. Her research and mentoring will expand into the implementation of mind and body practices for chronic medical conditions in clinical care and into electronic health to facilitate patient uptake of theses practices.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Aging is a major risk factor for dementia, which is a particularly devastating disease in older people, yet we still do not fully understand the mechanisms behind this. Current treatments for dementia are inadequate for people of all ages. My proposed research will determine how mitochondria and inflammation in blood vessels in the brain enhance cognitive decline with the goal of improving treatment for dementia and related diseases in blood vessels of the brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  Current gold-standard diagnostic techniques for Autism Spectrum Disorder rely on behavioral observation, and diagnosis is often not conferred until after age 4. This delay is unfortunate, because early intervention can drastically improve outcomes. This proposal seeks to identify and validate early-emerging neurobiological markers of ASD that occur before behavioral symptoms manifest to serve as diagnostic, risk, and/or treatment response biomarkers of social dysfunction in ASD.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A significant number of youth experience concussive symptoms lasting greater than one month (Persistent Post-Concussive Symptoms, PPCS), and there is scant research to guide treatment. This study will definitively determine the efficacy of a smartphone-delivered rehabilitative exercise intervention for treating PPCS in youth, examine long-term effects on health-related quality of life, and explore a novel potential mediator, Fear- avoidance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: One out of every 11 people have diabetes and about 10% of them administer insulin for blood glucose regulation. Automated insulin delivery is an advanced treatment to reduce the burden of managing glucose regulation. New wearable devices enabled streaming physiological information of a person. Multivariable automated insulin delivery integrated with artificial intelligence leverages physiological and glucose information, and provides a well-integrated user-friendly technology with minimal burden on the user.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Cisplatin chemotherapy is standard care for many cancers but is toxic to the kidneys, though the basis for this toxicity remains unclear to this day. We have recently developed a genetically engineered APE2 mouse model that affords a clearer understanding of this unwanted toxicity, and we will use this knowledge to guide future drug development aimed at reducing, or even entirely avoiding, cisplatin-induced acute kidney injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Rapid-growing nontuberculous bacterium Mycobacteroides abscessus is recognized as an emerging pathogen with a rising US incidence for individuals with underlying structural lung conditions such as bronchiectasis, cystic fibrosis, and chronic obstructive pulmonary diseases. While it causes chronic disease that leads to rapid lung function decline, existing treatment options require more than a year of daily treatment with antibiotics of poor efficacy and significant toxicities. Here, our aim is to develop new treatment regimen that is orally administered, safe and potent against M. abscessus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is a common cause of respiratory failure in sepsis with a high morbidity and mortality with no effective pharmacologic therapy. We have previously identified an association between ABO blood type, a genetically determined trait characterized by carbohydrate modifications on multiple cells and glycoproteins, and ARDS risk in sepsis. The aim of this research is to determine the association of ABO blood type with sepsis and sepsis-associated ARDS mortality, to develop a tool to identify those most likely to respond to therapies targeting ABO modified proteins, and determine the physiologic effects of blood type on the injury lung in an ex vivo lung perfusion system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Long-acting, injectable Cabotegravir (LAI CAB) HIV pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) has the potential to prevent HIV among those who experience barriers to effective use of daily, oral PrEP, including many adolescents and young adults (AYA) in sub-Saharan Africa who remain at highest risk of HIV incidence. Disappointing, inequitable outcomes from the initial roll-out of oral PrEP globally and limited utilization of promising injectable formulations in other disease areas demonstrate that implementation success is far from certain, however. This study will identify LAI CAB health system implementation opportunities, measure HCW and AYA implementation preferences, identify preference heterogeneity, and specify implementation strategies to optimize LAI CAB impact in Zambia and globally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: Public Health Relevance This R01 application seeks to develop and prospectively and externally validate ensemble machine-learning- based models to predict recurrence and all-cause mortality after an ischemic stroke as a promising novel approach for risk stratification for targeted prevention. The investigators will use data from three large healthcare systems to advance the manner in which large integrated datasets that are readily available in electronic health records can be leveraged for disease management and potentially improve outcomes for stroke patients. Novel findings derived from this project can be readily adapted to other complex conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Oral health during pregnancy and postpartum has significant impact on a woman’s overall health, birth outcomes and their child’s oral health. This study will provide evidence on how the generosity of state Medicaid dental benefits during pregnancy and postpartum impacts access to routine and emergent dental care. Understanding the effects of dental benefits generosity and duration is critical to inform policy decision-making and implementation of recent expansions of Medicaid dental benefits for pregnant and postpartum women aimed to improve maternal health outcomes.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Environmental influences on Child Health Outcomes (ECHO) Program investigates the roles of a broad range of early exposures on five key child health outcomes among diverse populations. In collaboration with the larger ECHO Consortium, the ECHO-PROTECT cohort based in Puerto Rico will contribute data, biological samples, and knowledge that allow us to better understand how these exposures affect child health outcomes both in Puerto Rico and the U.S. mainland. Results from our study will inform future clinical intervention, risk assessment and policy-setting efforts, with direct relevance to both the underserved population of Puerto Rico and the U.S. general population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Loop diuretic resistance in congestive heart failure and chronic kidney disease is mediated in part by expansion of the tissue mass and sodium reabsorption capacity of the distal convoluted tubule (DCT) and cortical collecting duct (CCD), which severely limits the ability of loop diuretics to reduce extracellular fluid volume in these patient populations. Loss of Kir4.1/5.1 potassium channel function in the DCT and CCD in EAST/SeSAME syndrome leads to sodium wasting and low blood pressure, providing genetic validation for the idea that Kir4.1/5.1 is a target for novel classes of diuretics that could circumvent many of the disadvantages of conventional diuretics, especially in the setting of diuretic resistance. The overarching goal of this proposal is to employ medicinal chemistry, molecular pharmacology, and renal physiology to optimize a series of newly discovered small- molecule inhibitors for rigorously validating Kir4.1/5.1 as a novel diuretic target.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The proposed research will develop a generalizable single-entity method for the crystallization of biomacromolecules with predictive crystal quality. Unprecedented real-time monitoring with electroanalytical and optical techniques will provide quantitative signatures for the active controls of individual crystal formation. Single crystals diffract at true atomic resolution under X-ray and neutron sources will provide unambiguous structure insights to correlate with their physiological functions and roles in diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Supplemental to its classic role as macrophage activating protein, the cytokine IFN-γ has emerged as a critical mediator of barrier immunity, mobilizing elaborate transcriptional programs within non-lymphoid tissues to combat infection. However, the functions, molecular activities, and regulatory circuits of the interferon-stimulated genes (ISGs) that serve as the effectors of this response are largely a mystery. Focusing on the human lung epithelium, I develop an experimental pipeline to map a functional genetic interaction network that underpins the ability of IFN-γ to restrict different classes of pathogens while balancing pathological tissue damage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal addresses the RFA (PA-22-176) call for assay development and screening of chemical probes or therapeutic agents. The urgent need for novel therapeutic intervention strategies is underscored by what has become regular outbreaks of Ebola virus (EBOV), each threatening a potential pandemic of global proportions. Given the rapid progression of the virus and the vulnerabilities in the immune response, a fast- acting, immune system-independent medical countermeasure is proposed that targets EBOV matrix protein (i.e. VP40) as an essential viral protein to produce infectious viruses. This novel approach for a potent, fast-acting therapeutic that is a selective antagonist of Ebola VP40 and viral particle assembly will enhance survival for infected people in hot zones of an Ebola outbreak. We have published our validated drug discovery assay for compounds that will inhibit the function of EBOV VP40 in viral particle assembly. With this proof-of-concept we seek to identify VP40-selective inhibitors with greater antiviral potency that act through a unique mechanism of action on a single target for preclinical development that will address the current sparse pipeline of Ebola therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) is the sixth leading cause of death, but its treatment has been hindered by a lack of human-based models that can mimic key aspects needed to mimic its pathogenesis and treatment: (1) the non- cell autonomous effects of glial, immune, and blood-brain barrier (BBB) cells on the pathology and (2) a 3D BBB that mimics the permeability and selectivity of the human in vivo BBB. To this end I have recently developed a multi-cellular integrated brain (miBRAIN) immuno-glial-neurovascular unit that includes all of the brain-resident cell types that recapitulates key phenotypic and functional phenotypes of the human brain, with enhanced in vivo-like signatures compared to their monocultured counterparts, that I propose to combine with custom microfluidic devices I invented to create and validate 3D-miBRAIN-Chips towards matching human BBB permeability and selectivity in vitro. I will harness these models to probe the effect of the strongest genetic risk factor for sporadic AD, APOE4, constructing and meticulously screening a diverse “in vitro patient cohort,” rigorously validating the platform with a view to translating the technology for maximal utility as an engine for accelerated therapeutic development for AD and other neurodegenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative We propose an ECHO Cohort Study Site in Houston, Texas that will enhance the geographic and racial/ethnic heterogeneity of the ECHO Consortium in a region with complex exposure profles to strengthen the ability of the ECHO Cohort to address research questions related to children’s enviornmental health disparities. We propose scientific aims related to understanding whether maternal discrimination modifies the impact of exposure to chemical mixtures neurodevelopmental trajectories in early childhood; exploring whether associations of structural racism with child neurodevelopment are mediated by exposure to chemical mixtures or epigenetic aging; and to explore racial and ethnic differences in preconception exposure to environmental tobacco smoke and children’s respiratory health outcomes. Further, our proposed research will be enhanced by a comprehensive Plan for Enhancing Diverse Perspectives (PEDP) that leverages institutional infrastructure for diversity, equity, and inclusion, will provide mentoring to team members who are at different career stages, and engage community partners, governmental officials, and advocacy groups with whom we have trusting relationships.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity is a major contributor to the risk for cardiovascular disease and the rates of obesity have continued to climb over the past 2 decades, driven by poor diet, inactivity, and reduced sleep. The support provided by this career development award will allow me to dedicate more time to training the next generation of clinical researchers to ensure they have the skills and expertise to address this important problem. It will also allow me to develop new research collaborations and research skills that will expand and enhance my own research program which is dedicated to improving lifestyle weight loss strategies to treat obesity, reduce chronic disease risk, and improve public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Disorders (ADRD) are an increasing threat to older individuals. Some have suggested that bilingual individuals may be at lower risk for ADRD. If true, this could provide important clues about how to prevent and possibly treat ADRD. However, research to date has featured a range of conflicting findings and murky results. This application seeks to examine the basic premise that individual raised in bilingual homes are at lower risk for ADRD in their later years by using a large, national study of older Americans. It also addresses several related questions, such as whether family of origin immigration, socioeconomic status, or adolescent cognitive ability can explain any links between bilingualism and ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because improved understanding of the neural mechanisms supporting visual attention in the healthy human brain is a key step towards identifying possible ways the system can fail. This basic understanding is expected to lead to new theoretical frameworks from which novel diagnostic and therapeutic techniques will emerge. Individuals with Schizophrenia and those with anxiety can present with impairments in the functioning of visual attention, so identifying the neural processes supporting this cognitive ability in healthy individuals will be relevant for understanding the etiology of these and other neurological and psychiatric disorders.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative To develop generic Orally Inhaled Drug Products (OIDPs), the FDA currently uses the so-called “weight-of- evidence” approach with in vitro testing, pharmacokinetic, and comparative clinical endpoint or pharmacodynamic studies; this approach requires considerable time and resources. To support the development of more cost-effective generic OIDPs, this project leverages latest modeling and simulation approaches to evaluate, whether pharmacokinetic bioequivalence studies along with population pharmacokinetic or standard non-compartmental analysis can reliably support the assessment of bioequivalence for generic OIDPs. This project will consider potential drug/formulation/device related differences in regional pulmonary exposure with the final goal to support bioequivalence assessments for generic OIDPs.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Feasibility of predicting regional lung exposure from systemic pharmacokinetic data of generic OIDPs via population pharmacokinetic modeling and non-compartmental approaches

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Narcolepsy with cataplexy is a debilitating neurological disorder caused by the loss of hypocretin/orexin (HCRT/OX)-expressing neurons in the lateral hypothalamic area (LHA). While HCRT/OX neurons are critical regulators of sleep/wake states, little is known about the molecular underpinnings of their synaptic function. We hypothesize that the synaptic protein C1QL3, which we have identified as uniquely expressed in HCRT/OX neurons, is a critical component of the excitatory synapses that HCRT/OX neurons make at their targets throughout the brain, and is therefore is an important contributor to HCRT/OX-mediated regulation of the sleep/wake state.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this proposal is to identify how phosphorylation of RNA binding proteins regulates the messenger ribonucleoprotein (mRNP) complex composition and downstream events. Defects of RNA regulation have implications in physiologic and disease processes including synaptic plasticity and neurodevelopmental diseases. Investigating how ZBP1 phosphorylation regulates the -actin mRNP in fibroblasts and neurons will provide important insight into mRNP regulation as a consequence of RNA-binding protein phosphorylation.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Telemedicine, the delivery of medical care through live audio-video technology, was incorporated into primary care for children rapidly in 2020 without evidence to inform best practices. While telemedicine offers the opportunity to enhance the delivery of primary care to children, careful examination of the impact of telemedicine on health outcomes and equity across primary care tasks such as preventive, acute, and chronic care is needed. We will perform quantitative examination of visits completed via telemedicine and of children receiving care through telemedicine-using practices along with qualitative identification of strategies to optimize the impact of telemedicine using over 1,000 practices’ electronic health records from 2018-25 providing evidence to guide research, policy, and practice to advance child health and health equity into the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Sarcopenia, the loss of muscle mass and function with age, is a condition bound to increase in prevalence with an aging population. The muscle changes involved include not only reduction in mass but also changes in muscle quality not easily visualized with current methods. This work aims to develop efficient MRI techniques to investigate these changes in better detail, improving scientific understanding of the mechanisms of sarcopenia and how they relate to muscle function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – PROJECT 1 Despite advances in treatments including the introduction of immunotherapies, metastatic or recurrent head and neck squamous cell cancers are typically incurable and, to begin changing this, we propose to develop and investigate a new treatment approach that combines the most common form of immunotherapy (immune checkpoint inhibitors) with targeted radionuclide therapy. Radiation can damage tumors in a way that renders them more responsive to immunotherapies, however conventional radiation therapy typically cannot treat all tumor sites in patients with metastatic disease because of toxicities and the inability to target small tumors that are not identified on imaging scans. Targeted radionuclide therapies injected into a patient’s vein go throughout the body to preferentially deliver radiation to tumors wherever they are located and here we will (1) determine the effect of this type of treatment on the susceptibility of tumors to immune response; and (2) test the effectiveness of this type of treatment when combined with the most common form of immunotherapy in order to determine which combinations should be most beneficial in patients with metastatic or recurrent head and neck cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – PROJECT 2 Successful completion of this research would provide a new tool to stratify HNC patients who are more likely to respond to specific treatments. Single cell CITE-seq of HNC tumors combined with patient-specific bioengineered models could identify biomarkers and provide a platform to test many treatments and thereby predict the most effective treatment strategies for individual patients. Our clinical pilot study which will investigate the feasibility of using bioengineered models to direct patient treatment contributes to our goal of improving clinical decision making and helping provide the most effective treatment for each HNC patient which would have a major impact on patient treatment outcomes and quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity is an area of critical public health concern, as it is associated with significant cardiovascular health risks and the onset of cardiovascular disease; as such, the National Institutes of Health has called for an acceleration of efforts to combat these problems from a multi-level, transdisciplinary perspective. In response to this significant public health priority, this training program, housed within Washington University in St. Louis, a world- class research institution with state-of-the-art resources, has recruited and will continue to recruit highly-qualified pre- and postdoctoral trainees from diverse backgrounds across disciplines and placed them within transdisciplinary mentoring teams with faculty members who are leading researchers in the fields of obesity and cardiovascular disease prevention and treatment. These training experiences are producing a diverse cohort of young scientists with the transdisciplinary research skills necessary to address the complex problems of obesity and cardiovascular disease prevention and treatment across the lifespan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Increasing evidence points to a strong link between prandial habits, such as meal timing and size, to metabolic health—independent of total caloric intake. Although diverse signals are known to regulate meal intake, how mechanical stimulation in the gut is sensed and contributes to the inhibition of feeding is less well understood. Determining the genetic and neural mechanisms that underlie meal size control, and how they contribute to physiology and health, will greatly add to our basic knowledge of the regulation of feeding behavior and influence efforts to develop dietary or pharmacological strategies that target prandial habits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – PROJECT 3 The use of immune checkpoint inhibitors has been a major advancement in the management of Head and Neck Cancer (HNC). However, clinical trials evaluating their efficacy have only shown about a 20% response rate in HNC patients. This suggests that our understanding of how tumor cells and the immune system interface is limited. We have demonstrated that the receptor tyrosine kinases Axl and MerTK on the tumor cells play a role in creating an immunosuppressive tumor microenvironment. Further, we have shown that targeting both receptors simultaneously can turn this immunosuppressive “cold” microenvironment to a “hot” immune microenvironment. We will investigate the molecular underpinnings of how Axl and MerTK cooperate to drive a suppressive environment and translate these findings into the clinic.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative The rates of TBI among older adults in the United States have increased in the last decade, and many more older adults are living with the long-term effects of earlier-life TBI. The proposed project will link three existing cohort studies to Medicare claims data to systematically detail health, function, and clinical care pathways among current older adults. This research fits with the current priority of person-centered NIH/NCMRR to evaluate real-world, outcomes through use of large-scale datasets among individuals with disabilities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Proprioception – the sense of self-movement and body position – is critical for the effective control of motor behavior: dysfunctions of the proprioceptive system can impair balance, motor coordination, motor learning, and cause muscle paralysis. However, despite its importance, little is known about the initial stages of limb proprioceptive processing in any animal. I will utilize the unique and powerful experimental advantages of the fruit fly, Drosophila melanogaster, to better understand how proprioceptive signals are encoded and modulated by behavioral context, as well as how proprioceptive information is relayed to the brain to integrate with behavioral state and motor planning.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative: We will create the Tailored Retention and Engagement for Equitable Treatment of OUD and Pain (TREETOP) clinical research center, an IMPOWR clinical research center at the University of Pittsburgh (Pitt) that develops effective, equitable, and sustainable interventions for chronic pain and OUD that improve engagement in medication for OUD treatment and retention in office-based addiction treatment. TREETOP will prioritize two disproportionately impacted communities for whom equitable implementation of effective interventions can be challenging: rural and Black communities. TREETOP’s success will not only advance the science in this area but will advance the professional development of early- career investigators and help grow our field long-term.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Clotting complications such as deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism (collectively termed as venous thromboembolism [VTE]) are a major health problem, with over 500,000 annual events in the United States alone. There is lack of knowledge of why some patients develop these complications, especially after traumatic injury, and others do not. Our goal is to evaluate novel laboratory tests and therapeutics that will define risk of VTE and that do increase risk of bleeding.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The aims of the proposed research are to identify and test practical, sustainable strategies for implementing a multi-condition pathway intervention for children hospitalized with asthma, pneumonia, or bronchiolitis in community hospitals. The proposed research is relevant to public health because will fill crucial gaps in our understanding of potential ways to rapidly improve evidence-based care and health outcomes for children in community hospitals (which provide care for over 70% of hospitalized children in the US). Thus, the proposed research is relevant to NHLBI's aim of testing interventions for implementing evidence-based practices in community settings and NHLBI's mission of reducing the burdens of lung disease among children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will build a foundational metabolic understanding of tonsils, a common immune organ playing a key role in responding to foreign respiratory pathogen invaders in humans, from children and young adults with sleep disorders. This proposal leverages cutting-edge spatial metabolite, protein, and gene profiling technologies to define a new chemical regulation in controlling a key cell type, B cell, while simultaneously testing clinically relevant differences between anatomically distinct B cell subtypes with unique functions in patients with sleep orders in comparison to controls. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the NIAID's mission that pertains to obtaining new knowledge on how the immune system responds to flu in patients with sleep disorders through molecular research on a dish.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative: This SPORE is focused on several important themes in kidney cancer: 1) using the growing understanding of kidney cancer biology to target critical pathways and produce durable clinical benefit for patients with advanced kidney cancer; 2) correlating genomic analyses with clinical outcomes to identify molecular biomarkers for the purposes of monitoring and predicting treatment outcome; 3) understanding the mechanisms by which kidney cancer becomes resistant to standard therapies and developing effective treatment combinations.

PHR: Narrative: The Administrative Core has been vital to the successful function of the SPORE. It has handled the scientific, administrative and fiscal responsibilities of the SPORE, maintained the expanded communication and educational efforts of the Program with newsletters and conferences and fostered additional research collaborations both within and outside DF/HCC. It has carried out an annual review of SPORE Projects and Cores, directed the selection of Career Enhancement Program Awardees and Developmental Research Projects and shepherded a thorough selection process for new Projects to be included within the initial SPORE competitive renewal and this competitive renewal application.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative: Organizing Biostatistical and Bioinformatic expertise as a shared resource core is a cost-effective approach to ensure that collaboration is readily available to SPORE investigators and an effective strategy to guarantee a high degree of integration among projects with interrelated analytic goals and needs. The primary role of the Biostatistics and Bioinformatics (B&B) Core of this kidney cancer SPORE is to ensure that research conducted in the SPORE benefits from efficient experimental design and data analysis; quantitative methods used in SPORE research are appropriate for the design of the study and for the data, and assumptions required for these methods are evaluated and data collected in the Projects are managed and subjected to rigorous quality control to minimize the possibility of errors and are organized within an overall data model and framework that facilitates inter-project collaboration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Diagnosis of non-precision medicine targetable lung cancer represents a bleak future with lower chance of survival and a poor quality of life. For many lung cancer patients, the only treatment options available are traditional multi-agent chemotherapy coupled with surgery and/or radiation. This project will explore the pathogenic roles of glycogen in lung cancer biology and progression and drive the discovery of personalized therapies that can be leveraged for the lung cancer patients that only qualify for conventional chemotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Most clear cell renal cells carcinomas, the most common form of kidney cancer, are caused by mutation (alteration) of the VHL gene and resulting activation of a protein called HIF2. Drugs that inhibit HIF2 appear promising, but not all patients respond to them and it is highly unlikely they will be curative when used as single agents. This project seeks to understand how clear cell renal cell carcinomas become resistant to HIF2 inhibitors and to identify other proteins that, like HIF2, are selectively required by kidney cancer cells lacking VHL.

PHR: OVERALL – NARRATIVE The Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory Cancer Center is dedicated to making foundational discoveries that reveal how tumors initiate and progress, producing novel tools, approaches, and cancer models that are used around the world. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Adverse Childhood Experiences (ACEs) are a leading public health problem, contributing to poor mental and physical health, substance abuse and other health-harming behaviors, and are often generationally transmitted. In order to reducing the harmful effects of ACEs, research is needed that better explains how childhood adversity affects developing biological systems and how protective experiences can mitigate those effects. The purpose of the Center for Integrative Research on Childhood Adversity (CIRCA) Phase 2 application is to expand on the accomplishments in Phase 1, growing and strengthening a sustainable center that supports researchers with the mentoring, training, and resources to study the effects of ACEs on multiple biological and behavioral systems and identify more effective ways to prevent and treat the effects of ACEs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative: PD-1 blockade-based therapies have transformed the management of advanced renal cell carcinoma (RCC), but too many patients still do not receive durable benefit, and it remains unclear how to best match the right immunotherapy regimen to an individual patient. By leveraging our unique access to informative tumor samples from anti-PD-1 clinical trials and our comprehensive immunopathology and immunogenomics tool-kit for dissection of the tumor-immune microenvironment, we aim to develop biomarkers for durable benefit (to clarify first-line therapy decisions) and determine the key drivers of anti-PD-1 response (and resistance) in RCC. This work has the potential to optimize the application of currently effective anti-PD-1-based therapies for patients with advanced RCC and to provide new and effective immunotherapy approaches for those destined to not benefit optimally from current regimens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The androgen receptor (AR) plays a critical role in lethal prostate cancer and despite initial clinical benefit with AR targeted therapy, both intrinsic and more often acquired resistance represents a major challenge. An emerging mechanism of acquired resistance is adaptation to non-canonical AR activity. Thus, in this proposal, we will test the role of identified master regulatory TFs in modulating non-canonical AR activity that aids enzalutamide resistance and determine optimal therapeutic options to overcome resistance using preclinical models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The development of brain-controlled prosthetic arms promises to provide independence to users, but current efforts suffer from at least two limitations: first, they are limited in their ability to coordinate arm and hand movements due to the way that decoders are trained, and second, they only harness a small fraction of the activity in motor cortex to infer motor intent. We propose to address these two limitations by leveraging advances in our basic understanding of motor control and by testing next-generation decoders in sophisticated and realistic VR scenarios.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative In this proposal we show that expression of the B7 family member HERV-H LTR-associating 2 (HHLA2) is present in the majority of ccRCC and may serve to suppress T cell function and promote resistance to PD-1 blockade. We have developed antibodies that selectively block the binding of HHLA2 to a newly discovered inhibitory receptor (KIR3DL3) and enhance anti-tumor responses. Our goal is to identify therapeutic antibodies that block the HHLA2 Inhibitory Pathway and test the optimized agent in human ccRCC clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Transfusions remain life-saving treatments for patients with sickle cell disease, but patients may develop life- threatening transfusion reactions, referred to as hyperhemolysis, in which their own red cells as well as the transfused ones are destroyed, and their body cannot produce new red cells. Our studies have identified a key inflammatory protein called interferon that appears to both increase red cell destruction and decrease red cell production in sickle cell disease, leading us to investigate its role as a potential driver of hyperhemolysis and as a target of therapies to prevent and treat this devastating transfusion complication in patients with sickle cell disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: HIV positive patients are prone to developing KSHV, and EBV positive B-cell lymphomas with a latency III program, similar to in vitro transformed LCLs, where EBNA3C is an essential oncogene for immortalization. This study examines its functions in reprogramming infected B- cells through regulation of the Rb-CycinD-E2F network by post translational modification. Insights from these studies will provide information about potential targets for therapeutic interventions in treating EBV, and KSHV B-cell lymphomas in HIV Patients.

PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because alpha-synuclein pathology is linked to various neurological diseases including Parkinson's disease and Lewy body dementia, and understanding the underlying disease mechanisms will allow us to develop a novel intervention therapy. Thus, this research is relevant to the NIH's mission that pertains to supporting the ongoing basic research, foster research that has immediate medical relevance, and encourage translational research that links the discoveries from basic research into therapeutic interventions for treating neurological disorders such as Parkinson's disease and Lewy body dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immunotherapy (IMT) has emerged as a promising treatment strategy across a broad spectrum of human cancers, with multiple agents, particularly immune check point inhibitors, showing promising results in various types of cancers. Its full potential has yet to be realized, partly due to a lack of biomarkers predicting response to treatment. Current immunotherapeutic approaches are mostly unsuccessful due to limited understanding of the tumor microenvironment, limited clinical utility of current immune markers and inconsistent use of assays or technologies that produce meaningful interpretations in studies. The MD Anderson Cancer Immune Monitoring and Analysis Center (MDA-CIMAC) will provide a centralized and harmonized platform for sample collection, processing and quality assurance and use analytically-validated and standardized assays and highly innovative assays and methodologies to offer state-of-the-art analyses for phenotypic, genomic, and functional characterization of responses of patients enrolled on NCI-sponsored early phase immunotherapy clinical trials leading to the identification of biomarkers that will ultimately improve the therapeutic strategies for cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We seek NIH support for a diverse cohort of graduate students, postdocs, and early career scientists to attend the 2023 Annual Colorado Immunology and Microbiology Conference (CIMC). The CIMC will significantly improve scientific knowledge in the areas of Immunology and Microbiology including cancer immunology, diabetes, autoimmunity, respiratory immunology, microbial pathogenesis, host-pathogen interactions, inflammation, and therapeutics. The CIMC will bring together the most talented and productive researchers in the field and facilitate their interactions with the next generation of scientists and clinicians.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: KRAS drives transformation and growth of human cancers from several sites, including pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) and low-grade serous ovarian cancer (LGSOC), but therapy targeting KRAS remains a work in progress. Upon completion of this grant, we will better understand the role for DIRAS3, a tumor suppressor, in targeting KRAS, inducing autophagy and potentiating the pro-apoptotic activity of autophagy inhibitors in PDAC and LGSOC, opening a new approach to treating KRAS mutant cancers by inhibiting KRAS dimerization/nanoclustering, increasing autophagy and enhancing sensitivity to autophagy inhibitors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative While older adults prefer to remain in their own homes as they age (i.e., “age in place”), impairments in physical function may limit their ability to do so. Meanwhile, those who undergo residential relocation and those who live in less supportive neighborhood environments experience negative health outcomes including greater healthcare utilization, mortality, and falls with injury. Establishing: 1) whether older adults with cancer are vulnerable to residential relocation in response to impairments in mobility-related physical function and, 2) how such relocation influences cancer-related health outcomes will inform development of patient-, provider-, and system-level strategies to assess and mitigate impairments in physical function and promote aging in place for this growing population. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Adolescence is a critical period for emergence of a range of psychiatric syndromes, as well as for maturation of the cerebral cortex. Investigators have long presumed these events to be linked, potentially in ways that can predict specific clinical outcomes, but until now we have lacked data from sufficiently large, prospective studies to establish definitive or tractable patterns. Leveraging data from the ongoing Adolescent Brain Cognitive Development Study (n=11,875), we will map emergent psychopathology across a range of symptoms to specific patterns of cortical development from age 9 to 16, and anchor these relationships to mediating genomic and environmental risk factors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aging affects global health and contributes to the development of many diseases including metabolic disease and cardiovascular disease. Histone deacetylase 9 (HDAC9) is a regulator of metabolic disease in obesity and here we show novel evidence of a role of HDAC9 in aging. The studies proposed in this application will examine the role of HDAC9 as a mediator of adipose tissue mitochondrial dysfunction and senescence in adipose tissue aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Heart failure is one of the leading causes of death in the United States, but it is currently difficult to predict who will develop heart failure. In this study, we will apply machine learning and signal processing techniques to multiple types of data (electronic health records, electrocardiography, and heart rate variability) to predict heart failure onset, and we will use wearable devices to improve the predictions and expand their impact to a wider population. We expect the resulting tools will help prevent delayed diagnosis of heart failure, leading to improved medical outcomes, enhanced patient experience, and reduction in healthcare costs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative: In this project we will determine the relationship between the genetic and functional diversity of human immunity genes and natural killer (NK) cell driven responses in life-threatening SARS-CoV-2 infection. The exceptional diversity of NK cell functions, driven by HLA and KIR gene variation, arose due to similar threats posed during human history by multiple viral and other pathogens. We will perform a large scale, high resolution, study of this immunogenetic diversity and a functional assessment of the role of NK cells in the development of COVID-19. Our results will help understand why some people or racial/ethnic groups are more likely to develop severe disease upon SARS-CoV-2 infection than others, and lead to therapies that prevent severe COVID-19.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative. Parkinson’s disease (PD) is among the most common neurodegenerative conditions affecting adults worldwide. Deep brain stimulation (DBS) is an increasingly common option for managing PD symptoms. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will directly address the effect(s) of DBS on communication (voice), and airway protection (swallowing & cough), both of which contribute to morbidity, mortality, and reduced quality of life in people with PD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is the most common heritable cardiac disease and is the most common cause of sudden cardiac death in young adults. This project proposes to combine patient clinical and biomarker data with powerful in vitro tools of induced pluripotent stem cell (iPSC) technology, genome editing and tissue engineering, to gain important insights and understanding of potential triggers and molecular pathways involved in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy in Black individuals. Our ultimate goal is to improve patient care and patient quality of life in those who have this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement (Project Narrative) The Caltech/UCLA integrated Cardiovascular Medicine for Bioengineers (iCMB) embraces a humanistic approach to integrate training in imaging or sensing coupled with machine learning to confront the rising endemic of cardiometabolic disease. The joint mentorship with the biomedical faculty alongside with engineering or industry partnership provides an interactive ecosystem for recruiting and retaining our under- represented iCMB scholars. The vision is to accelerate innovation to commercialization via pathways in advanced skills in clinical research design, ethics of human research, and scientific communication as the next generation of leaders in cardiovascular engineering.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Narrative Survivors of childhood cancer often report problems with working memory and executive function (attention, planning) as adolescents and extending in to adulthood. Experiments in this proposal will use a mouse model of cancer plus chemotherapy in early life to better understand how the brain is negatively affected, and to start to identify new therapies to improve cognitive side effects in childhood cancer survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mycobacteria that cause respiratory infections, such as nontuberculous mycobacteria lung disease, require many months and tens of thousands of dollars for treatment. The diagnostic algorithm to identify (or rule out) the organism that is the cause of the infection (and detect drug resistance), is complex because of a lack of a comprehensive, sensitive and rapid test. We propose to develop a molecular test that identifies clinically- relevant mycobacteria species and sub-species that cause respiratory infections and detects genetic mutations that confer drug-resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative This is a renewal of an international collaboration to study the soluble guanylate cyclase (sGC) activator, BAY 58-2667 (cinaciguat), in treating bladder afferent sensitization and detrusor overactivity due to micromotion. Using C57BL/6 mice of both sexes with acrolein-induced cystitis or T8-T9 spinal cord transection (SCT) we have demonstrated improved bladder function whilst overcoming reliance on nitric oxide (NO•) due to nitrergic nerve damage and decreased NO• production or oxidative stress and inactivation of sGC. The University of Pittsburgh team will use in vivo and in vitro approaches to study peripheral LUT functions and the University of Bristol group, an in situ decerebrate arterially perfused mouse (DAPM) to study centrally mediated LUT reflexes. Since cinaciguat has passed phase 1 safety trials for non-urological pathologies, the proposed studies have considerable clinical relevance and translational potential.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Postpartum depression is a common and impactful public health problem, which has severe and lasting consequences for the mother and infant, and sometimes the entire family. The Reach Out, Stand Strong, Essentials for New Mothers (ROSE) program is an evidence-based intervention that prevents half of cases of postpartum depression and was one of two interventions recommended by the US Preventive Services Task Force in 2019. This project is the first fully-powered randomized control trial to assess whether all pregnant women or only those at risk for postpartum depression should receive an evidence-based intervention (ROSE) for preventing postpartum depression cases. This project will help ensure that those who need postpartum depression prevention receive it.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  Imaging the structure and function of intact brains over a large depth and 3-dimensional volume, with high spatial and temporal resolution, is key to understand how the brain works. We will build a new laser and microscope that will improve deep brain imaging by more than a factor of 10 in imaging volume or speed. We will demonstrate the applicability of the system in three key neuroscience problems and provide a path to the commercialization and dissemination of the technology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Only 5% of young children receive mental health care, as most do not exhibit obvious psychiatric behavioral symptoms before age 2 or, more commonly, school age. The overall goals of this program are to 1) identify common biological and brain-based pathways by which prenatal exposures exert their influence on offspring and confer psychiatric risk; and 2) to train the next generation of patient-oriented scientists interested in perinatal- developmental neuroscience.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mental health conditions increasingly present to general emergency department settings; these visits are associated with 1.7 million annual episodes of agitation, defined as excessive psychomotor activity leading to violent behavior and physical danger to staff and patients. Although regulatory bodies and experts emphasize early risk assessment and use of behavioral techniques before agitation occurs, prevention of agitation is limited by lack of knowledge regarding specific risk factors that predict the need for pre-emptive intervention and complex care delivery in the general emergency department. In this study, we will address these challenges by developing and testing an electronic health record-based clinical decision support tool to help clinicians appropriately invest resources for at-risk patients and prevent agitation from occurring.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Many biologically or clinically relevant species present at extremely low concentrations, sometimes down to a few copies. Despite their key functions and diagnostic roles, it has been difficult to analyze these species with existing analytical methods due to insufficient sensitivity, selectivity, speed, or high cost. To address this technical challenge, this project aims to harness the power of optical microscopy and bipolar microelectrode arrays to develop a low-cost and highly sensitive analytical platform for detecting and counting individual biological target species.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Deep brain stimulation (DBS) effectively ameliorates motor symptoms in Parkinson’s disease (PD), however its mechanism of action remains unclear, limiting further optimization of therapeutic efficacy. This study aims to test how delivering burst DBS instead of continuous electrical stimulation can produce long-lasting motor recovery by probing the behavioral effects, and the electrophysiological effects on the pathological synchrony in the basal ganglia nuclei, at various disease stages. This investigation might add to our understanding of the motor dysfunction in PD, while also providing further insights to new interventions in treating patients with PD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obsessive-compulsive symptoms (OCS) such as intrusive thoughts, excessive worries, and repetitive behaviors have a lifetime prevalence of 30%; onset during childhood increases risk for obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD), but can also spontaneously remit with time. To date, the neurodevelopmental trajectory of OCS remains poorly characterized. The goal of this proposal is to use computational methods to identify neural signatures that reliably represent OCS, predict longitudinal trajectories and response to first-line psychiatric treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The proposed research is highly relevant to public health in that survival rates for most cancer types remain stubbornly low despite advances in genomics. This work attempts to directly address this challenge by enabling both basic and translational cancer researchers worldwide to easily discover the key ‘dependencies’ of every major tumor type so that existing drugs may be rapidly repurposed or new targets can be investigated therapeutically. This effort will enable researchers in both academia and industry to advance precision medicine towards greater numbers of patients.

PHR: Project Narrative The APOLLO (APOL1 Long-term Kidney Transplatation Outcomes) study is a prospective genetic study of kidney donor-recipient pairs involving donors of African ancestry. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: SANFORD BURNHAM PREBYS MEDICAL DISCOVERY INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) is projected to be the second leading cause of cancer-related death in the United States and has been recognized as a recalcitrant cancer that requires accelerated research via the implementation of a long-term strategic plan. Glutamine is the most depleted amino acid in PDAC tumors and to bypass nutrient deficiency, the tumor cells augment their metabolism through macropinocytosis, a mechanism of fluid uptake that serves as an amino acid supply route. We have identified new regulators of macropinocytosis that represent novel drug targets for this disease and we propose to study how these enzymes function in PDAC tumor growth and therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative According to the CDC osteoarthritis affects more than 50 million Americans. As such, this project is relevant to the NIH mission and PA-20-185, as it aims to identify metabolite predictors of osteoarthritis in both the synovial fluid and blood plasma. These studies will lay the foundation for early detection of osteoarthritis before the onset of symptoms, which will support earlier therapeutic intervention toward improved clinical care.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Michigan-Ohio Occupational Research Education Program (MOORE Program) is a consortium involving the University of Michigan, University of Cincinnati, and Michigan State University that will develop and provide training and research experiences for graduate students and occupational health and safety practitioners. These activities are aimed at meeting the nation’s need for a skilled workforce that can evaluate, manage, and handle hazardous substances and protect environmental and occupational health and safety. The program will help address needs in four focus areas: exposure assessment, home health care, sustainability and OHS practices, and ergonomics and aerosol exposure, and provide on-line academic and continuing education offerings, research experiences, and dissemination.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Alterations in intestinal microbes are critical factors contributing to many chronic inflammatory conditions such as Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD), celiac disease, Type 1 diabetes, and rheumatoid arthritis, which collectively affect 2.01% of the U.S. population. We have discovered a completely novel role for the protein tyrosine phosphatase non-receptor type 2 (PTPN2) gene, a candidate gene for all of these autoinflammatory conditions, in restricting expansion of an IBD-associated pathobiont, adherent-invasive E. coli (AIEC). In this proposal, we will use novel in vivo and in vitro model systems to mechanistically define the cellular and molecular mechanisms by which loss of PTPN2 activity increases host epithelial cell susceptibility to AIEC invasion, and identify if clinically approved JAK inhibitors can be repurposed to alleviate this risk event.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT SUMMARY Antenatal maternal depression (AMD) is a global mental health problem that is experienced by children in low- and middle-income countries (LMIC) 2-3 times as frequently as in high-income countries and puts them at risk of mental health problems even after maternal depression resolves. There is evidence to suggest that atypical neurodevelopment of the amygdala, as well as its modulatory brain circuits, can be detected soon after birth in children exposed to AMD. However, there is a critical need for refined characterization of neurodevelopmental trajectories from birth to early childhood that can potentially mediate poor mental health outcomes after AMD exposure, especially in low-resource settings. Here, two early-career investigators from South Africa aim to delineate deviations in growth trajectories and functional and morphological integration across the amygdala, insular and prefrontal cortex following AMD exposure. A further key aim is to determine whether environmental adversities aggravate AMD-related neurodevelopmental deviations in a LMIC setting. We propose to include 6 longitudinal neuroimaging datasets that are actively contributing to ENIGMA-ORIGINs for a cross-national analysis of amygdala, insula, and prefrontal neurodevelopment related to AMD exposure in children 0-6 years of age. AMD exposure will be defined by clinically relevant thresholds in each sample. Standardized protocols for harmonized image processing are to be applied to T2-weighted, T1-weighted, and resting state brain scans. Non-linear longitudinal growth trajectories will be estimated for regions of interest, and their intercepts and asymptotes will be compared between AMD-exposed and unexposed children. The two groups will also be contrasted on indices of intrinsic network connectivity and coordinated structural expansion across regions. The aggregation of data across four continents will give the power necessary for analyses stratified by sex and child age, mediation analysis on child internalizing and externalizing psychopathology, and exploration of interactions between AMD and socio-economic status in linear mixed models. Finally, we will utilize a unique LMIC birth cohort with AMD assessment and repeated child brain imaging to examine prevalent environmental adversities such as food insecurity, intimate partner violence, and single/unplanned parenthood as moderators of AMD-related changes to neurodevelopment. This project will provide important insights into critical periods in neurodevelopment for early manifestations of psychopathology after exposure to AMD in the global as well as LMIC context. It will provide a first explorative answer as to whether and how socio-economic advantage can provide a protective buffer against deviations in early brain development following AMD exposure. South African research capacity will grow through mastery of advanced neuroimaging techniques that can eventually be applied to many different types of local environmental adversities and allow us to participate in ENIGMA as equitable, valuable partners. Finally, the project is designed to establish the principal investigators as the world leaders on the impact of maternal depression on early brain development in low-resource settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this project is to develop our mechanistic understanding of the structure and function of the lens alpha-crystallins, and the aggregation pathways associated with age-related cataract formation. We are applying technologies in single particle CryoEM to illuminate these mechanisms with atomistic-levels of detail. These studies will provide critical knowledge required for the development of rational drug-design strategies, targeted at controlling cataracts and a range of other crystallin-opathies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Racial and ethnic minority adolescents in low-resource communities (i.e., high-risk) have the highest intake of added sugar (AS) and are disproportionately at-risk for diet-related chronic disease in adulthood, highlighting that AS is a critically important and potentially impactful target for intervention efforts. This study aims to provide an in-depth understanding of the key drivers of AS intake in high-risk adolescents using ecological momentary assessment, develop a contextually tailored, technology-enriched intervention to reduce AS intake, and assess outcomes using a novel objective biomarker of AS intake. This study will leverage state-of-the-art methodologies to provide high-quality evidence on AS intake in high-risk adolescents and has the potential to reduce diet-related chronic risk during the transition to adulthood.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Despite established guidelines supporting appropriate cancer screening in order to prevent death and adverse cancer-related outcomes, screening is often underutilized. In this project, we will pilot nudge interventions among older adults – including racial/ethnic minorities, low SES individuals, and other high-risk groups identified using novel analytic methods – and tailor nudges to overcome screening barriers facing these patient groups. We will then conduct a pragmatic, multisite trial evaluating the ability for tailored nudges to clinicians and patients to improve vaccination rates and reduce disparities in care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Vaccines represent a highly effective public health measure to protect individuals from infectious diseases by eliciting the host immune response against microbial antigens. Here, we hypothesize that mannans formulated with alumOH induce a potent and durable adaptive immune response to SARS-CoV-2 Spike by inducing specific innate immune pathways and activation programs. By combining detailed immunogenicity and mechanistic analyses, our proposal will define a novel adjuvant formulation for SARS-CoV- 2 Spike and potentially other viral glycoproteins as well as shed new light on the biology of Dectin-2.

PHR: NARRATIVE Relevance to public health Anti-OSP and other antibody responses have been associated with protection against shigella infection. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Certain bacterial strains from the microbiome induce a highly potent immune response pre-emptively (i.e., before an infection happens). In preliminary work, we have found that by gently swabbing a mouse with a skin bacterium engineered to decorate its surface with a molecule from a tumor, we can trick the immune system into destroying the tumor—as though it were bacterially infected—without harming the healthy tissue around it. Here, we propose to build on this observation to make ‘commensal vaccines’ for a broad range of therapeutic uses including cancer, infectious disease, and autoimmune disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of COBRE Center for Computational Biology of Human Disease is to enhance the research infrastructure for computational and bioinformatics analyses of biological research related to human disease. In this Phase 2 proposal we seek to strengthen the collaborations between laboratory scientists working with model systems and data scientists working with computational and bioinformatics tools to accelerate and sustain the implementation of translational medicine at Brown University and its affiliated hospitals. This is consistent with NIH’s mission of supporting bioinformatics and computational biology to advance all of biomedicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  We seek to develop a method for the long-term cryopreservation, or banking, of pancreatic islets prior to transplant. If successful this approach could revolutionize how islets are isolated, allocated, and stored prior to transplant. Further, it would help lessen the organ shortage problem, reduce the risk of transplantation, and improve islet transplantation's success rate for the cure of diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Human hearing is mediated at the level of the hair cells within the inner ear, where the mechanical deflection of the hair bundles results in mechanotransduction. However, the mechanical element controlling the precise and sensitive channel opening is not known: the leading hypothesis for the identity of this element is the filamentous tip link connecting adjacent stereocilia within the hair bundles, which comprises a dimer each of protocadherin 15 (PCDH15) and cadherin 23 (CDH23). This study aims to elucidate the role of PCDH15 in both normal and pathological hearing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Organophosphate nerve agents such as sarin, soman, and VX are classified as extremely lethal chemical warfare nerve agents (CWNA) likely to be abused in terrorism. The civilian populations are at risk if exposed to CWNA, which will cause deaths at high concentrations, but sublethal concentrations cause acute seizures and brain disorders for lifelong if not treated immediately. The current medical countermeasure (MCM) drugs alone are inadequate to prevent the long-term neurological problems, we, therefore, propose to test a combination of MCM and a neuroprotectant, saracatinib (a highly selective Fyn/Src kinase inhibitor which is in clinical trials for various cancers and Alzheimer's disease) or 1400W (a highly selective iNOS inhibitor), in a rat soman and VX model, and a Guinea pig model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The addictive quality of opioid drugs is known to involve changes in the activity of neurons in the brain that utilize dopamine as a neurotransmitter. The search for drugs that can reverse such changes and potentially treat addiction to opioid drugs, as well as the search for analgesics that are devoid of addictive qualities, will be aided by model systems based on human cells. We aim to design such “organ-on-chip” model systems and use them to better understand the addictive process at a molecular level and to potentially identify new therapeutics to treat drug addiction and chronic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Half of pregnant women develop insomnia disorder, which is associated with high rates of comorbid depression. To address a severe lack of empirically supported treatment options for prenatal insomnia, we developed a mindfulness-based insomnia therapy specifically for pregnant women (Perinatal Understanding of Mindful Awareness for Sleep; PUMAS), and efficacy data suggest PUMAS produces large effects on insomnia and comorbid depression. The proposed project is an effectiveness-implementation hybrid type 1 pilot randomized controlled trial to test the feasibility, acceptability, and preliminary effectiveness of PUMAS, and to preliminarily investigate reductions in cognitive arousal as a key treatment mechanism by which PUMAS effectively alleviates clinical outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As current immunotherapies boost T cells to kill cancers, they are ineffective in ~80% of tumors that contain too few T cells (“cold” tumors). We have identified a new immunotherapy to activate a new immune cell called group 2 innate lymphoid cells (ILC2s), which increase T cells to control pancreatic cancer, a deadly cold tumor. We now propose to study how ILC2s increase T cells in pancreatic cancer, so that we may identify better ways to activate ILC2s in immunotherapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Tissue-resident memory T lymphocytes are a population of cells that are poised to encounter and eliminate pathogens as they attempt to invade the intestine and other mucosal surfaces. Understanding conditions that support differentiation and function of this important cell population will provide insight into how vaccination strategies can be modified to elicit protective immune responses.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Cognitive impairments in mathematics affect a significant percentage of children (6%). Some argue that mathematics impairments are more common in girls than boys but this claim is debated. Prior research has not compared the biological markers of mathematics development between gender groups during early childhood. Our research program uses neuroimaging techniques to identify biological markers of mathematics learning in 4- to 8-year-old boys and girls. We also examine the role of early spatial learning, gender socialization, and home learning activities in the neural development of mathematics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: Project Narrative Doxorubicin is a chemotherapeutic drug commonly used in breast cancer but is associated with a major complication called lymphedema, which is debilitating to patients. Our project explores how doxorubicin directly inhibits contractions of lymph vessels, which remove fluid from tissues to prevent lymphedema. There are no known medications to alleviate DOX-related lymphedema; however, we have identified a potential new target for anti-lymphedema medications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: Improving blood pressure (BP) control may represent an important public health strategy for lowering the risk of dementia. We hypothesize that a health-system wide approach with home BP monitoring and a “virtual” collaborative care clinic will safely and effectively lower BP and slow age-related decline in cognition while reducing cardiovascular events and risk, mortality, and health care utilization. If this approach effectively overcomes the numerous barriers to effective BP control, it would have significant public health implications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The main focus of our research is studying the role of SHH-FOXF1 and TBX4-FGF10 signaling pathways in epithelial-mesenchyme interactions during human lung development as well as in etiology of lethal lung developmental disorders (LLDD) and pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) in neonates. In particular, we are interested in an interplay between the pathogenic coding variants and the regulatory non-coding regulatory elements of the FOXF1, FENDRR, TBX4, and FGF10 genes, implied in complex compound inheritance of these disorders. We hypothesize that (i) non-coding variants are promising therapeutic target and (ii) that a little known transmembrane protein TMEM100 mediates SHH-FOXF1 and TBX4-FGF10 signaling during human lung development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our nation is currently nearly paralyzed by the twin pandemics of COVID-19 and inequities in health outcomes among Americans of differing ethnicities affected by COVID-19; so, to address these, we seek sponsorship for this initiative—entitled FRONTIERS IN EMERGING, REEMERGING AND ZOONOTIC DISEASES AND DIVERSITY (FrERZD2)—to train a new generation of pandemic and emerging disease researchers by providing urgent and essential knowledge and the abilities necessary to manage pandemic responses. This training course, offered at Morehouse School of Medicine and Ponce Health Sciences University (a Historically Black College or University and a Hispanic Serving Institution, respectively) will launch and sustain three vital undertakings: sophisticated courses for skills development, addressing the causes, prevention and healing strategies for dealing with pandemics at the national level; relevant vital research experiences addressing these national threats; and career-mentoring activities to promote the careers of specialists in relevant biomedical professions. FrERZD2, responsive to PAR-20-289 (NIAID Research Education R25 Program), is designed for graduate and medical students, medical residents, postdoctoral fellows, and/or early- career faculty and to enhance and expand the research careers of the most promising scientists, with sensitivity to ensuring full diversity in the NIAID workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Early liver transplantation (eLT), defined as LT evaluation with <6 months of alcohol abstinence, is associated with acceptable outcomes for patients with severe alcohol-associated liver disease (ALD) in retrospective studies. However, prospective, multi-center data including biopsychosocial factors on eLT for all patients with ALD in racially, culturally, and socioeconomically diverse populations are lacking. The INTEGRATE collaborative is a highly diverse investigative team that seeks to: 1) define factors influencing referral and waitlisting for eLT in ALD (selection); 2) identify which biopsychosocial factors are causally related and predictive of outcomes most important to stakeholders (outcomes); and 3) determine how integrated care among the healthcare team influences stakeholder-relevant outcomes in eLT for ALD (management).
