IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Early life metabolic dysregulation has lasting consequences on the developing infant immune system and lung, and these changes likely underlie the pathobiology of childhood atopy and wheeze (an early manifestation of allergy and asthma). Knowledge gaps remain in understanding the pathobiological mechanisms of atopy and wheeze phenotypes, which the proposed study aims to address by computationally integrating metabolome and immune response data to identify molecular pathways relevant to the pathobiology of atopic and wheeze phenotypes. Biomarker and pathway identification will aid in identifying targets for primary prevention of allergy and asthma syndromes in the pediatric population, which is of high public health priority.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Proteins that utilize the iron-containing heme cofactor play essential transport, enzyme, and signaling functions in physiology. Our research will provide new information about how the heme cofactor, which is made inside the cell mitochondria, is transported for delivery to proteins that use heme throughout the cell. This research is highly relevant to the mission of NIGMS to increase our understanding of biological processes and to investigate how living systems work from the molecular to the cellular level, and it is also medically relevant for understanding physiology and a broad number of diseases like anemia, asthma, autoimmunity, infections, and inherited diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Translational research in Artificial Intelligence (AI) has been hindered by the lack of shared data resources with sufficient depth, breadth and diversity. There are very limited EHR datasets freely available to the general research community especially the AI research community through direct download with credential-based access. We aim to establish a large cross-CTSA collaborative data sharing for critical care by leveraging the existing CTSA collaborative networks. With the diversified racial, ethnic and geographic profiles from the above CTSAs, with inpatient, outpatient, and ICU data pre-, during and post- ICU admissions, we will provide the data foundation to support fair and generalizable algorithms for advanced patient monitoring and decision support. We will also develop a series of novel AI algorithms to fully leverage the data and advance translations. The proposed project will provide best practice guidance to and set up exemplary examples for nationwide CTSAs. It will also support the cultivation of next generation medical AI researchers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this study is to support patients with hypertension self-management using both home blood pressure monitors and digital messaging programs. We will first engage patients with uncontrolled hypertension in technology training to use home monitors, online portal websites to view their medical record information online, and texting and mobile phone applications. Then we will assess the effectiveness of home blood pressure monitors and enhanced patient-clinician digital communication on blood pressure control during a 12-month intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to use high-throughput and high-resolution single-cell and spatial omics technologies to characterize senescent cell heterogeneity and environments. It will generate multiscale molecular and cellular maps of cellular senescence in primary and secondary human lymphoid organs, representing a highly valuable data resource to improve our understanding of cellular senescence in development, aging, and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Inherited retinal degenerations and age-related macular degeneration affect more than two million people in the United States. For 90% of the people afflicted with these diseases, no treatments have been developed. This project will study the role of a transcription factor STAT3 in regulating mechanisms that slow retinal degeneration. Knowledge from this study will ultimately lead to new therapies to treat retinal degenerations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Many biologically important sequences of ribonucleic acid (RNAs) fold into speciﬁc 3D structures conserved through evolution, but knowing when an RNA sequence includes a conserved RNA structure is not trivial and depends on clues left behind by conservation: covariation and variation. We have developed state of the art methods based on evolutionary conservation to identify when a conserved RNA sequence includes a conserved structure (R-scape), and to predict the RNA structure of those that have one (CaCoFold); these methods are more accurate and have fewer false predictions than other previous methods, which makes them suitable for the detection and analysis of conserved RNA structures in complex eukaryotic genomes. We propose three lines of research: to systematically identify novel structural RNAs in vertebrates with special emphasis on the experi- mental characterization of those involved in human health and disease; to produce novel methods to accurately determine their 3D structure; and to produce next generation methods exploiting pre-covariation signals to detect novel primate-speciﬁc structural RNAs relevant to human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is directly relevant to public health as it aims to advance the clinical management of patients with patellar tendinopathy, a common chronic musculoskeletal pain condition that results in reduced physical activity and quality of life, by applying an innovative whole person healthcare intervention approach. This research is relevant to the NIH mission to improve patient-oriented long-term outcomes by moving beyond outdated traditional unifocal clinical care models towards comprehensive and individualized care models. The expected outcome of this research seeks to stimulate a shift in current treatment strategies and outcomes for patients with chronic musculoskeletal pain conditions.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Sepsis is a life-threatening disease caused by infection that affects many children around the world and can frequently result in the failure of organs in the human body (for example, the lungs, heart, or kidneys). The current criteria to identify children with sepsis are outdated and have many limitations. We propose building a large database containing clinical information about children from both high-income countries and low- and middle-income countries to develop new criteria for sepsis in children using measures of organ function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project seeks to determine whether a stakeholder-informed intervention delivered via a chatbot can be an effective means to reduce suicide risk among cyberbullied adolescents, focusing especially on underserved youth. By intervening proximally to incidents of cyberbullying when adolescents are vulnerable to suicidal ideation, this research has significant potential for public health impact. Ultimately, this research will inform the feasibility and initial efficacy of a digital just-in-time suicide prevention intervention for cyberbullied adolescents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute coronary syndrome (ACS) is a pressing public health concern and post-ACS depression interferes with health behavior engagement and cardiovascular risk reduction. The proposed R34 research will evaluate the feasibility and acceptability of study procedures of the Behavioral Activation for Health and Depression (BA- HD) intervention compared to Enhanced Usual Care (EUC) among 60 adults post-ACS with depression recruited from three distinct regions (Northeast, Midwest, and Southeast). The proposed research will standardize multisite procedures and gather necessary and sufficient information to inform a subsequent fully powered efficacy trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As cells age, the loss of proteostasis leads to the accumulation of excess, damaged, and aggregated proteins which interfere with essential cellular functions and promote the onset of age-related diseases, particularly in neurons and muscle. This proposal will define the biochemical and physiological functions of an orphan lysine methyltransferase which is required for proteostasis, likely its via methyltransferase activity on molecular chaperones and other factors within the proteostasis network. These studies will broaden our understanding of the cellular mechanisms used to prevent deterioration of proteome integrity during aging and aging- associated pathologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE advance our understanding on how to alleviate the intergenerational impact of war trauma among second generation refugee children (SGRC) who have not directly experienced war trauma. This type I hybrid effectiveness-implementation trial tests a family strengthening (FS) model delivered through multiple family groups (MFG) combined with a virtual peer mentoring program called TeenAge Health Consultants (Virtual TAHC) aimed at addressing emotional and behavioral problems among youth born in the U.S. to parents resettled as refugees. The study will provide preliminary data on the potential impact of the intervention on the intergenerational mental health of youth from conflict-affected families resettled in the U.S.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Maternal stress during pregnancy is a major determinant of child neurodevelopment and long-term psychiatric risk. The current study will examine how understudied but crucially important features of maternal stress (timing, unpredictability) shape development of the autonomic nervous system and neurocircuitry in offspring prior to birth. This work holds potential to identify novel mechanisms underlying the intergenerational transmission of psychiatric risk and may, for the first time, define periods of gestation when fetal biology is most susceptible to variation in maternal experience

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hearing loss affects over 40 million adults in the United States and can negatively impact many areas of life for adults. The lack of access to diagnostic hearing tests prevents timely diagnosis and treatment of hearing loss, especially, among adults who live in rural areas. This study will (1) evaluate the experiences and challenges in obtaining hearing tests among adults who live in rural areas and are patients at rural health clinics, and (2) develop a program, in partnership with rural patients and medical providers, which can help rural adults get easier access to hearing tests.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the known dangers of air pollution to children with asthma, little is known about the contribution of radon exposure to asthma morbidity. With recent data reporting indoor exposure to radon associated with COPD morbidity and mortality, the goals of this research project are to understand the effect of exposure to radon progeny found within classrooms on health outcomes of inner-city students with asthma and to identify biomarkers associated with particle radioactivity exposure. The findings of the proposed research will provide important information that may shape public policy to improve the health of inner-city children with asthma and may be used to design public health intervention trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Despite effective cholesterol-lowering therapies, cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk remains a major unmet clinical need. We hypothesize that genes expressed in the artery smooth muscle cells play a prominent causal role in atherosclerotic plaque instability and CVD risk independent of genes affecting blood cholesterol level. To address this, we propose a unique integrative approach, validated by natural “human knockouts,” to fine-map the genome regions for CVD, discover causal genes, and elucidate safe therapeutic targets for smooth muscle cell casual pathways in atherosclerosis stability and CVD risk independent of blood cholesterol.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Neuropathic pain in multiple sclerosis (MS) afflicts over 50% of patients; however, currently available analgesic drugs are inadequate, due in part to a lack of understanding about the underlying mechanisms that drive multiple sclerosis-associated neuropathic pain (MSNP). This proposal aims to use cellular manipulations and pharmacologic interventions to elucidate microglial mechanisms that will guide future development of non-opioid therapeutics to treat MSNP. We focus on the FDA-approved S1PR1 agonist, fingolimod, not only for its disease modifying properties, but also as a treatment for the pain of MS.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This K23 proposal entitled, Towards Equitable Early Identification of Autism Spectrum Disorder in Females, will test the hypothesis that using computational approaches to identify sex-related measurement bias and characterize heterogeneity in early ASD symptoms will identify ASD risk profiles that can be clinically actionable in practice. Training goals focused on conducting community-based screening for ASD, computational modeling of heterogeneity, and dissemination and implementation science, under the mentorship of Dr. Damien Fair, Dr. Jed Elison and Dr. Timothy Beebe will support the career development of Dr. Catherine Burrows, an Assistant Professor at the University of Minnesota. The work herein promises to elucidate novel, clinically actionable screening practices to lower the age of identification of ASD-related concerns.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research will develop and test an intervention, Resilience Training for Teens, which aims to reduce transdiagnostic symptoms and improve social cognition and social functioning in adolescents who are at an elevated risk for a serious mental illness. Thus, this project could provide the basis for a novel, mechanism-based approach to improving outcomes and reducing severe disability in transdiagnostically at-risk adolescents. This project, through a set of four training goals, coursework, and a strong mentorship team, will provide this candidate with the additional training needed to become an independent intervention researcher.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Combined reflectance confocal microscopy - optical coherence tomography (RCM-OCT) imaging may noninvasively guide diagnosis of oral potentially malignant lesions and cancers, with reduced need for biopsy. The imaging in real-time at the bedside may guide diagnosis and treatment in a single patient visit – a “one stop shop” patient care paradigm. The imaging may provide care to deserving patients at low affordable costs in 15-20 low-and-middle income countries, in which high incidence rates and prevalence of oral cancer is a major healthcare problem.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Fathers’ talk with teens about sex can protect teens from risky sexual behavior, but few interventions support fathers’ preparation for and engagement with health-promoting talk with teens about sex and relationships. The proposed project will develop a 3-module prototype for a father-teen online program to support health-promoting father-teen communication about sex and relationships, and to evaluate the program’s acceptability, feasibility, and preliminary efficacy. This research contributes to public health by developing an intervention which addresses fathers as an under-utilized resource to support teens’ sexual health, using novel approaches to maximize father-teen communication about sex.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Sickle cell disease is a painful inherited disorder that affects approximately 100,000 people in the United States, and more than half of these individuals develop chronic or persistent pain that is often severe and disabling. The factors that predict whether an individual with sickle cell disease will develop severe, disabling pain are unclear. The goal of this project is to identify the factors that predict severe pain outcomes in these patients in order to improve pain management strategies and guide future studies of non-opioid therapies for treatment of their pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The nuclear package of eukaryotic DNA is regulated to express only essential genes for specific cell functions and proliferation. The proposed research will investigate how active genes are positioned in the hierarchical genome organization, the movement speeds and directions of different chromosomal regions, and whether we can predict and identify compartments by chromatin mobility and transcription rate in the nucleus. Live-cell imaging combined with biophysical models and high-throughput RNA analysis will be used to dissect the dynamic organization of individual chromosomes and map the active gene positions, which leads to a deeper understanding of the nuclear function and genome stability in single cells under physiological conditions.

Accumulating evidence suggests that activation of Neuropeptide B/W Receptor 1 produced analgesic effects. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immunosuppressed individuals are at increased risk of persistent COVID-19 infection and therapeutic treatment failure, but the mechanisms by which chronic infection, viral evolution, and drug resistance occur in this population are poorly understood. The proposing investigators will leverage an existing translational research infrastructure with experience recruiting cohorts of immunosuppressed individuals with COVID-19 and broad expertise in clinical research, viral quantification, viral culture, sequencing and immunology. The primary goal of this proposal is to determine the host and virologic characteristics that promote chronic viral infection, and the results will provide critical new data about COVID-19 pathogenesis, variant evolution, therapeutic response, and inform the clinical care of immunosuppressed populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: We propose to continue our work—to lead, participate in, and support activities that will maximize the creativity, productivity, scientific rigor, and dissemination of SOBC products and approaches to meaningfully impact health behaviors. Our team created the first generation SOBC website and Measures Repository, and we have developed an innovative and impactful plan for expanding and improving upon those tools, to facilitate adoption of the experimental medicine approach and collaboration between basic and applied scientists. We also propose innovative scientific outreach and dissemination approaches, with deliverables that we will translate directly into tools for use by the broader scientific community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Proposed studies will characterize the autophagy-dependent mechanism(s) that regulate a cell's ability to escape from replicative crisis and initiate a tumor. This research will increase our understanding about the molecular basis of autophagy and its implication in cell death, genome stability, and early stages of malignant transformation. In addition to these fundamental advances, this project has translational potential because it will provide new insights into the roles of autophagy in cancer biology and will enhance the efficacy of existing autophagy manipulation methods.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative A wide array of evidence suggests that relative hypoxia due to medical conditions or high altitude may contribute to major depressive disorder, possibly by causing deficits in brain energy metabolism and serotonin synthesis. The study proposed here is a randomized, double-blind, three-armed clinical trial of combination treatment with two supplements—5-hydroxytryptophan and creatine—that could improve those deficits in subjects with depression who have responded poorly to traditional antidepressants and are living at high altitude. The study uses phosphorus magnetic resonance spectroscopy and resting state functional connectivity imaging to assess physiologic correlates of treatment response, and measures blood serotonin levels to determine how they are altered by the supplements. !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: This project is relevant to public health because flaviviruses are reemerging arthropod-borne viruses that infect millions of people annually and cause hemorrhagic fever, congenital abnormalities, and fatal encephalitis. Despite the urgent global public health need to control these infections, there are no antivirals or licensed vaccines for most flaviviruses, and many aspects of the flavivirus assembly and replication process remain elusive. This proposal will advance our mechanistic understanding of flavivirus assembly by defining the critical roles of structural and nonstructural proteins and their interactions to identify novel targets and strategies to combat these vector-borne diseases, contributing to NIAID’s mission to understand, treat, and prevent infectious diseases.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative This clinical trial will test the effectiveness of a smartphone-based mobile health (mHealth) system called UseIt! as both a standalone and coach-assisted intervention. The UseIt! mHealth system includes both an app and online portal and is designed to work by promoting skills-practice. The project has the potential to increase access to care by boosting the reach and scalability of skills-based psychosocial interventions for childhood behavior problems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/RELEVANCE AMD is a major cause of visual impairment and blindness in the US. Antiretroviral-treated HIV- infected persons have accelerated and accentuated aging, including AMD. This proposal’s unprecedented availability of cryopreserved specimens in both HIV-infected and HIV-uninfected cohorts provides a unique opportunity to evaluate the immune response and inflammation in the pathogenesis of AMD, including correlating systemic inflammation with AMD risk genes.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal is to continue the partnership of the University of Virginia and the icddr,b in Bangladesh as a Research Unit (RU) within the Global Network for Women’s and Children’s Health Research. The UVa-icddr,b RU will continue to add innovative and complementary expertise in infectious diseases, vaccinology, neonatal health, immunology, and human genetics to the robust strengths of the Network. The RU will build on the 30- year history of co-leadership of clinical studies by the PI Dr. Petri and SFI Dr. Haque, and the rich history of sustainable improvements in maternal-child health through the icddrb (most notably the invention and implementation of oral rehydration solution), to help achieve the Network goals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposal investigates a novel therapeutic strategy for management of aggressive p53-deficient colorectal cancer. This novel therapeutic strategy is based on our inducer-amplifier concept for selective damaging of deadly cancer carrying a genetic abnormality commonly found in most solid tumors. Our work provides a novel and immediately feasible plan for treatment of patients with p53-deficient CRC using a combination of FDA- approved clinical drugs that have never been combined before.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Risk for major depressive disorder (MDD) dramatically increases during adolescence, particularly for females, and although interpersonal stress generation is an established risk factor, it is essential to clarify the underlying mechanisms to improve early detection and prevention of depression risk. The current study will utilize a multi- wave prospective design to examine neural and real-world affective reactivity to negative social interactions as prospective predictors of interpersonal stress generation and subsequent increases in depression symptoms in female adolescents at elevated risk for depression. Ultimately, the elucidation of brain and behavioral mechanisms underlying interpersonal stress generation and subsequent depression risk in female adolescents may contribute to greater understanding of the etiology of adolescent depression and aid in identifying novel targets for intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Relevance Congenital hyperinsulinism is a severe genetic disorder associated with high rates of neurodevelopmental impairment. This study will expand our understanding of the pathophysiology of hyperinsulinism and will facilitate the identification of new molecular mechanisms of disease and potential new therapeutic targets for this devastating disease. This study will improve our understanding of the mechanisms regulating insulin secretion in health and disease, and may benefit the development of new therapies not only for HI, but also for diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: The regulation of protein diversity is a highly orchestrated process involving co-translation of transcripts and nascent proteins to their post-translation modifications. However, our understanding of co-translational processes in the maintenance of cellular signaling networks in the physiological environment lags compared to our understanding of genomic regulation. Applying a novel discovery approach that simultaneously examines the activity translating transcriptome and proteome within cells, we will investigate the co-translational and post- translational regulation of proteins expressed within angiogenesis signaling networks in the endothelial of the heart as they change with age and gender in vivo.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Many cancer patients experience numbness and (paradoxically) pain caused by chemotherapy; these neurologic problems can be debilitating and severely compromise quality of life for too many people. To find ways of preventing these complications, we investigate how chemotherapy causes these nerve problems. Our studies will analyze four new potential approaches for treatment that should prevent pain and improve the quality of life for cancer patients and survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Head and Neck Cancer is a public health concern in the United States and a major challenge in oncology. Hyperthermia combined with other treatments, such as radiation, chemotherapy, and immunotherapy, has been shown in clinical trials to increase response for head and neck cancer. The proposed project will develop methods for precise and practical hyperthermia delivery to head and neck cancer under magnetic resonance imaging control and tissue assessment to increase response rate and survival for patients with superficial and deep tumors in the head and neck, such as squamous cell carcinoma, melanoma, and soft tissue sarcoma of the head and neck region.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Melioidosis, caused by the bacterial pathogen Burkholderia pseudomallei, is a major cause of morbidity and septic death in tropical/subtropical regions worldwide and has recently become endemic in the United States. It is particularly virulent in diabetic patients and is also considered a Tier 1 select agent due to its potential use as a bioweapon. We are developing as a therapeutic a recombinant protein that interferes with the bacterium’s natural ability to evade being killed by complement.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The current application will make important advances in understanding the nature of early markers of risk for psychotic disorders such as schizophrenia, otherwise known as psychotic-like experiences. Specifically, we do not yet understand why some individuals go on to develop more severe forms of psychotic-like experiences (i.e., sustained distressing psychotic-like experiences) and why for some individuals these experiences are transient. The current application will make significant strides in understanding the most important factors (such as family history and cognition) distinguishing sustained from transient distressing psychotic-like experiences, as well as understanding the clinical importance of these symptoms (including how many individuals with sustained distressing psychotic-like experiences seek treatment or have problems in school or at homes as a result of these symptoms).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Autophagy is crucial for the maintenance of neuron homeostasis and is often disrupted in Alzheimer’s disease. However, precisely what the impact of impaired autophagy is on the progression of AD remains unclear. My proposed research will examine how autophagy in neurons and microglia can mitigate neuroinflammation and plaque formation, and will provide a foundation for me to establish an independent research group investigating autophagy in AD progression.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Many babies are exposed before birth to opioid drugs taken by their mother during pregnancy. These infants often develop neonatal opioid withdrawal syndrome and are at higher risk of sudden infant death syndrome. In this project, we will use information on heart rate, breathing rate, and blood oxygen levels from soon after birth to predict which infants are at higher risk of developing neonatal opioid withdrawal syndrome, determine the severity of withdrawal and the response to treatment, and find abnormal breathing patterns that may increase the risk of sudden infant death.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The incidence of myopia, or near-sightedness, is increasing at an alarming rate, with significant public health implications due to myopia being a risk factor for multiple sight-threatening conditions. In this proposal we use a mouse model of myopia, together with novel techniques for measuring changes in tissue properties, to understand how critical ocular tissues (retina, choroid and sclera) communicate with one another to trigger the excess axial growth of the eye that causes myopia. The data we will generate, when combined with a novel modeling platform that we will also create, will lay the foundation for intervening in the development of myopia by modulating the effects of a key signaling molecule, all-trans retinoic acid, in the sclera.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The assembly and egress of coronaviruses is controlled by peptide motifs that are found on the cytoplasmic extensions of virion membrane proteins. These peptide motifs interact with host machineries directing intracellular protein and vesicle transport. Here we will construct recombinant coronaviruses and virus‐like particles containing alternative peptide motifs, with comparative analyses aimed at discerning the mechanisms by which coronaviruses incorporate membrane proteins and then transport out of infected cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Project Narrative One major reason for the current obesity epidemic and its associated lack of effective treatment is due to incomplete understanding of neuronal control of complex feeding behavior. Using a combination of fiber photometry and mouse genetic approaches, the current proposal will determine whether paraventricular hypothalamic corticortropin-releasing hormone (CRH) neuron responsiveness functions as a neural basis underlying diet-induced obesity and time-restricted feeding or clock-enhancement inducing obesity prevention. The results will identify a previously unknown neural basis that dictates metabolic outcomes in response to diet changes and therefore form a foundation for effective treatments against obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Eating and drinking are controlled by neural mechanisms in the brain that remain poorly understood. A better understanding of the structure and regulation of the underlying neural circuits would advance our ability to develop new therapeutic approaches for the treatment of medical conditions such as obesity and eating disorders. This proposal utilizes state-of-the-art approaches to selectively manipulate and record the activity of key neurons in the mammalian brain that influence eating and drinking.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Parkinson’s disease, the second most common cause of age-related neurodegeneration in the U.S., in part reflects abnormal mitochondrial function in midbrain neurons, which produces cell death. Current therapies relieve the hallmark symptoms of abnormal movements, but they do not prevent neurodegeneration, disease progression, dementia, or death. This proposal will explore the novel hypotheses that there is a previously unrecognized link between hormones secreted by the intestine and midbrain neurons that protects their mitochondria against toxic injury, and that those hormones can be used as drugs to prevent and treat Parkinson’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lipoprotein(a) [Lp(a)] is a lipid-carrying particle that is causally associated with elevated cardiovascular disease risk when at elevated levels, which occurs in roughly 30% of the population. However, there are limited therapeutic options available for people with high Lp(a), especially for primary prevention. The proposed studies would help to address this unmet need by potentially providing an option for therapy with aspirin for primary prevention of cardiovascular events in a very large group of people with elevated cardiovascular risk.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This project aims to establish a new method for creating vaccine candidates. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: We propose to study lung cancer in Uganda and Tanzania and the relationship to HIV-1 infection through three project-based and three cores. The results of these studies of the epidemiology, molecular characterization and imaging of lung cancer and the relationship to HIV infection will lead to technological transfer of instrumentation to characterize lung cancer and artificial intelligence algorithms to aid in discerning pulmonary granulomatous disease from lung cancer on radiological imaging. Findings herein may lead to the development of country-specific guidelines in the evaluation and management of lung cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: RELEVANCE - Developmental Core Lung cancer is a major national and international health problem resulting in more cancer deaths than any other cancer. The rates are increasing in the low to middle income countries where the epidemiology, outside the effect of tobacco, is not well understood. HIV-positive patients are increased risk of developing lung cancer. By providing developmental and pilot funds to highly qualified investigators early in their career we can make develop novel ideas and grow the next generation of physician scientists tackling these issues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Computational modeling is an enabling technology for scientific discovery and clinical care but the potential of simulations in knee biomechanics is hampered by the diversity and ambiguity of modelers’ preferences. Consensus-based workflows, which are established and evaluated for intended uses of knee models, are sorely needed to elevate knee modeling and simulation as an efficient, reliable, and scalable practice. With these, modelers will be empowered to confidently conduct large scale virtual cohort studies and routine individualized simulations that are unified across research institutions and healthcare settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: RELEVANCE – Project 2 The molecular risks of lung cancer mutation and co-incidence of HIV and accelerated aging as a factor in lung cancer incidence and progression in two East African countries will be assessed. We will characterize lung cancer somatic mutations, link them to HIV subtype/viral load/CD4 T cell counts, and explore the hypothesized role of DNA methylome aging in HIV-infected versus HIV-uninfected individuals. We will also train and transfer technological equipment to build capacity for lung cancer mutational analysis and DNA methylome aging for lung cancer and HIV in Uganda and Tanzania.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: RELEVANCE – Project 3 In this project, we will develop a radiomics based machine classifier called LunIRiS (Lung Image Risk Score) for predicting risk of malignancy for a nodule on a chest computed tomography (CT) or X-ray scan for use in patients in Uganda and Tanzania which has a higher prevalence of tuberculosis (TB) and hence TB- induced granulomas. Additionally, we will seek to employ these tools to identify possibly differences in the radiographic phenotype on CT and chest X-rays between HIV+ and HIV- lung cancer patients and to employ these differences to develop HIV status specific lung cancer screening models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Once the regulatory and signaling logic of the cell is irreversibly dysregulated by mutations, cells are no longer constrained to well-defined physiologic states but rather transition to a novel dysregulated and highly plastic landscape, where de-differentiation and trans-differentiation events become common and novel synergies with other non-transformed cell populations are forged, leading to the emergence of bona fide neomorphic organs. We propose that identifying vulnerabilities that are more universal and less likely to be defeated by the cancer cell’s remarkable adaptive nature will require a quantum leap in our ability to dissect and interrogate intra- and inter-cellular network models that are predictive of the dynamic behavior of cancer as a bona fide neomorphic organ. For this purpose, we will leverage breakthrough technology allowing silencing of thousands of genes in millions of individual cells, followed by RNA-seq profiling, thus creating the first generation of genome- and proteome-wide network models that can effectively predict the probabilistic, time-dependent response of mammalian cells to small molecule and genetic perturbations, as well as their ability to plastically reprogram across the relatively small number of molecularly distinct states detected in virtually all human malignancies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Dysregulation of lipid metabolism is strongly associated with age-dependent retinal diseases based on genetic and epidemiological studies. Using mouse models showing impairment of lipid metabolism and cellular homeostasis in the retina, we propose to study how dysregulated lipid metabolism impacts retinal health and lead to age-dependent retinal diseases. This study may provide insights into how age-dependent retinal pathologies are caused and offer therapeutic strategies for prevention of retinal conditions associated with aging and age-dependent retinal disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The creation of the Cancer Immune Monitoring and Analysis Center (CIMAC) program as part of the Cancer Moonshot Research Initiative established an unprecedented multi-institute network that delivers a more standardized analysis of biospecimens from immunotherapy clinical trials. The goal of this application is to not let this valuable resource go to waste but rather to continue the work by applying proven assays to a greater number of trials and by expanding the scope and sophistication of analysis with more comprehensive methods coupled with enhanced bioinformatic tools for facile data processing and improved biomarker identification. Our network will continue its mission to support, harmonize, compare, and disseminate existing and new approaches aimed at learning the mechanisms underlying responses to immune-based therapies for the treatment of cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it is aimed at addressing low utilization of mental health services that leads to delayed diagnosis and treatment, and increased morbidity and mortality related to mental illness among Black adults. The proposed research is relevant to the mission of the NIMH to enhance the efficacy and precision of interventions, as it is proposed to design and test the feasibility of an anti-stigma intervention that better defines the optimal intervention conditions and mechanistic targets (stigma and medical mistrust) to promote uptake of mental health services. Thus, the findings are expected to enhance mental health treatment outcomes among millions of Black adults with mental illness in the United States.

ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Soluble adenylyl cyclase (sAC) is essential for sperm function, and both men and male mice with the sAC gene deleted are sterile with no other immediate phenotypes. Mice given a single dose of an acute acting sAC inhibitor are temporarily infertile with no other observable side effects. Our goal is to develop sAC inhibitors into safe, `on-demand' male birth control pills whose effects would be temporary and taken only when, and as often as needed.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: Borrelia burgdorferi (Bb), the causative agent of Lyme disease, is the most prevalent arthropod-borne infectious agent in the US and causes significant morbidity and extensive health care costs in endemic areas where the disease is prevalent. The proposed studies are directed at evaluating genetically defined mutants that hyper-express a number of lipoproteins as reservoir bait vaccines to limit or eliminate the survival of Bb in experimental and reservoir mouse models. Several adjuvants will be evaluated for stimulating protective immune response against Lyme disease pathogen as a single dose, oral, reservoir-targeted vaccine to interrupt natural history of infection leading to a reduction in the incidence of Lyme disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Both adversity and psychopathology experienced in early childhood are profound, yet nonspecific, risk factors for adolescent mental health problems. Identifying neural pathways through which early adversity and psychopathology lead to this risk may improve our prediction models, directly addressing prevention and intervention science. The current study, building on a large and well-characterized existing cohort, is efficiently designed to test specific neural pathways linking adversity and psychopathology in preschool to adolescent psychopathology individually and interactively.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Aging is characterized by a gradual decline in function across multiple organ systems and this decline sensitizes these systems to disease. As a consequence, chronological age is a well-known risk factor for many human diseases including cancer, osteoporosis, cardiovascular disease, dementia, type 2 diabetes, glaucoma and others. The research proposed will contribute new therapies to promote brain health across age, and help postpone the cognitive and mental health deterioration that occurs with age.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: NARRATIVE The goal of this grant is to dissect the contribution of fibroblast derived WNT ligands to activation of WNT signaling in T cells and to the shaping of the tumor microenvironment. We will then study the role of the WNT effector TCF1 in pancreatic cancer infiltrating T cells. Finally, we will harness our findings to design and test a novel combination targeting approach for this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Twenty percent of patients hospitalized for acute exacerbations of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) are readmitted within 30 days of discharge. Pulmonary rehabilitation is associated with a reduction in hospitalization in patients with COPD, but significant barriers in availability and access limit its use. We propose a multicenter randomized controlled trial that will test whether a video telehealth pulmonary rehabilitation intervention that overcomes these barriers will reduce hospital readmissions, improve quality of life, and be cost-effective.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project proposes a systematic, large-scale observational study comparing the effectiveness and safety of the second antihypertensive drugs added to monotherapy in people with hypertension in real-world settings. The proposed project is relevant to public health because it provides critical information to inform decisions about randomized trials for hypertension treatment escalation and the highest quality non-randomized evidence to support guideline recommendations. The proposed research is relevant to National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute’s Strategic Goals and Objectives, specifically objective 6, to optimize clinical and implementation research to improve health and reduce disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The rapid formation of new memories and the recall of old memories to inform decisions is essential for human cognition, but the underlying neural mechanisms remain poorly understood. The objective of this application is to assemble a multi-disciplinary and multi-site team with the expertise and patient volume to test key predictions on the neural substrate of human memory that can only be evaluated by observing and studying neurons in-vivo in humans enabled by rare neurosurgical opportunities. This innovative approach permits us to investigate circuit-level mechanisms of human memory that cannot be studied non-invasively in humans nor in animal models due to their unclear relevance to human memory and its diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Weakness is an important contributor to age-related physical impairments. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will advance the understanding of the causes of age-related weakness. As such, this application is highly relevant to NIH’s mission of extending healthy living and reducing the burdens of physical disability in old age.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Metastatic breast cancer and relapse following therapy are dependent on (1) development of intrinsic resistance to targeted and endocrine therapies, and (2) resistance to recognition and destruction of cancer cells by the immune system. The Stanford Breast Metastasis Center (SBMC) is focused on (1) quantifying the timing of metastatic dissemination in breast cancer (2) functionally delineating the contribution of cellular and microenvironmental crosstalk on metastatic proclivity, and (3) characterizing the mechanisms of responses by metastatic cells to therapies. To achieve these goals, we harness an integrated systems biology, functional genomic and evolutionary dynamic approach applied to longitudinal breast cancer tissue cohorts and patient- derived organoid models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Health equity is a public health priority and key outcome of the federal initiative to end the HIV epidemic. However, public health professionals lack tools to assess the ability of a given program to produce equitable outcomes. This research will not only address this gap but also make a significant contribution to the public health and health equity landscape through the development of the Health Equitability Assessment and Readiness Tool (HEART). The HEART will be a valid and practical tool used to assess the equitability of public health programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: GABAergic dysfunction is strongly associated with autism, schizophrenia and childhood epilepsy. Increasing experimental evidence points towards imbalances between the excitatory and inhibitory circuits in the brain as a prominent component in the etiology of these illnesses. This project is aimed at further our understanding on how electrical activity affects early brain maturation during critical periods of development with an emphasis on cortico-cortical pathways.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In response to an inadequate and declining number of scientists with expertise in clinical research methods, coupled with an increasing recognition of the importance of rigorous epidemiological research, we created an undergraduate research opportunity, the Undergraduate Clinical Scholars Program (UCSP); the program is closely linked with the University of Pennsylvania's world-renowned Center for Clinical Epidemiology and Biostatics, the interdisciplinary home of epidemiology and biostatistics research at Penn. Students receive career mentoring, a comprehensive core curriculum spanning the methods of clinical epidemiology and biostatistics; and participate in structured and mentored research projects the output of which will be abstracts,publications, presentations and applications for next-stage fellowships. Our first five years have shown that early exposure to this rich environment encourages these talented young students to pursue careers in clinicalinvestigation, in line with the NIDDK's missions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative  Down syndrome (DS) is one of the most common genetic conditions in the United States with a prevalence rate estimated at 6.7 people with DS per 10,000 of the population in 2010 and is characterized by global developmental delays, intellectual disability, and obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), which can have negative effects on daily life for children with DS. Hypoglossal nerve stimulation (HGS) is a novel therapy for OSA in adults as well as children with preliminary data suggesting improved cognition and language in this population. Therefore, this proposal is a formal clinical trial to focus upon the effects on neurocognition and expressive language before and after hypoglossal nerve stimulation treatment of OSA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE HIV and cervical cancer severely impact racial and ethnic minorities in Georgia, particularly Black women living with HIV (WLWH). The Georgia Consortium to Eliminate Cervical Cancer in Women Living with HIV maximizes the collaborative strengths of Emory’s high-impact HIV research and clinical network and Morehouse School of Medicine’s strong community and clinical partnerships by engaging a diverse array of community members who serve WLWH. This unique setting of multidisciplinary partners will provide the ‘CASCADE’ Network with valuable information on the clinical effectiveness and scalability of interventions aimed at improving cervical cancer prevention in WLWH.

PHR: NARRATIVE The T32 Colorado Training Program is designed to provide our Trainees with a comprehensive, integrative, and formal career development experience with the goal of positioning them to become the next generation of leaders in Pulmonary and Critical Care Medicine. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Oxidative DNA damage at telomeres induced by radiation or other stresses is a source of genomic instability, which fuels both aging and tumorigenesis. We have discovered a new DNA repair pathway that protects cells against telomeric oxidative damage and found it remarkably similar to the alternative lengthening of telomere (ALT) pathway used by cancer cells to maintain telomeres. We will molecularly delineate this repair pathway, understand its relationship to ALT, and develop strategies to selectively kill cancer cells reliant on these pathways, bringing a new front to the interface of aging and cancer research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The precursor phase of multiple myeloma (MM), smoldering MM, is increased in African Americans (AA) leading to an increased incidence of active MM requiring therapy, therefore, understanding early molecular events is critical to establish why this racial disparity occurs. Chronic inflammation is linked with MM in European Americans and our preliminary data has identified an immune mutational signature, active in early pre-clinical disease phases that is increased in AA, and could explain the AA excess risk. By extracting these early mutational signatures from whole genome sequencing data of bone marrow samples along with assessments of the immune microenvironment and the gut microbiome we aim to establish a link that could be manipulated to minimize racial disparities in this devastating cancer. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the on-going serious obesity epidemic, genetic factors, gene-environment and gene-sex interactions as well as biological mechanisms driving obesity-related health-to-disease transitions towards manifestation of obesity-induced cardiometabolic disorders (CMDs) have remained largely elusive, leaving a significant number of individuals without proper prevention and care. To address these pressing medical knowledge gaps, we propose to 1) elucidate epigenetic and transcriptional markers for health-to-cardiometabolic disease transitions in males and females; and 2) discover gene-environment and gene-sex interactions for health-to-CMD transitions using a new function-to-variants omics approach and its follow-up in extensive biobanks. Overall, our health-to- CMD approach has a great potential to help prevent CMDs and delay their onset.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As genomic sequence data are being produced faster and at lower cost, the most significant challenge in clinical genetic testing today is accurate variant classification and communication of that information to patients which is being adversely affected by variants of unknown significance (VUS), which comprise of a substantial percentage of all genetic variants in clinical oncology. VUS along with other confirmed variants are being reclassified with increasing availability of more ethnically diverse reference data, yet there is a lack of understanding on how practicing clinicians, and patients are impacted by and manage these variants. To provide empirical data to fill this critical knowledge gap and potentially inform patient care, I will conduct a national survey of oncology providers about how their variant reclassification related practices, develop a tool for measuring patient reported uncertainty in genomics, and evaluate the clinical utility of VUS reclassification among cancer patients and at-risk individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: NARRATIVE Systemic Sclerosis (SSc) is an inflammatory-driven multi-system fibrotic disease impacting morbidity, mortality, and quality of life. We have identified Hippo-signaling as a critical circuit in SSc pro-fibrotic processes in promoting endothelial-mesenchymal (Endo-MT) and fibroblast-to-myofibroblast transition. Here, we will mechanistically dissect the role of the Hippo pathway in SSc and the contribution of LAMP3+ Dendritic Cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE It is becoming increasingly evident that changes in how molecules, cells and tissues respond to forces are linked to many diseases, such as cancer, cardiovascular diseases, muscular dystrophies, asthma, fibrosis, osteoarthritis and connective tissue disorders. Mechanobiology focusses on understanding these changes and at developing mechanodiagnostic and mechanotherapeutic approaches while mechanochemistry is dedicated to engineering mechanoresponsive materials for tissue regeneration. The 2024 Multiscale Mechanochemistry and Mechanobiology Gordon Research Conference and Seminar will serve as a platform for interdisciplinary scientific discourse, uniting experts and trainees in the aforementioned domains to drive the translation of fundamental insights into biomedical applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Achondroplasia, the most common form of short stature in humans, is due to variants in FGFR3 that over- activate the fibroblast growth factor receptor 3 and thereby severely impair the specific activities of cartilage growth plate cells. This project is designed to increase current knowledge of the mechanisms controlling FGFR3 expression in these cells and affecting them downstream of FGFR3 in achondroplasia. The ultimate goal is to propose novel strategies, whereby the targeting of these mechanisms would provide direly needed, safe and effective treatments for people with achondroplasia and related conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE Changes in the curvature of cell membranes are important for the morphology and motility of cells. These functions are disrupted in many diseases including developmental disorders and cancer. Here we will establish an in vivo model to test the physiological significance of the structural domains of a peripheral membrane protein of the BAR family that changes membrane curvature. Furthermore, we will use protein structure methods to solve its structure. Data originated here will advance our understanding of how cells regulate morphology and motility in health and disease.

PHR: Project Narrative The 14th Gordon Research Conference on Environmental Endocrine Disruptors will bring together basic and translational scientists, clinicians, and public health advocates across scientific disciplines to increase collaboration and discussions to foster cross-fertilization in the field. The theme of this conference, the impact of environmental endocrine disruptors on planetary health and planetary boundaries, will allow researchers to present cutting-edge results, illustrating the depth and breadth of the field, in a way that is accessible across disciplines. The primary objective of this conference is to remain the preeminent place for researchers at every career stage to learn about the latest advancements and exchange scientific ideas relevant to the endocrine disruptors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Current surgical options for intractable epilepsy result in continued seizures in 30-60% of cases. New research, including our own, suggests that quantitative analysis of the interictal EEG — time periods between seizures — can localize seizure generators and may help improve surgical planning. The goals of this study are to determine the spatiotemporal characteristics of two alternate quantitative methods of analyzing interictal EEG, to test whether these methods accurately localize seizure generators, and to determine if probing the interictal EEG with electrical stimulation improves localization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The 2024 Gordon Research Conference (GRC) and Gordon Research Seminar (GRS) on Microbial Toxins and Pathogenicity are the premiere events that showcase exciting, innovative basic and applied research in the field of infectious disease. The GRC and GRS promote open discussions and active networking between new and veteran researchers from academia and government, medicine and biotech. In addition to providing an exceptional forum for a diverse community of scientists to learn and discuss the latest discoveries in the field, the GRC and GRS provide exceptional opportunities for the professional development of the next generation of researchers and promotes their success within the broader scientific community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE With the newly generated multi-tissue DNA methylation data from the Genotype-Tissue Expression (GTEx) project, we propose to develop methods for integrating multi-tissue methylation QTLs (mQTLs) with multi-tissue eQTLs to improve the mapping of QTLs with co-occurring effects; and we extend the method to multi-cell-type single-cell QTL mapping with the integration of bk-QTL statistics, and trans-ethnic disease-relevant supervised QTL mapping. Moreover, motivated by the shared genetic regulation of cis-expression and methylation levels, we propose a multivariable Mendelian randomization framework for analyzing multi-tissue expression and methylation as joint risk exposures for complex diseases. We will develop scalable software for the proposed methods, will analyze GTEx, sc-eQTLGen data and multiple GWASs to map QTLs and identify risk genes, and will use additional e/mQTL and sc-eQTL data to replication and validate our results.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Cerebral amyloid angiopathy (CAA), a common finding in over 90% of Alzheimer's disease (AD) cases, is characterized by the deposition of amyloid in the cerebrovascular compartment. This overlap between AD and vascular brain pathology in dementia has been difficult to separate, with AD and vascular dementia probably existing as a continuum of distinct but mechanistically related processes. The studies outlined in this proposal will allow us to dissect in detail the mechanisms by which CAA leads to cognitive decline and may identify novel therapeutic targets for CAA and AD.

ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it transforms free-text clinical evidence in the literature into a computable format that can better support evidence extraction and summarization. It applies natural language processing to unstructured biomedical literature to support evidence-based clinical research and to enhance the health of the public. The proposed research is also relevant to the part of the NLM's strategic plan that focuses on (1) development and demonstration of innovative informatics methods and data science techniques for informing public health, (2) advanced information retrieval and knowledge discovery from very large and/or heterogeneous data sets

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Piezo2 is a non-selective Ca2+ permeable mechanically activated ion channel, that is indispensable for gentle touch and it is involved in injury-induced mechanical pain. We identify a novel lipid regulator of this channel, that inhibits Piezo2, but not Piezo1 activity. Our data will provide insight not how these channels are regulated, and may help identifying selective pharmacological inhibitors of Piezo2 in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD) and steatohepatitis (MASH) (previously known as NAFLD and NASH) are the most common liver diseases and often associated with diabetes and obesity. However, mechanisms underlying these diseases and thus, treatments directly targeting the mechanistic drivers are lacking. As such, this application proposes to study a promising novel small molecule antidiabetic drug candidate and its distinct underlying cellular and molecular mechanisms as a potential novel approach and future therapeutic against these metabolic liver diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Congenital CMV (cCMV) infection affects 1 in 200 liveborn infants in the United States and can cause permanent neurodevelopmental impairments and sensorineural hearing loss, but robust outcome predictors are lacking. Infants have poor antiviral T cell responses to in-utero CMV infection, but instead generate cytotoxic NK cells expressing adaptive-like features that are phenotypically distinct from adult NK cell responses to CMV infection. This project will investigate the immunophenotype and cytotoxic activity of cCMV-induced NK cells using advanced CITE-seq and spectral flow cytometry methods, determine the impact of antiviral treatment upon these NK cells, and investigate the potential relationship between NK cell immunophenotypes and neurodevelopmental outcomes among a large cohort of cCMV infected infants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Naturally-derived nanoparticles, or extracellular vesicles (EVs), have shown potential in healing damaged heart tissue. Yet, delivering these EVs to the injured heart effectively faces challenges: rapid dispersion, limited retention, and invasive injection. Our proposed approach aims to enhance EV accumulation and retention in the heart, offering non-invasive treatment possibilities for heart attack recovery without surgery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE To understand the brain in health and disease, identifying functional connections between neurons is essential. Optogenetics (to turn on neurons) and voltage biosensors (to read-out brain activity) are powerful tools for achieving this, but the current spectral compatibility between blue-absorbing voltage sensors and optogenetic reagents poses a limitation. This project proposes developing red voltage biosensors that operate on a different part of the spectrum, thereby overcoming this challenge and allowing experiments that provide new insights into how the brain works.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Oxidative stress, inflammation, and mitochondrial dysfunction contribute to endothelial dysfunction and atherosclerosis, which is a major cause of morbidity and mortality, predominantly occurring in arterial regions exposed to disturbed blood flow. Recently, excess copper (Cu) in mitochondria is shown to induce a new type of programmed cell death. We will demonstrate that endothelial Cu transporter, as a flow sensor, plays an important role in Cu levels, inflammation, mitochondrial dysfunction and programmed cell death in atherosclerotic lesions and potential therapeutic target for the treatment of vascular inflammatory disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Aging is inexorably linked to the degeneration of tissues and cells, a process we believe is partially driven by the loss of normal DNA organization within cells. Leveraging state-of-the-art techniques, we are rigorously examining the intricate packaging of DNA within individual cells, with the goal of understanding the consequent implications of changes in this DNA organization on aging and associated disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Skeletal muscle plays a critical role in glycemic control and metabolic homeostasis and is the predominant site of glucose disposal under insulin-stimulated conditions. Therefore, skeletal muscle function is a very important fundamental phenomenon in human health and disease. This project will use physiological and molecular approaches to identify new molecular pathways playing a role in muscle performance and metabolism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE The novel mechanism of action of a class of complex molecules, cyclodextrins, was uncovered against a cytotoxic sphingolipid, galactosylsphingosine, or psychosine, which, at non-physiological higher levels, causes a devastating leukodystrophy. The characterization of a specific cyclodextrin and the synthesis of its new analogs to neutralize the cytotoxic effects of psychosine will lead to a potential therapy for an inborn lysosomal disorder caused by galactocerebrosidase deficiency, mostly known as Krabbe disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative: Mutations in taperin protein complex have been liked to hearing loss in humans, a major health problem that significantly affects the life quality of those affected. We anticipate illustrating the physiological functions of taperin protein complex and the pathophysiological changes in hair cells that result from their mutations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Aged-and-obese Americans have a risk of developing type 2 diabetes of nearly 50% making them vulnerable to both direct negative consequences on lifespan and healthspan, as well as increasing risk for numerous age- related diseases including cardiovascular disease, cancer, and Alzheimer’s disease. New interventions to treat and prevent obesity and diabetes are thus urgently needed. This project seeks to determine if a diet low in specific dietary amino acids can reverse diet-induced obesity in a non-human primate and to understand the molecular mechanisms behind such actions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Recent work by our group established that ivosidenib is a potent wild-type IDH1 inhibitor with strong anti- pancreatic cancer effects under tumor-associated conditions, like low magnesium and glucose. In this proposal, we seek to optimize this treatment even further by nominating therapeutic partners that induce free radicals or shift metabolism towards oxidative phosphorylation, like a ketogenic diet or PARP inhibition. Further, we analyze patient samples to show that allosteric IDH1 inhibitors are indeed active against the wild-type enzyme, paving the way for future translational studies testing these combinatorial approaches in patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Indirect traumatic optic neuropathy (ITON) patients experience immediate optic nerve damage from the traumatic event followed by secondary neurodegeneration weeks later. We propose that the duration of the “latent” period prior to secondary neurodegeneration is determined by the ratio of healthy to dysfunctional mitochondria. We will test this in our mouse ITON model, quantifying mitochondria and mitochondrial quality control processes and testing the efficacy of mitochondria transplantation while all quantifying optic nerve structure and function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: 2024 Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory Conference  GLIA IN HEALTH & DISEASE  PROJECT NARRATIVE The intricate functioning of the nervous system relies not only on the activity of neurons but also on the crucial contributions of glial cells. The “Glia in Health and Disease” conference, hosted biennially since 2006, remains the preeminent glial meeting. This meeting unites a diverse assembly of researchers investigating basic, fundamental biological mechanisms by which glia contribute to brain circuit development and function to translational neuroscientists who identify new glia-based targets for therapeutic intervention. Above all, the conference strategically engages leaders, seasoned investigators, and early-career scientists to interact and collectively share their latest discoveries on the intricate roles of glial cells in the nervous system.

PHR: Project Narrative This grant is written to request funding to support the 18th International Congress on Combustion By-Products and their Health Effects, also known as "PIC", to be held May 20- 22nd, 2024 in Durham, NC. This enduring and small conference provides a unique platform to share the latest science and exchange ideas across and among a diverse group of researchers from various fields, including academia, industry, and government officials. The goal of the Congress is to foster interactions and collaborations in a more narrowly focused research field compared to other large discipline-specific scientific conferences that have a larger breadth and parallel session formats.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative MEG, EEG, and invasive electrophysiological recordings can be used to understand and diagnose abnormalities underlying a wide range neurological and psychiatric illnesses including epilepsy, schizophrenia, obsessive-compulsive disorder, autism spectrum disorders, and Alzheimer’s disease, as well as cognitive deficits such as delayed acquisition of language. However, widespread use of these methods especially in large populations has been problematic because of the lack of well-established analysis approaches, which map the sensor data into the brain space for detailed temporal, spatial, and connectivity analysis. This research will provide well-documented and tested novel analysis software to promote both basic neuroscience and clinical research applications of human electrophysiological recordings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  Eating disorders are an impairing and deadly psychiatric disorder with high rates of relapse. There is a need to improve our understanding of relapse to inform the design of more efficacious treatments and relapse prevention efforts; however, current research is limited by examining relapse as an outcome longitudinally (i.e., across 1 year) rather than a process that unfold through moment-to-moment choices engagement in ED behavior (i.e., lapses). The current study – informed by existing theory of relapse borrowed from substance use disorders15 – will capture the process at the momentary level, with the ultimate goal of identifying mechanisms of relapse that can be addressed through existing and new treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Non-coding repetitive DNA sequences at the ends of eukaryotic chromosomes are called telomeres, and in many cancers they’re lengthened by the enzyme telomerase to achieve immortality. These telomeres are normally composed of deoxynucleotides, but they can also contain ribonucleotides, which are the most prevalent form of DNA damage. The overarching goal of this proposal is to understand the prevalence of telomeric ribonucleotides, how they are repaired, and how ribonucleotides alter telomeric integrity to promote chromosomal instability.

PHR: Project Narrative The goal of the 2024 FASEB SRC on Biological Methylation is three-fold: (1) To bring together members with diverse expertise to bridge and foster collaborations and translational research in the fields of cancer, neurology, developmental biology, and small molecule inhibitors; (2) To provide an opportunity for scientists studying diverse aspects of the biochemistry, structure/function and disease relevance of SAM-dependent methylation to discuss recent research developments and to initiate collaborations; (3) To provide a supportive mentoring platform for trainees and junior investigators from diverse backgrounds, giving them opportunity to engage with those more established in their field.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Adeno-associated viral (AAV) vectors are mainstream delivery platforms in gene therapy, yet AAV- mediated gene transfer to adipose tissue is left far behind due to the low transduction efficiency and tropism of natural AAV serotypes. Our preliminary studies have found a newly engineered capsid LC.V7 to possess exclusive adipose-tropism while eliminating transduction of liver and other peripheral tissues. This project aims to develop the next generation of AAV vector platform for adipose gene delivery based on the novel LC.V7 capsid, which will provide a powerful tool for basic research and therapeutic purposes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative – Symposium on the Immune System of Bacteria Defining at the mechanistic level how cells resist viral infection is essential to controlling and treating infectious diseases. The proposed 2024 Symposium on the Immune System of Bacteria will convene US and international scientists in the emerging field of bacterial anti-phage defense and the evolutionary connection between the immune system of bacteria and human antiviral immunity. The conference will establish priority directions for future research and create a unique opportunity to foster inclusivity and the next generation of researchers studying microbiology, virology, and immunology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: 22q11.2 deletion (22qDel) is a high-risk schizophrenia-associated microdeletion. Several nuclear-encoded mitochondrial proteins are located within the 22q11.2 locus prompting the hypothesis that neuronal mitochondria may be particularly vulnerable to heterozygosity of 22q11.2 genes. This project will determine the impact of the 22q11.2 deletion on mitochondrial biology and neuronal development and may provide novel insights into its shared biology with schizophrenia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is a widespread virus that causes mild illness in healthy individuals but can cause serious disease in newborns, seniors and the immunocompromised. Multiple antibodies and vaccines to prevent CMV infection have failed in the clinic, which we hypothesize is at least partly due to the virus’ ability to capture and destroy anti-CMV antibodies. This project will evaluate strategies to disarm this viral defense strategy and thereby restore antibody activities against CMV that are expected to contribute to future effective treatments.
