IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Numerous studies support the premise that inflammation rises in aging. Drugs with immunomodulatory actions such as mechanistic Target of Rapamycin (mTOR) inhibitors may promote healthspan, the length of one’s life spent in good health, especially if given prior to onset of age-related declines. We will analyze deidentified samples from an NIA-funded clinical trial to test the possibility that the mTORC inhibitor everolimus is a safe and effective option to ameliorate age-related inflammation and sequelae thereof.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: LOUISIANA STATE UNIV A&M COL BATON ROUGE
PHR: Project Narrative  CAR-T cell therapy has been proven effective in treating hematological malignancy and autoimmunity caused by B cell abnormality, but the cytotoxic and short-lived nature of CAR-T cells have become a major hurdle to this therapeutic strategy. We aim at improving longevity while reducing the cytotoxicity of CAR-T cells, by deletion or inhibition of the TCR signaling mediator ITK, which is a negative regulator of T cell survival and long- term memory functions. A better understanding of the role of ITK in CAR-T cell development and function, and new approaches to targeting ITK in CAR-T cells, will improve CAR-T cell production, therapeutic sustainability, and help expanding the therapeutic options for patients with cancer and/or autoimmune disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: We have found that estrogen therapy can protect against the development of kidney injury in animal models, and we plan to determine the mechanisms responsible for this protection and to test whether clinically approved selective estrogen receptor modulators (SERMs) can also be effective. We will also use insights from these murine studies to inform investigation in a separate study of women undergoing renal transplantation and receiving peri- operative estrogen therapy. These studies may have significance for the management of patients at risk of kidney injury due to a sudden decrease in blood supply or those undergoing renal transplantation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Migrant agricultural workers and their families experience persistent negative health consequences from the SARS-CoV-2 pandemic due to disparities in access to effective testing and treatment and pre-existing social and economic inequities; in response we have engaged rural migrant families in Nebraska to improve access to COVID-19 testing, healthcare, and community response resources through the Mobile Health for Migrant Health (mHealth-4-Mhealth) program. In the proposed study we will evaluate the impact, moderators, and cost- effectiveness of implementing mHealth-4-Mhealth program elements on migrant families’ access to and utilization of COVID-19 testing, treatment, and related healthcare resources. Given the portability and adaptability of mHealth tools to diverse communities, our findings can inform national-scale interventions to empower families to adapt to public health emergencies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this project is to capture dynamics of neural circuit formation, chronicle its functional and structural elements, and determine which maturational events are dependent on spontaneous action potential activity. Functional elements include the complement of ion channel expression and calcium signaling pathways to gene expression which underlie appropriate structural transformations that become the topographically correct neural circuit. These data, although focused on an important auditory brainstem neural circuit, provide a roadmap to understand severe developmental disorders that result from problems in early brain development, and to reorganize and possibly re-connect neurons in mature brains affected by injury or disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: We seek to understand the active processes that are responsible for normal hearing by building mathematical models simulating the behavior of the cochlea, the transducer of the hearing system. By understanding the cochlea well enough to model it, we hope to predict how the cochlea might fail, say in response to loud sound or age, and guide the development of protective approaches or enhanced prosthetics. In addition, a predictive mathematical model will enable the development of new noninvasive tests to better interrogate the health of one's hearing and may enable better speech recognition software or cochlear implant neural stimulation algorithms to be devised.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Accumulation and misfolding of tau drives impairment in the autophagy lysosomal pathway (ALP) in Alzheimer’s disease and other related dementias. This proposal will develop two cellular fluorescence-based technologies that will monitor the kinetics of tau-induced ALP dysfunction by tracking the nuclear transport and dimerization of TFEB, the master regulator of ALP. These technologies will provide a platform for future biological questions and therapeutic discovery campaigns targeting critical steps within TFEB’s signaling cascade.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because: 1) it will directly lead to an improved understanding of how antiretroviral therapy (AVT) causes drug-hormone interactions in fragile patient population groups, including pregnant people, developing fetuses, and neonates and 2) it will provide mechanistic physiologically based pharmacokinetic (PBPK) to understand, predict, and prevent deleterious DHIs in these same groups. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative We have shown that prior exposure to S. aureus leads to blunted humoral and cellular staphylococcal vaccine responses. Here we test the hypothesis that IL10 induced by prior S. aureus exposure underlies the non-protective T and B cell responses to S. aureus vaccines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: This proposal identifies GW8510 as a new and functionally improved analog of BX795, which inhibits ocular herpes infection. This small molecule can strongly inhibit as well as synergistically enhance the efficacy of clinical antivirals. We will use GW8510 to study proviral mechanisms in the cornea and improve our understanding of its safety and efficacy in murine eyes using lab and clinical strains of ocular HSV-1.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative: In the midst of an unprecedented and escalating crisis of drug-related maternal morbidity and mortality in the US, public health has yet to generate the essential evidence needed to develop interventions to help people who use drugs (PWUD) survive pregnancy and the postpartum year. The proposed longitudinal (2017-2022) study is thus designed to support a new arena of interventions to help PWUD survive these 21 months of pregnancy and the postpartum year by generating essential evidence about (1) which drug-related harms PWUD suffer while pregnant/postpartum; (2) when during these highly dynamic 21 months these harms occur; (3) who suffers these drug-related maternal harms, overall and within subpopulations defined by race/ethnicity, insurance status, and rurality; (4) where PWUD experiencing these harms cluster spatially; and (5) the features of the “risk environments” where pregnant/ postpartum PWUD live that may elevate vulnerability to these harms.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (RELEVANCE STATEMENT) Central to the etiology of disease processes leading to early pregnancy loss, preeclampsia, intrauterine growth restriction, placentae abruptio, and pre-term birth is abnormal development of the uterine-placental interface. Morphogenesis of the uterine-placental interface depends on differentiation and actions of the invasive/extravillous trophoblast cell lineage. Elucidation of mechanisms controlling invasive/extravillous trophoblast cell differentiation and its involvement in the development of the uterine-trophoblast cell interface will lead to the discovery of diagnostics for early detection of failures in the establishment of pregnancy and regulatory events that can be targeted for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: HEALTH RELEVANCE Chlamydia trachomatis is one of the most common causes of bacterial sexually transmitted infections and the leading cause of infectious blindness worldwide. Identifying how C. trachomatis promotes the fusion of its inclusions and characterizing the molecular regulation of the fusion machinery will provide invaluable insight into the mechanisms of disease progression. Furthermore, identifying the molecular machinery used by Chlamydia to promote membrane fusion will generate critical information for studying similar events with other intracellular human pathogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Relevance to public health: Candida albicans is a major human fungal pathogen responsible for both mucosal and systemic infections in a wide variety of immunocompromised individuals. This proposal seeks to determine how translational mechanisms control the ability of C. albicans to tolerate a variety of different host environmental stess conditions and undergo filamentous growth, promoting virulence and pathogenicity. Ultimately, this study will provide new information leading to the development of novel and more effective strategies for the treatment of candidiasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The inaugural Science of Community Outreach and Engagement (SoCOE) Conference is proposed by six NCI-designated Cancer Centers to provide a platform for Community Outreach and Engagement (COE) academic-clinical-policy-community stakeholders to share best practices and recommendations that will address inequities in cancer prevention, early detection, care and survivorship. The SoCOE is an annual conference, with the 1st conference proposed to be hosted by the Mayo Clinic Comprehensive Cancer Center and the Virginia Commonwealth University Massey Cancer Center from May 8 to 10, 2024, in Florida, United States.

PHR: Project Narrative With a team of collaborators, we propose to use state-of-the-art approaches to dissect the mechanisms underlying blood cell formation. Specifically, the proposed studies address a gap in our knowledge as to how red blood cells and platelets are formed in the bone marrow. The results of the proposed studies hold significant promise for the development of novel therapeutic treatments for blood diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Exposure to stress is one of the leading causes of mental illnesses like Major Depressive Disorder, Post- Traumatic Stress Disorder, and many anxiety disorders. Understanding the neurobiological and neuroendocrine mechanisms that link the stress response to long-term clinical outcomes is therefore a primary challenge for the field of neuroscience and psychiatry, and this meeting allows stress researchers to share their findings, network, and learn from each other with the ultimate goal of informing therapeutic development.

PHR: Project Narrative Atrial fibrillation (AF) leads to high health economic burden of >$15 billion for new onset AF and an annual cost of $6.65 billion for the care of these patients. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Bone marrow aspirates are critical to the diagnosis, staging, and monitoring of hematologic conditions and cancers (e.g., leukemia, aplastic anemia, sickle cell disease, and metastasis of solid tumors), but 8-50% of aspirations are unsuccessful due to operator technique, hemodilution, or underlying pathology. Cellia Science will enable improved quality and reliability of bone marrow aspiration procedures by developing an automated point-of-care instrument for assessment of sample adequacy. Successful implementation of this device is expected to increase the fraction of successful procedures, which will drastically improve the quality of care for the patient.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: In the AYA Access Study we will evaluate if a theoretically and stake-holder informed enhanced eHealth and chatbot enabled delivery model can increase uptake of genetic services and provide non-inferior patient reported outcomes as compared to the standard model for remote genetic services in AYA cancer patients in community cancer practices. We expect this research to significantly inform how best to increase adherence to genetic testing guidelines among AYA while maintaining adequate patient outcomes and improving the quality of cancer care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Type 2 diabetes is a costly and complex chronic illness and a serious public health problem, responsible for a host of complications that significantly decrease healthy lifespan. The underlying issue in diabetes is the failure of specific cells in the pancreas, termed β-cells, to release enough of the hormone, insulin, into the bloodstream to properly control blood sugar levels. The aims of this proposal are to characterize emerging cellular targets to promote β-cell cell health and proper insulin release, ultimately improving the care and treatment of individuals with type 2 diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The mechanisms underlying complex neurodevelopmental condition-relevant behaviors remain poorly understood. In this proposal, we will delineate neural circuit mechanisms that contribute to critical behaviors such as social behaviors; delineate potential benefits of neural circuit modulation to these behaviors; and provide a better mechanistic understanding of the networks, communication, and function of cerebellar-medial prefrontal circuits in the regulation of social behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Public Health Relevance: Spinal and bulbar muscular atrophy (SBMA) is one of 9 polyglutamine diseases that are part of a larger family of neurodegenerative diseases characterized by protein misfolding and accumulation; these diseases include Alzheimer’s disease, Huntington’s disease, Parkinson’s disease and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). We have begun to characterize the mutant AR interactome – both stable and transient interactors – in a cell model of SBMA and propose here to continue this identification in novel human cell models, to validate these identified proteins in vivo, and to further these studies by exploring the detailed mechanistic basis for one of these interactors, USP7, and for other interactors uncovered by these studies. Finally, with the additional study and understanding of the therapeutic potential of targeting the USP7-AR interaction in SBMA models, the sum of these studies represents a powerful approach to uncover the underlying mechanisms of disease in SBMA.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Responsive to the call for global team science and collaboration, the Global Perspectives on Developmental Science to Address Adolescent Resilience and Well-Being in the Face of Sociocultural and Ecological Challenge conference aims to integrate cutting-edge research regarding socio-cultural and ecological challenges confronting today’s adolescents and to guide policies, programs, and practices that best support resilience and well-being in youth around the world. To springboard the establishment of a sustainable community of global scholars, this conference provides a foundation for the creation of a global science research network in adolescent resilience and well-being, contextually- and culturally-relevant theoretical frameworks and methods for advancing that science, and support for a diverse cadre of scholars across the career trajectory to engage in and translate this work in ways that benefit local families and communities around the world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Program Director/Principal Investigator (Last, First, Middle): GUAN, JIANJUN Project Narrative: Following myocardial infarction, the prolonged inflammation and uncontrolled cardiac fibrosis gradually deteriorate cardiac function. Thus, timely transitioning the proinflammatory phase to anti-inflammatory phase, and inhibiting cardiac fibrosis are crucial for improving cardiac function. However, the effective therapies to simultaneously achieve both goals remain to be established. This project will create and validate a conceptually new approach to address current limitations. IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Systemic and structural racism within health systems and racial biases among health care providers and administrators are significant contributors to racial, ethnic and related inequities in health. Advancing anti-racist strategies requires health delivery systems (HDS) to partner with communities served by these institutions to gain necessary trust, co-design, and implement anti- racist practices. The proposed continuation of the ASTARISQ will be convened each year in an innovative, collaborative, and structured approach to achieve three aims: (1) Identify, prioritize, and co-design with impacted community members trainings on anti-racist strategies, policies, and practices to address structural racism in HDS to improve patient safety, quality of care, and trustworthiness in HDS; (2) Convene an interactive series of roundtables to train and prepare diverse stakeholder groups to address structural racism in HDS and health services research (HSR); and (3) Produce and disseminate guidance documents to equip participants and broader audiences with resources and skills in evidence-based, anti-racism-informed strategies to strengthen anti-racist policies and practices.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: ASTARISQ: Addressing systemic and STructurAl Racism to Improve Safety, Quality, and trustworthiness in health delivery systems

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glioblastoma (GBM), the most common malignant brain cancer, is notorious for wide dissemination in the brain; how invading GBM cells achieve invasiveness is poorly understood. Here, we will explore novel mechanisms driving invasion of GBM cells through confined space by applying innovative microchannel devices, fluorescent probes, new molecular reagents and live-cell imaging. We will also conduct proof-of-concept in vivo studies of how perturbation of mechanoelectrical membrane dynamics may curb GBM invasion, thus forming new paradigms to study GBM mechanobiology and its translational potential.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Fusobacterium nucleatum is associated with oral and extra-oral diseases, yet how this oral bacterium adapts to various metabolically changing environments to sustain its virulence potential is not well understood. Here, we will investigate formation of outer membrane appendages as a mechanism of metabolic adaption that enables F. nucleatum virulence. A better understanding of fusobacterial pathophysiology will aid the development of effective therapies against this oral pathogen.

PHR: Project Narrative The objective of this proposal is to understand systemic factors, with a focus on provider-patient interactions, that may contribute to the reduced access of Black and Hispanic patients to waitlisting and kidney transplantation. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Neurons depend on the transport of mRNA down axons and dendrites so that the mRNA can be translated into proteins locally. We uncovered a mechanism by which mRNA travels on mitochondria by binding to a protein called synaptojanin2. We now ask what species of mRNA use this method of transportation and how important the mechanism is for the health of neurons, synapses, and neuronal mitochondria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative There is an urgent need to address the current public health crisis of opioid abuse and overdose deaths through development of effective treatments for opioid use disorder and non-addictive therapeutics to manage pain. To this end, we are using human cells to create an ex-vivo model that recapitulate key features of neurobiology underlying the addictive process for opioid use disorder research. We anticipate the technological innovations to provide crucial tools for development of new therapeutics which can effectively combat the opioid crisis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Obesity has dramatically increased the burden of cardiovascular disease, and a major goal of the NIH/NHLBI is to reduce this burden. The goal of this application is to discover how a lipid transfer protein called CETP influences the liver pathways that improve glucose and lipid abnormalities in obesity, which is expected to help reverse the impact of obesity on cardiovascular risk. Our project also identifies pathways that mediate sex- differences in cardiovascular disease, which is also an NIH priority area.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative Black adults are disproportionately impacted by serious mental illness (SMI) and are known to underutilize formal mental health services, often seeking support to manage their mental health outside formal settings, creating unique pathways to mental health recovery. The recovery processes among Black adults with SMI are understudied, contributing to a lack of understanding of how they experience recovery through multiple pathways, including formal care (therapy and medication), informal support (peer support, family, faith-based), and personal recovery (self-management) and how these pathways promote and facilitate their recovery processes. The goal of this study is to explore the process of recovery among Black adults with SMI and examine how professional and informal help seeking leads to recovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Mutagenesis, changes in the DNA which can occur due to endogenous cellular event and environmental stresses, has wide-ranging impacts from the development of cancer and aging to the acquisition of antibiotic resistance in microorganisms. This meeting will bring together scientists from various countries from a wide range of disciplines to discuss the fundamental mechanisms driving mutagenesis across species. We aim to promote cross-field fertilization of ideas, the establishment of new collaborations, and based on what we are learning at the fundamental level, ultimately, the identification of potential new avenues for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Membrane transporters move ions, metabolites, nutrients, neurotransmitters and therapeutic drugs that are central to both life and death, into and out of cells and organellar compartments. They are the clinically relevant targets of blockbuster drugs to treat widespread diseases like diabetes, cancer and depression, as well as orphan diseases and rare genetic disorders. The 2024 Gordon Research Conference on Membrane Transporters titled “New Insights into Structure, Function, and Regulation of Critical Membrane Transport Proteins in Health and Disease” will bring together scientists from industry, academia and government to focus on translating advances in basic science to therapies that benefit numerous patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Work from our group and others over the past decade leads us to conceptualize that progressive pulmonary fibrosis is the last of three distinct stages of disease pathogenesis, starting from a point of sub-radiographic molecular pathology through progressive radiologically detectable presymptomatic disease, culminating in progressive, symptomatic pulmonary fibrosis. Leveraging samples from individuals across the complete spectrum of PF pathogenesis, together with formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded (FFPE)-capable, state-of-the-art single-cell and spatial transcriptomic technologies, we will establish a deep understanding of the identity, sequence, and spatial coordination of the molecular mechanisms that drive disease pathogenesis across these stages of PF progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: BENAROYA RESEARCH INST AT VIRGINIA MASON
PHR: NARRATIVE Multiple sclerosis is a debilitating autoimmune disease resulting from damage to the brain and spinal cord leading to neurological impairment and death. Relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (RRMS) is the most common type of multiple sclerosis and is defined by attacks (relapses or flares) of new or increasing neurologic symptoms followed by periods of partial or complete remission. The proposed studies are focused on understanding how changes in chromatin accessibility affect T cell function and lead to disease flares in RRMS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: NARRATIVE In recent years, the rapidly growing number of teens who use e-cigarettes threatens to reverse the progress made in reducing teen smoking, not only in the United States but around the world. This study aims to better understand how teens’ peer networks at school, including their best friends and others with whom they communicate online, influence them to both start and continue to smoke and use e-cigarettes. By comparing Mexican and U.S. teens, the results will help find better ways to reduce teen smoking, e-cigarette use, and the health problems that they cause.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The Annual Meeting of the American Society for Investigative Pathology offers a unique forum for the sharing of original research results related to a wide spectrum of human diseases and disorders, with particular emphasis on the development, treatment, and prevention of cancer. Such sharing fosters more rapid advances in the understanding of human diseases such as cancer and accelerates the rate at which this knowledge can be applied to the development of diagnostic and prognostic tests, as well as targeted therapies. A major goal of the meeting is to provide educational and career support to trainees and other young investigators who are interested in cancer biology and experimental pathobiology.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A major challenge to treating spinal cord injury and maximizing functional recovery is the sheer number of neural populations that carry brain-spinal information. To move beyond a tract-by-tract approach, this project harnesses new technology to survey the entirety of the affected cell types and then selectively manipulate genetically defined subsets, which will yield new insights into the injury and direct attention toward the most important sets of cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this project, we will develop computational software and generate extensive datasets to study CRISPR (also called genome editing) experiments, which are intended to make precise changes in the DNA of living cells. The software will allow researchers to understand how DNA differences between people may change how CRISPR works, the spectrum of potential DNA changes that might result from different CRISPR methods, and compare how experimental parameters may influence these results. This project will help scientists and clinicians develop precise tools to change DNA sequences in living cells to treat a range of diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The heart consists of multiple cell types, but how these different cell types interact to produce heart function is incompletely understood. An even more challenging problem is to determine the functional consequences of different subtypes within the same cell type – i.e. cardiac muscle cells with different patterns of gene expression. In this exploratory project, we will combine state-of-the-art sequencing technology with mechanistic mathematical modeling and functional cellular assays to predict the physiological consequences of multiple subtypes of cardiac muscle cells.

ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT ALBANY
PHR: NARRATIVE: Although fibrosis contributes to 45% of all deaths in the US, whether fibrosis is reversible and thereby treatable is not known. In the study, we will compare a reversible model of fibrosis with a non-reversible model of fibrosis to identify biomarkers for reversible and non-reversible fibrosis. We will also examine cell mesenchymal stromal cell transplantation and secreted vesicles made by these cells to reverse fibrosis as a step towards development of better therapeutics for salivary gland diseases involving fibrosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: NARRATIVE Although revolutionary approaches with immune checkpoint blockade (ICB) have dramatically transformed the therapeutic landscape of cancer patients, ICB has had a limited impact on head and neck squamous cell carcinomas (HNSCC) where >80% of patients fail to respond. The objective of this proposal is to exploit the ability of specific chemokines to recruit and activate key anti-tumoral immune cells and dramatically potentiate ICB therapy for enhanced tumor elimination and durable responses. The underlying mechanisms for treatment success as well mechanisms that limit responsiveness will also be explored to inform future therapeutic strategies.

PHR: Narrative Infection by the gram-negative pathogen Bordetella pertussis results in persistence in the human nasal cavity resulting in bacterial transmission and pertussis outbreaks. This research will advance the understanding of the mechanisms by which B. pertussis survives in the human nose and lead to the discovery of how both the bacterium and host adapt to the nasal cavity environment. Outcomes from this study will provide novel targets for next generation pertussis vaccines.

PHR: Project Narrative Converging lines of evidence indicate that stress, and childhood adversity in particular, accelerates the aging process, leading to impairment, suffering, and disease. The proposed study examines the role of mitochondrial DNA deletions in this process, leveraging data available from a longitudinal study of children that includes rich data on exposures, aging biomarkers, and health behaviors and outcomes. Results of this study are expected to provide insight into the early development of biological alterations that may accelerate aging and risk for disease, and provide targets for new treatment and prevention approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rheumatoid arthritis is a common multisystem inflammatory condition, affecting approximately 1% of the world population. A major unmet goal in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis is reliable clinical methodology to identify biomarkers that allow for more rational selection of therapy, so as to reduce patient morbidity, mortality, and the heavy economic burden associated with loss of function. This research will develop a patient-derived immunocompetent “Synovium-on-a-Chip” microphysiological system to accurately interrogate pathobiology and enhance precision medicine in rheumatoid arthritis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Disorders of gut brain interaction (DGBIs), like irritable bowel syndrome (IBS), functional dyspepsia, chronic diarrhea, and constipation, affect ~15% of the US population and lead to substantial chronic healthcare consumption and productivity losses, with costs estimated at $20 billion per year. A large proportion of DGBI patients have disruptions in mechanosensitivity; therefore, my laboratory's long-term goal is to elucidate the cellular and molecular mechanisms of gastrointestinal (GI) mechanosensitivity in health and DGBIs, and thus pave the way for novel targeted treatments for large cohorts of DGBI patients. We discovered a population of mechanosensitive enteroendocrine cells, which are important sensors in gut lining, and the objective of this proposal is to better understand their cellular function and roles in GI physiology, which would have substantial public health relevance since the knowledge acquired from these studies may yield novel diagnostic and therapeutic targets for DGBIs.

PHR: PROJECT Narrative Suicidal cell death is intrinsic to life, including single-cell microorganisms, but has been studied primarily in mammals to understand disease mechanisms and treat cancer. In contrast, mechanisms of suicidal death in microorganisms, especially pathogenic eukaryotes represents a new frontier undertaken in this study.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research contributes to public health by investigating the neurocognitive mechanisms by which depression contributes to episodic memory impairments, and age exacerbates these impairments, in racially/ethnically diverse adults across the lifespan. Comparisons across racial/ethnic groups, in the present case Non-Hispanic Black, Mexican American, and Non-Hispanic Whites, are needed to have an accurate understanding of how depression presents across age and race/ethnicity, whether it similarly impacts memory across groups, and the race-related psychosocial factors that explain these relationships. Understanding racial/ethnic differences in depression-cognition relationships can support effective cognition, wellbeing, and independence across the lifespan, revealing who may be most sensitive to the negative effects of depression and identifying reasons why, informing future cognitive, brain stimulation, and lifestyle-based interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Our current U01 grant, “DIVINCI: Dissection of Influenza Vaccination and Infection for Childhood Immunity” aims to study influenza infection from birth to examine the effect of first influenza exposure and subsequent exposures on immune response using participants from three birth cohorts. The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has caused several issues which have affected participant enrollment and incidence of influenza infections. This proposed Supplement will allow additional enrollment in Well Kiwis, support continued enrollment at UCSD, and supply testing reagents and PPE across all cohorts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) affects more than one million Americans and causes substantial morbidity and suffering, including greater susceptibility to colon cancer. MTG16 is a protein that regulates key differentiation pathways in the colon, affecting damaged colon regeneration and tumor growth in mouse IBD models. We propose to investigate the underlying mechanisms using a combination of biochemical, cellular, and animal experiments with the ultimate goal of improving IBD screening and therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative While fibroblast activation protein-α (FAP) has emerged as a potential target for pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) imaging using small molecule radiopharmaceuticals, the translation of FAP-targeted radionuclide therapy (FAP-TRT) has, thus far, failed. The proposed studies aim to develop, optimize and characterize a novel class of FAP-targeting agents (FAPTAs) based on lysosomal adduct formation and trapping to enhance tumor residualization and evaluate their efficacy in novel models recapitulating PDAC tumor microenvironment and heterogeneous FAP expression observed in human disease. This proposal will result in a novel class of FAPTAs that can deliver clinically relevant radionuclides (177Lu & 225Ac) to image and treat primary and metastatic PDAC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although over 95% of human genes have alternative transcript isoforms, most cancer studies largely ignore the impact of isoform-specific function. In this study, we will identify and functionally characterize a large set of cancer gene-isoform variants with and without somatic mutation. This project will provide a new framework for identification and characterization of cancer-associated isoforms, their functional impact on cancer, and their contribution to drug sensitivity and resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Following a myocardial infarction, an intense inflammatory response occurs whose duration and magnitude are modulated by CD4+CD25+Foxp3+ regulatory T cells (Tregs) that express CD39, an ectonucleotidase that degrades proinflammatory ATP and ADP. While the level of CD39 expression is genetically controlled in human Tregs by the genotype at specific single nucleotide polymorphisms, no studies have examined the impact of genetically determined Treg CD39 expression on inflammatory resolution and healing following myocardial infarction. In response to NOT-ES-20-018 Notice of Special interest: Promoting Fundamental and Applied Research in Inflammation Resolution,” we propose to determine how genetically determined differences in CD39 activity on Tregs impact the inflammatory resolution following myocardial infarction.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE Meiosis is the cellular process that gives rise to haploid gametes (sperm and oocytes) for reproduction and must be tightly regulated to avoid errors that could prevent fertility or lead to developmental defects in offspring. This proposal seeks to understand how a key DNA damage response pathway enforces quality control during both male and female meiosis. Cutting-edge molecular techniques and innovative mouse models will be used to precisely and comprehensively define key molecular events underlying successful gamete production, with important implications for infertility and the origins of birth defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: TITLE: Programs for generating inhibitory interneuron diversity and connectivity NARRATIVE: Inhibitory interneurons modulate the output of diverse neural circuits, and their dysfunction is linked to a growing number of neuropsychiatric and neurodegenerative disorders. Here we propose to define key functionally relevant programs for producing interneurons and test their functional capacity using deep phenotyping. This will enable new means to identify and implement inhibitory neuron-based therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to examine the relationship between functional cerebellar atypicalities and sensory over- responsivity (SOR) in autism spectrum disorder (ASD). Findings from this study will provide new insight into the involvement of the cerebellum in ASD symptomatology and help to characterize the complex neural mechanisms underlying SOR. Results derived from this research will inform future behavioral and psychopharmacological treatment strategies to target sensory symptoms in ASD youth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our sense of taste is mediated by taste buds on the tongue surface, and we use this sensory system to allow us to choose what to eat and what to avoid. Taste bud cells, like skin, continually renew throughout life, making taste prone to damage cancer therapies. Here we use mice to better understand how a particular chemotherapy used to treat kidney cancer causes troubling taste dysfunction for patients.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The primary causes of male infertility are defects in sperm motility and capacitation, which require properly functioning Ca2+ signaling. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it aims to provide molecular insights into the sperm Ca2+ channel CatSper and the CatSper-organized signaling nanodomains, whose integrity is required for sperm energy metabolism, thus sperm motility and male fertility. The proposed research is relevant to the NIH’s mission because it will improve our understanding of sperm physiology and male fertility, which may enable the development of more effective strategies for the diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of conditions that affect male fertility, with the ultimate goal of promoting a better quality of life for all individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: BUCK INSTITUTE FOR RESEARCH ON AGING
PHR: Huntington’s disease (HD) is a fatal, dominantly inherited neurodegenerative disorder that primarily affects neurons in the striatum and cortex. Our work has identified striatal developmental impairments in HD and transcriptional pathways that are amenable to disease-modifying interventions. Our work will advance the field by furthering the understanding of abnormal HD striatal developmental molecular mechanisms and identify potential interventions early in the pre-manifest phase of the illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a chronic cell degenerative disease characterized by hyperglycemia due to progressive destruction of pancreatic β-cells due to these cells having to counter upstream insulin resistance (most often in obese states). The high secretory burden of these insulin-producing professional secretory cells predisposes them to high levels of endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress, and recent work from our laboratories has shown that the activation of ER stress response pathways such as the unfolded protein response—UPR—may be an initial causal event in the development of T2D. In this collaborative grant we capitalize on our complementary expertise of the investigators to pharmacologically target the UPR by advancing new kinase inhibitors called KIRAs as new disease-modifying approaches for T2D.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Public Health Statement/Project Narrative Alcoholic liver disease (ALD) poses a significant threat to public health, accounting for approximately a half million death annually worldwide and the disease burden is projected to increase. This proposal is aimed at defining the molecular mechanism underlying the development of alcoholic fatty liver (AFL), the initial stage of ALD. The insights obtained through this study will reveal novel targets for the development of therapeutics that mitigate the disease burden of ALD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal of a one-day, virtual scientific workshop in October 2024 aims to increase knowledge of National Center for Complementary Integrative Health (NCCIH) funded complementary integrative medicine (CIM), support the representation of junior-level, underrepresented minority (URM) background scientists in the CIM workforce, and provide mentored research opportunities to utilize CIM in rehabilitation. Following the virtual workshop the fellows will attend the American Congress of Rehabilitation Medicine’s (ACRM’s) 2024 in-person annual meeting and be offered the opportunity for networking and research mentoring. The fellowship is geared specifically towards early career URM scientists; exposure to the most cutting-edge CIM science will encourage their interest in CIM and ultimately increase the number of promising URM scientists in the CIM field.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: FEDERATION OF AMER SOC FOR EXPER BIOLOGY
PHR: The Training, Workforce Development and Diversity (TWD) Program Directors’ Meeting would provide ~500 program directors, administrators, and NIGMS program staff with 2.5 days of interactive sessions that advance best practices in developing a diverse biomedical workforce, and catalyze research training interchange. The overarching goal is to build upon and extend the meeting’s past success as the premier conference devoted to NIGMS TWD-funded institutional training program directors and administrators. High-quality interactive presentations of evidence-based research training practices and interventions would be combined with networking and exchange of ideas on 4 major proposed themes: 1) trainee and faculty wellness; 2) advancing research mentoring; 3) inclusive excellence including recruiting and admissions; and 4) promoting positive research laboratory culture.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: NARRTIVE Alcohol use can lead to alcoholic liver disease and it also has inhibitory effects on host defense mechanisms. In this project, we will evaluate a new hypothesis that alcohol use reprograms innate immune cells resulting in inappropriate responses to an infectious challenge, a term called “trained immunity”. We will test this hypothesis by using immune cells from blood of patients with alcohol-associated liver disease and perform mechanistic studies in mouse models of alcohol-induced liver disease first, by identifying epigenetic and metabolic drivers of alcohol-induced trained immunity and second, by testing potential interventions with the aim to restore alcohol- induced immune defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: FEDERATION OF AMER SOC FOR EXPER BIOLOGY
PHR: Project Narrative The 2024 FASEB Summer Research Conference, “The Lung Epithelium in Health and Disease,” brings together basic scientists, translational researchers and clinician investigators to discuss state-of-the-art approaches to understand the molecular mechanisms which underlie a broad range of respiratory diseases such as asthma, bronchopulmonary dysplasia, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, COVID-19, and others. The objectives of the conference are to 1) stimulate meaningful discussion, 2) facilitate collaboration, 3) establish new research directions and priorities, and 4) serve as a major forum for early stage investigators and trainees to present their work, facilitating development of the “next generation” of lung epithelial biologists. By linking the pathobiology of these disorders to normal lung development and lung cell differentiation, central themes will be identified to provide a mechanistic understanding of these diseases, and will accelerate progress toward the development of novel therapeutic approaches for a variety of lung diseases.

Findings address a priority topic in health promotion and injury prevention in a population of high need.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: Narrative: By 12th grade, 10% of youth have been victims of sexual violence and much of this violence was committed by their adolescent peers. The SUSI campaign, a social marketing campaign to promote social norms that protect against sexual bullying and violence, has been funded by CDC's RPE program and implemented in Georgia High-Schools since 2014. The purpose of this project is to conduct formative and summative evaluation of the SUSI campaign's impact on sexual violence among high-school students, including sexual and gender minority youth.

PROJECT_TITLE: CE20-001 Effectiveness Evaluation of `Step Up Step In' (SUSI): A Campaign to Promote Social Norms against Sexual Violence

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The Tennessee Department of Health strongly desires to continue work with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and other EHS-Net consortium members to conduct practice- based research. Our mission is aligned with the stated purposes and objectives in the EHS-Net Practice Based Research to Improve Food Safety cooperative agreement and we have proposed projects that we feel can enhance foodborne disease investigation and food safety in Tennessee with generalizable outcomes for other jurisdictions. Our goal is to reduce morbidity and mortality associated with foodborne illness.

PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-EH-20-001: Environmental Health Specialist Network (EHS-Net) - Practice Based Research to Improve Food Safety

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: People of color experience persistent disparities in liver disease outcomes in the U.S.; this project investigates how these disparities affect members of the Mount Sinai World Trade Center (WTC) General Responder Cohort. We will analyze for disparities in mortality, introduce a liver disease screening tool to Mount Sinai WTC Healthcare Program (WTCHP) providers, and study archived specimens to assess for toxins that were present in the WTC dust cloud. Results will provide data to inform CDC/NIOSH decisions about whether liver diseases meet criteria for WTC certification and will help identify and address any disparities that may exist among WTC General Responders.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Racial and Ethnic Disparities in Liver Disease in the WTC General Responder Cohort

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative. This project will investigate how exposure to World Trade Center (WTC) dust during the 9/11 attacks impacts prostate cancer recurrence in First Responders with correlative mechanistic studies in relevant mouse genetic models. The results should aid in assessing whether responders with high exposure levels require increased active surveillance for evidence of biochemical recurrence and the presence of more aggressive disease.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Assessing the impact of WTC dust exposure on prostate cancer recurrence

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: Disturbed sleep is a common symptom in the World Trade Center General Responder Cohort (WTCGRC) either due to obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) or from other comorbid conditions and can lead to poor cardiovascular health. In this project we will determine the risk of MACE in responders with OSA, association between hs-CRP, a biomarker of cardiovascular health, and disturbed sleep in WTCGRC subjects with and without OSA. In addition, we will test if the disturbed sleep clinical phenotype of OSA is associated with low arousal threshold and propensity to wakefulness.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Disturbed sleep and cardiovascular outcomes in World Trade Center Responders

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The long term goal of this study is to develop safer and effective therapeutic approach for bone loss caused by excessive osteoclast (OC) differentiation implicated in many metabolic bone diseases (such as osteoporosis). The study will characterize the function of key epigenetic factor Cbx3 in interacting with C/EBPα to mediate OC formation with implication in bone homeostasis and bone loss. Insights gained from this study will not only address the basic scientific question about epigenetic regulation of gene expression in OC biology, but also will provide the foundation for the ultimate goal of facilitating the design of safer and novel therapeutic approach for osteolytic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Invasive fungal infections are a serious public health issue which are associated with unacceptably high mortality rates, suggesting modern therapies are insufficient. One obstacle in developing new therapies is an incomplete understanding of complex host-pathogen interactions during fungal infection, including the role of the recently characterized behavior of neutrophil swarming. This research will utilize novel microscale tools to elucidate key aspects of neutrophil swarming biology, in order to lay the foundation for leveraging swarming function in the design of new therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Trans women (TW) achieve suboptimal advancement through the HIV Care Continuum, including poor HIV healthcare utilization, retention in HIV medical care, and rates of viral suppression and these issues are exacerbated by comorbid conditions such as substance use disorder. This application will conduct a comparative-effectiveness research trial with a comprehensive economic evaluation of two HRSA-funded demonstration projects, to identify the optimal intervention for improving rates of viral suppression among TW living with HIV. The public health significance is profound, as comparative- and cost-effectiveness research trials are critical steps in the development and adoption of scalable and effective HIV care intervention, especially among key populations that rely on service provision in community-based settings.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aging is a major risk factor for alcoholic liver diseases and is associated with gradual alteration of liver structure and function as well as significant changes in liver cells including liver sinusoidal endothelial cells. The health relatedness of this grant proposal is that effective treatments are lacking for alcoholic liver diseases that cause vascular dysfunction and senescence in the liver. The rationale for our research is that the successful completion of the studies can ultimately be expected to provide a greater understanding of the functional role of non-coding RNA (ncRNA) mediated endothelial dysfunction and cellular senescence during the progression/recovery of alcoholic liver injuries and increase opportunities for the development of novel treatment paradigms for the management of alcoholic liver diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE It has been demonstrated that the human lumbosacral spinal cord can be neuromodulated with epidural (ESS) and transcutaneous (TSS) spinal cord stimulation to enable recovery of standing and volitional control of the lower limbs after complete motor paralysis. The work proposed herein will examine and identify the distinct and potentially overlapping electrophysiological mechanisms underlying TSS and ESS, and define how these approaches determine functional outcomes. We will also directly compare the immediate and delayed training effects of TSS and ESS on the ability to maintain self-assisted standing after SCI, and determine potential biomarkers associated with delayed neurophysiological changes that are thus indicative of plasticity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because human Noroviruses (hNoV) are the leading cause of viral gastroenteritis and food-borne disease worldwide. NIAID/NIH has designated Caliciviruses (including hNoV) as an “Emerging Infectious Disease Category B Priority Pathogen.” Currently, there are no antiviral drugs or vaccines approved for the treatment of hNoV infections, and therefore, the goal of this proposal is to design and develop a series of specific and safe small-molecule inhibitors targeting a critical viral protein required for virus replication and thus limit or eliminate hNoV infections in immunocompromised patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bacterial pneumonia caused by the highly antibiotic resistant ESKAPE pathogens is an important cause of acute lung injury, sepsis, and long-term sequelae collectively referred to as post-intensive care syndrome (PICS). Despite the severity and prevalence of these debilitating conditions, there are currently no specific therapies available to facilitate treatment and augment patient recovery. Thus, the goal of this proposal is to test the potentially transformative concept that the amyloid precursor protein (APP) modulates PMN NETosis and degranulation to limit lung damage in response to lung infection, and leverage these findings towards discovery of novel targets to treat pneumonia, sepsis, and PICS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pain, the most common complication of sickle cell disease, causes significant patient suffering and lacks effective treatments. This proposal will derive and preliminarily determine whether a biomarker that reflects the activities of the inflammatory and regulatory components of the immune system is correlated with the heterogeneity of pain seen in patients with sickle cell disease. This biomarker could be used in clinical trials of novel pain treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Older kidney transplant (KT) recipients are at higher risk of cognitive and physical function decline, Alzheimer's Disease (AD), and frailty compared to their healthy community-dwelling older adult counterparts; post-transplant cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection and subsequent inflammation may play a critical mechanistic role, and is a potentially preventable determinant of cognitive and physical function decline and frailty in older adults. This proposal aims to understand the effect of CMV, CMV cell mediated immune reconstitution (CMV-CMI), and inflammation on decline in cognitive and physical function, AD, and frailty among older KT recipients. Our exploration of CMV, CMV-CMI, cognitive and physical function decline in a novel population of older KT recipients will directly benefit this uniquely vulnerable population and guide their physicians by helping to inform risk prediction, guide clinical decision making, and possibly even offer clues into underlying physical and cognitive reserve mechanisms that may relate to cognitive decline, AD and frailty among healthy community-dwelling older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: OVERALL – NARRATIVE Ischemia-reperfusion injury (IRI) limits the success of orthotopic liver transplantation in patients with end-stage liver disease and those with tumors of hepatic origin. By using established mouse models of IRI, and analyzing human liver transplants, this translational Program Project seeks to address unmet scientific and clinical needs in the field of organ transplantation. The results have the potential to alter clinical paradigms by identifying the continuum of innate/adaptive immune phenotypes that can be used to select, monitor, and refine the practice of therapeutic interventions against IRI in transplant patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Endocrine diseases have a substantial impact on public health. Cushing’s syndrome occurs when the body produces too much of the stress hormone cortisol. This is often a consequence of defective cAMP signaling in adrenal glands. We test two transformative ideas that change how we think about Cushing’s syndrome. 1) Losing spatial control of the enzyme protein kinase A (PKA) is a molecular event that drives adrenal Cushing’s syndrome and 2) related disease-causing mutations in PKA promote distinct pathological effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: This proposal focuses on dissecting of the molecular mechanisms involved in the control of cell division, cell polarization, and morphogenesis. These simultaneously interrelated and functionally distinct processes are controlled by small GTPases, switch like proteins that primarily act at cell membranes to remodel cellular physiology. We propose to study the role of several small GTPases during these processes in intact model organisms, including the nematode C. elegans and the fruit ﬂy, Drosophila using a combination of live cell imaging, classical genetics, and optogenetics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Collagens are essential components of the extra-cellular matrix and basement membranes and mutations in these proteins result in severe diseases. Here, we propose an integrated approach that combines chemical biology, computational protein design and biochemistry to elucidate the mechanistic details of how the efficiency of initial trimerization dictates overall collagen biosynthesis. These studies will reveal how disease-associated mutation damage the unique folding pathway of collagens and potentially elucidate therapeutic approaches to treat collagen associate disorders (CADs).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative    Bats serve as reservoirs for many viral pathogens that are transmissible to humans, yet we still only  poorly- understand the immunological defenses that bats employ to inhibit viral infection. Here we take a unique  approach to identify components of the bat innate immune response by screening for bacterial immune evasion  proteins (IEPs) that promote virus replication when expressed in bat cells. We will use these IEPs as "tools" to  identify and characterize the bat immunity machinery these IEPs inhibit with the ultimate goal of leveraging this  information to develop new strategies to enhance bat immunological responses to infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative In January 2020, the NIH Institutes of Allergy and Infectious Diseases gathered leading investigators and clinicians from around the world to discuss the emergence of a multi-drug resistant pathogen called Candida auris and the global problem of systemic fungal infections. The conference highlighted the critical need to develop new, broad-spectrum antifungal drugs to combat not only Candida auris but other Candida and Aspergillus species because of increasing resistance to azole drugs, and growing echinocandin resistance in C. glabrata. This proposal aims to develop a unique and systematic Redesigning Existing Drugs against Indispensable Targets (ReEDIT) platform technology to identify essential fungal genes whose products are inhibited by Chemically Tractable Inhibitors (CTIs), originally developed against human orthologs, and advance essential targets and drug candidates into lead optimization programs, accelerating development of novel drugs to treat life threatening fungal infections.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Child poverty in combination with the enduring and inequitable burden of the COVID-19 pandemic underscores the urgent importance of understanding the effects of poverty on diverse children and families. Although many children flourish despite the stress that economic hardship brings, chronic and unpredictable poverty-related adversities put children at an increased risk of developing cognitive, emotional, and behavioral difficulties that, while potentially adaptive in the immediate context of poverty, may disrupt their capacity to meet the learning and psychosocial demands of formal schooling. Using data from a mixed-methods national survey of predominantly low-income families during the pandemic, the current project addresses central questions concerning (1) what, when, for whom, and how poverty-related experiences unfold during pivotal developmental periods; and (2) how such experiential manifestations enhance or impair core regulatory skills critical for children’s successful adaptation across contexts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Stable integration of the HIV-1 viral genome to the host genome is the reason this infection cannot be cured. Features of host chromatin that enable HIV-1 integration and the components that engender these elements have not been thoroughly elucidated. We propose to investigate the functional and regulatory roles of host chromatin marks and modifiers during integration to reveal novel targets for antiretroviral therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Hepatic insulin resistance is a key factor in the progression of type 2 diabetes, as well as an unmet treatment need. Studies supported by this grant have provided insight into mechanisms of hepatic insulin action and resistance, and suggested alternative approaches to its treatment. Key advances in the last cycle–including the discovery of a new mechanism to account for the twin pathogenic abnormalities of increased hepatic glucose production and dyslipidemia in diabetes, the development of FoxO1-based selective insulin sensitizers, and the discovery of Gpr17 as a mediator of insulin and leptin signaling to promote energy efficiency–offer hope that the disease can be reversed and prompt a strategic reassessment of drug discovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE During normal physiologic stress (such as endurance exercise training), the heart muscle increases in size (undergoes hypertrophy), but in disease the heart muscle undergoes hypertrophy but later becomes weak (heart failure). We propose to study a process called Store-Operated Calcium Entry (SOCE) in both favorable (physiologic stress due to exercise) and unfavorable forms (resulting in heart failure) of altered heart structure and function. Findings from these studies may be used to find new therapies for heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Defects in the length of the specialized structures at the ends of human chromosomes, known as telomeres, can lead to myriad medical problems including a failure of the bone marrow to produce blood cells. Persons born with certain mutations in the gene TINF2 have very short telomeres and develop bone marrow failure at a very young age. This project seeks to understand why these particular mutations have such catastrophic effects on telomere length and utilizes a novel humanized mouse model to examine the impact of TINF2 mutations on telomere length and bone marrow function, and test potential therapeutic approach to treat the associated-bone marrow failure.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Stress Hydrocortisone In Pediatric Septic Shock (SHIPSS) Narrative Sepsis represents the most common cause of childhood mortality worldwide, with 200 cases of pediatric sepsis diagnosed each day in the U.S. alone, with an associated hospital mortality rate of 5-10%, and health care expenditures approaching $5 billion annually. This prospective, randomized, double-blinded, placebo-controlled interventional trial will examine the potential benefits and risks of adjunctive hydrocortisone prescribed to critically ill children with fluid and vasoactive-inotropic refractory septic shock. It will benefit public health by providing the heretofore missing evidence to inform guidelines regarding therapy for septic shock in children.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The SET1/MLL methyltransferases constitute a novel family of intracellular enzymes, which are responsible for regulating gene expression in all eukaryotic cells by catalyzing histone methylation. Dysregulation of members of this enzyme family is closely associated with neurological disorders including schizophrenia, autism, and intellectual disability, as well as other human diseases such as cancers and congenital heart disease. This proposal is aimed at revealing the molecular mechanisms underlying the functions and regulation of a prototypical yeast SET1/MLL methyltransferase complex, which will benefit our understanding of the basic biology of transcription regulation and the etiology of diseases associated with the mutation and dysregulation of the human SET1/MLL orthologs and paralogs.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: The drug supply chain is global and susceptible to disruptive unanticipated events, such as the 2019 Corona- virus (COVID-19) pandemic, but the impact of drug shortages during a global public health emergency and effectiveness of strategies to alleviate drug shortages is unknown. The proposed research is relevant to public health because policy-makers need real world evidence to plan for future global emergencies, drug shortages at large, and inform national- and international-policy to decrease the impact of drug shortages on patient outcomes. Thus, this project is relevant to the AHRQ research priority areas of patient safety, im- provements in health care practice, providing timely response to critical questions, and AHRQ priority groups.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Impact of COVID-19 on Drug Shortages

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Obesity is a major public health concern, as it increases the risk for diabetes, heart disease and certain forms of cancer. Obesity, particularly in its most severe form, has an extremely strong genetic basis. Unfortunately, most of the genes that predispose people to obesity, as well as the molecular and cellular pathways those genes participate in, remain unknown. This project builds on the expertise and established collaborative work of two investigators to illuminate how dysfunction of neuronal primary cilium, a specific sub-cellular compartment that functions as an intercellular antenna, causes obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Glioblastoma is the most common adult brain cancer and has remained incurable since it was first identified over two centuries ago. A central reason for this failure in treatment lies in the heterogenous and immunosuppressive nature of these malignancies, and its ability to evade the immune system from destruction. This proposal will identify how microglia and macrophages, the largest non-tumor component of the microenvironment, can adopt opposing “tumor killing/tumor promoting” activation states and how manipulation of these different states may redirect progressing glioblastoma toward regression.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We currently lack the ability to predict how cancer cells will respond to transcriptional inhibitors—a drug class of major clinical and pre-clinical interest. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed R01, Improving Medication Adherence with Pharmacist and Community Health Worker Team (IMPaCT) to Reduce Disparities in Hypertension, will test the effectiveness of an innovative, culturally-tailored, coordinated care intervention derived from previous research (RxHL Study, 1R01HL120907) and existing pilot medication therapy management program at the research site. Building on an ecosocial framework of chronic disease self-management, the IMPaCT intervention by pharmacist-community health worker team will identify and address individual, clinical, social-cultural and structural barriers to medication adherence among low- income minority patients with hypertension, polypharmacy use and nonadherence. To determine effectiveness, we will conduct a rigorous, intention-to-treat randomized controlled trial among African-American, Latino and Vietnamese patients at a community health center to create a practical solution to the adherence problem and provide a how-to framework for healthcare workforce to reduce health disparities in hypertension and prevent cardiovascular risks among the vulnerable population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chromosomally unstable cancer cells frequently harbor cytoplasmic DNA that activates a cell-intrinsic innate immune response. We currently do not understand whether these cytoplasmic DNAs are capable of eliciting non-cell autonomous effects to surrounding cells in the tumor microenvironment. The proposed research seeks to elucidate whether and how fragmented chromosomes entrapped in the cytoplasm can undergo lateral transfer between cells in a shared environment, which will advance our understanding of cell-to-cell interactions in the tumor microenvironment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Timbre, or the quality of a sound, is a critical component of speech, music, and sound source identification, yet how timbre is encoded by the central nervous system is not understood. This proposal will investigate how suprathreshold synthetic and natural timbre sounds are encoded in neurons of the auditory midbrain, while also improving a computational model to be used for these and other complex sounds. This research is relevant to public health as cochlear implants and hearing aids distort timbre; our results will inform novel signal-processing strategies to benefit users of cochlear implants and hearing aids.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the well-described impacts of age-related hearing loss (ARHL) on general and hearing-specific health, little information exists on benefits of hearing aid use for these outcomes, or on whether earlier intervention improves treatment results. This epidemiological study conducted in a sample of the general population will assess benefits of hearing aid use on psychosocial well-being, communication, and cognitive outcomes that capture general and hearing-specific health, and will determine the extent to which earlier intervention for ARHL is a determinant of hearing aid benefit. Findings from this work will provide a scientific framework for clinical and public health recommendations related to the optimal timing of hearing aid interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A disproportionate burden of cumulative lifetime trauma among African American (A.A.) people living with HIV may, directly and indirectly, contribute to poor retention in HIV care, poor viral suppression, and high morbidity and mortality in A.A. communities. The proposed study aims to understand the role of trauma on health disparities seen in the HIV health continuum, specifically, retention in HIV care and durable viral suppression among A.A. men and women living with HIV. The findings of the proposed study will provide a deeper understanding of the long-term clinical implications of trauma on retention in HIV care and durable viral suppression among A.A. people living with HIV; these findings may also inform routine follow-up practices to reduce the trend in health inequities among A.A. people living with HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The shortage and poor quality of donor organs represent major limitations facing liver transplantation, the gold standard of care in patients with end-stage liver disease and those with tumors of hepatic origin. The goal of this project is to improve long-term liver transplant outcomes as well as “rejuvenating” suboptimal hepatic tissue, and promoting homeostasis without late fibrotic pathology. Our findings should facilitate innovative interventions to improve the quality/size of the current organ supply, an absolute imperative for the full realization of success for solid organ transplantation

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Innate lymphoid cells (ILCs) are highly plastic cells that can exert both enhancing and regulatory activity in tumor microenvironment depending on the type of signals they receive. Our hypothesis is that the suppressor functions of ILC2s are enhanced by stress through β2 adrenergic signaling and thus contributes to the known tumor promoting effects of stress. The work proposed here will investigate how adrenergic stress affects ILC2 plasticity and immune-inhibitory functionality in the tumor site with the long-term intent of improving outcomes of immunotherapy in patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) is a normal cellular program involved in development and wound healing that occurs aberrantly in carcinomas to promote metastasis and chemotherapy resistance. Within cell populations and tumors, EMT occurs with a high degree of heterogeneity, with some cells undergoing the transition and others remaining in an epithelial state. This project will develop integrated experimental and computational methods for quantifying the degree to which EMT heterogeneity is regulated transcriptionally or via biochemical signaling processes in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC), with anticipated results having important implications for developing novel combination therapies for PDAC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because studying new chemical and molecular approaches to inhibition of high-risk childhood neuroblastoma may result in novel approaches to treatment of this devastating childhood cancer, as well as other EP300-dependent cancers. The strategy described here, in which existing and newly-generated agents targeting the known neuroblastoma dependency EP300 are assessed alone and in combination with conventional chemotherapy agents is highly relevant to the NCI mission of developing novel therapeutic approaches to advance scientific knowledge, improve survival outcomes and reduce the toxicities of cancer therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative When cells are stressed they can adapt and try to survive, or they can instead undergo cell death if the stress is too severe. Cancer cells tip this balance by finding ways to survive when normal cells might typically die. Our research has contributed significant new knowledge by uncovering mechanisms of cell death and new cellular adaptations that promote cell survival, uncovering vulnerabilities that can be targeted for cancer therapy.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative Significant concern exists about the COVID-19 pandemic causing increased antibiotic prescribing in hospitals and accelerating the public health threat of bacterial resistance. In this project, we will measure the impact of COVID-19 on overall and condition specific antibiotic prescribing and bacterial resistance patterns using data from a diverse, nationally representative group of over 350 U.S. hospitals. We will then conduct interviews with healthcare professionals at hospitals with varying alterations in antibiotic prescribing during the pandemic to identify effective strategies for inclusion in a resilient antibiotic stewardship implementation toolkit.
