IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The novel and theory-driven 16-week “Guys/Girls Opt for Activities for Life” (GOAL) school- and home-based intervention addresses the high overweight and obesity prevalence among U.S. adolescents and the underrepresentation of those who are underserved in prevention research. To address these vital public health priorities, a rigorous group RCT will be used to evaluate the efficacy of the GOAL intervention in improving healthy eating and physical activity and perceptions related to both behaviors, as well as anthropometric outcomes among urban, racially diverse, adolescents of low socioeconomic status. The intervention is expected to reduce cardiovascular disease risk factors among at-risk adolescents and contribute toward reducing health disparities, a major priority of the NIH and CDC Division of Adolescent and School Health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Extracellular vesicles (EVs) comprise a heterogeneous pool of membrane-bound compartments exported from cells, and EV-mediated intercellular propagation of microRNA-122 (miR-122) has been purported to promote breast cancer metastasis in vivo. Concurrent with this line of experimental evidence, we have demonstrated, both in cells and a cell-free reaction, that the Lupus La antigen (La) mediates selective enrichment of miR-122 into a high-density exosome subpopulation of EVs derived from a metastatic breast cancer cell line, however, the mechanism underpinning this selective sorting event remains unclear. This proposal will elucidate the molecular mechanism by which the La:miR-122 ribonucleoprotein complex is selectively sorted into breast cancer-derived exosomes, and by extension, identify putative therapeutic targets for metastatic breast cancer and inform efforts to engineer exosomes into effective vehicles for therapeutic drug and nucleic acid delivery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hypertension is the risk factor responsible for the greatest reduction in quality-adjusted life years globally, and effective therapies that reduce blood pressure and its related mortality make it an ideal target for public health programs. However, sustained hypertension control on a population level has been a major challenge, particularly in low-resource settings. We will partner with the South African Department of Health to implement a combination of individual and clinic-based interventions to achieve sustained blood pressure control in a high-prevalence, low-resource region of rural South Africa. We will adopt an implementation science framework to consider acceptability, feasibility, effectiveness, and assess conditions for reproducibility and scalability, to inform best practices for implementation of hypertension control in LMICs, and to ensure our findings are directly relevant to academic and public health stakeholders implementing similar programs globally. !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) affects 1 in 44 children, but the underlying mechanisms that lead to ASD are poorly understood. This project studies the role of CHD8, a high-confidence autism risk gene identified in patients with ASD, in shaping key biological processes in early vertebrate brain development. Together, this work will advance our understanding of this important gene and shed light on the basic mechanisms underlying neurodevelopment in ASD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Reduced interferon (IFN) signaling is major way tumor cells evade the immune system. Mitochondria are central players in cell metabolism, but their role in regulating anti-tumor immune responses is less well understood. This project examines the link between mitochondria and IFN signaling, which may provide new ways to target tumor metabolism to bolster anti-tumor immune responses and the effectiveness of immunotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Currently, there are few options for treating diffuse cancers, particularly those that arise in sensitive tissues (i.e., not amenable to resection), in tissues in which drug diffusion is limited, or in patients for whom typical interventions incur unacceptable sequelae (e.g., pediatric patients). Using as basis one of the most aggressive forms of pediatric brain tumor, Diffuse Intrinsic Pontine Glioma (DIPG), we propose the use of safe electrical fields to move and/or consolidate DIPG cells – electrotaxis – and thus provide a strategy to for making diffuse cancers amenable to surgical removal and/or chemo/radio therapeutic treatment.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative Asymptomatic colonization (i.e., carriage) with carbapenem-resistant Enterobacterales (CRE), a type of highly drug-resistant bacteria, poses urgent challenges in U.S. hospitals: undetected colonized patients can transmit CRE to other patients, and colonized patients themselves are at a significantly higher risk of developing CRE infections. Because widescale screening for CRE colonization remains impractical for most U.S. hospitals, hospitals miss critical opportunities to identify patients at high risk of CRE colonization and infection early, when it is still possible to prevent deleterious patient outcomes. We propose to leverage state-of-the-art machine learning and natural language processing (NLP) techniques on electronic health records (EHRs) to improve identification of CRE-colonized and infected patients by: (a) developing and validating natural language processing classifiers to detect established and new CRE risk factors from free-text, narrative EHR data; (b) using NLP-derived variables with EHR structured data to predict CRE colonization at admission; and (c) developing machine learning-based models to predict which CRE-colonized patients will progress to infection during the hospital stay, in order to guide precision medicine-based approaches for interventions.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Using natural language processing and machine learning to identify patients at high risk of potentially preventable carbapenem-resistant Enterobacterales (CRE) infection

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Loss of muscle and bone mass with age are underlying factors contributing to falls and fractures in the elderly, and these fractures are very costly in terms of both financial burden and quality of life. A critical barrier to progress in correcting the problem of muscle and bone loss with aging is a poor understanding of the molecular and cellular mechanisms underlying age-related musculoskeletal dysfunction. Our goal is to address this problem by providing critical, new information on the molecular and cellular mechanisms that control these processes, and thereby improve scientific knowledge, technical capability, and eventually clinical practice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research would be the first to examine the feasibility, engagement and implementation of a technology and behavioral economics enhanced Contingency Management study for alcohol misuse among American Indian young adults. The proposed research and training plan will provide the protected time for the candidate to acquire the knowledge and skills necessary to become an NIH-funded independent investigator with expertise in community engaged research, developing culturally grounded substance use disorder treatments for American Indian communities, behavioral economics, technology-delivered interventions and statistics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Despite remarkable progress in reducing mortality from infectious diseases during the 20th century, in 2020 humanity faces three major growing infectious disease threats: 1) emerging infections; 2) antimicrobial resistance; and 3) synthetic pathogens. Well trained epidemiologists are critical to inform and guide the societal response to these worsening and unprecedented threats. This infectious disease epidemiology training program will produce researchers with the skills necessary to confront these 21st century threats.

The Core C is essential for the success of the Program Project as all individual projects in the Program will need to use the same cells and standardized services in order for the data sets generated from individual projects are comparable, consistent and synergistic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Despite major advances in cardiovascular research, there are significant and unacceptable disparities in healthcare in our underserved populations, for example, risk of heart failure, sudden cardiac death, and obesity is doubled in African Americans, death from stroke is four times greater than majority populations. Yet too few members of disadvantaged populations achieve careers in the STEM workforce. Given the urgent need to redress these inequities, Cleveland State University will partner with the Cleveland Clinic to offer the first T32 training program in Cleveland to recruit pre-doctoral students from those populations underserved and underrepresented in the STEM workforce. !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Muscle and bone loss with age are underlying factors contributing to falls and fractures in the elderly. These fractures are very costly both in terms of financial burden and quality of life. This project will determine whether inhibitors of the kynurenine pathway, a key pathway involved in aging, can improve muscle and bone function with aging as a strategy to prevent falls and fractures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – Overall This Program renewal will provide evidence to improve the equity and effectiveness of breast cancer screening and surveillance. We will create risk prediction tools that perform well for all racial and ethnic groups and examine factors that influence the quality of breast imaging across radiology facilities to identify opportunities to improve care. Our findings will provide timely information to inform decision making about the frequency and type of breast cancer screening and surveillance for women, healthcare providers, and policymakers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The human brain has approximately equal numbers of glia cells and neurons, and interactions between these cells are essential for all nervous system functions. Impaired glia-neuron interactions underlie many neurological diseases including Alzheimer’s disease, Autism, epilepsy and may contribute to age-related neural decline. To understand glial contribution to nervous system health, aging and disease, we will dissect glia-neuron interactions with exquisite speed and molecular resolution in vivo by using a powerful genetic model we recently established.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Public Health Relevance/Project Narrative Community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) is a leading cause of hospitalization and inpatient antimicrobial use in the United States. However, diagnostic uncertainty at the time of initial treatment and following negative cultures is associated with prolonged exposure to broad-spectrum antimicrobials. We propose a large multicenter cluster randomized controlled trial to test two approaches to reducing the use of broad-spectrum antibiotics in adult patients with CAP a) routine use of rapid diagnostic testing at the time of admission and b) pharmacist-led de-escalation after 48 hours for clinically stable patients with negative cultures.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Reducing Antimicrobial Overuse Through Targeted Therapy for Patients with Community-Acquired Pneumonia

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – Project 2  Women of minority race/ethnicity, lower income, lower education, and rural residence have limited access to  higher quality breast cancer screening and newer technologies that can detect more cancer and reduce  unnecessary diagnostic follow-up. The proposed study will comprehensively evaluate how targeted facility-  level changes, including the use of artificial intelligence for automated mammography interpretation, can  promote greater equity in breast cancer screening outcomes. This study will generate evidence to guide  practitioners and policymakers in optimizing the quality of care in cancer screening and reducing  the unequal  burden of cancer in our society.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Some people age significantly more gracefully than others, and understanding the neural factors that underlie those individual differences could lead to interventions to slow or even stop age-related behavioral impairments. The objective of this project is to investigate two neural factors that may play a role, namely age-related changes in the distinctiveness of neural representations and age-related changes in the variability of neural signals. This research could lead to the development of better preclinical markers of Alzheimer’s disease and open avenues for pharmaceutical interventions to slow cognitive declines in aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Impairment of information processing is a frequent consequence of stroke. Several interventions have been developed to address this impairment but the transfer of gains made in the treatment setting to everyday life and the retention of these gains is limited. The proposed research is designed to begin the process of evaluating a Transfer Package of behavioral techniques designed to result in: 1) transfer of gains achieved in the treatment setting to everyday life, and 2) result in retention of the real-world gains without decrement for at least 1 year.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – Project 3  Surveillance mammography is recommended every year for all breast cancer survivors who still have breast  tissue. Unfortunately, it does not work well for all survivors—with 3 out of every 10 second breast cancers  missed. This Project focuses on improving imaging surveillance after breast cancer treatment by: testing a risk  model for breast cancer survivors to receive additional imaging if they are at high risk; validating artificial  intelligence algorithms to see if they can help find more cancers on mammography; and understanding if  conditions where women are born, grow, live, work, and age affect how we find and treat second breast  cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: NARRATIVE: Cardiovascular disease (CVD) including heart failure, stroke, and myocardial infarction are leading causes of morbidity and mortality in people with HIV worldwide with the highest HIV-attributable CVD risks observed in Africa. Elevated blood pressure at nighttime and poor sleep may contribute to this increased risk of CVD in people with HIV. Our cohort study in Tanzania will be the first to investigate the relationship between nighttime blood pressure, poor sleep, and the onset of CVD in people with HIV and our research findings will inform the design of prevention and treatment interventions to prevent CVD in people with HIV in both Africa and in the United States.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nonsense (stop) mutations lead to truncated proteins and cause many genetically inherited diseases, such as Duchenne muscular dystrophy and cystic fibrosis, and are also common in cancer. We propose a novel approach based on repurposing an endogenous cellular machinery that reinterprets (recodes) UGA stop codons as a selenocysteine amino acid, hence reestablishing translation of the full-length protein. This project, if successful, will lead to effective oligonucleotide-based therapies for a broad spectrum of disorders and diseases.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Public health disasters, such as COVID-19, have disproportionate consequences on low-income and racial- ethnic minority communities through pathways that likely exacerbate disparities associated with poverty and racism, and act over extended periods. Young children are vulnerable to deleterious effects on parent-child relational health and early psychosocial development that will likely result in large adverse consequences for mental health and educational attainment across the life course, but have received less attention and resources. The current application provides a unique opportunity to determine whether population-scalable, healthcare- and community-based, preventive interventions initially targeting pathways of adversity for families living in poverty can prevent widening of disparities anticipated to result from COVID-19, by pooling and harmonizing seven data sets across four studies (including three NICHD R01 awards) in New York City, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania and Flint, Michigan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hypertension is a modifiable risk factor for cardiovascular disease and the most common comorbidity among women with HIV; yet few lifestyle behavior interventions have been adapted for this population. Using a mixed methods approach informed by social cognitive theory, the current project aims to systematically adapt a physical activity intervention supplemented by peer support for women with HIV and hypertension. The adapted behavioral intervention will be pilot tested to assess its acceptability, feasibility, and preliminary impact on blood pressure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Chronic kidney disease affects > 50% of older adults, 75 years or older, and type 2 diabetes mellitus is the commonest cause of chronic kidney disease. The sirtuin family of nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD)-dependent deacetylases act as metabolic energy sensors, mediate some of the beneficial effects of caloric restriction on lifespan, and are important regulators of the aging process. NAD augmentation by administration of NAD precursors, such as nicotinamide mononucleotide (NMN), prevents or reverses a number of aging-related conditions, including diabetic kidney disease. Reduced NAD levels in the kidney and aberrant signaling through the sirtuin-NAD pathway are closely linked to the pathogenesis of diabetic kidney disease (DKD) in mice as well as humans, and NMN supplementation prevents the development of DKD and reduces mortality in a mouse model of DKD. The proposed proof-of-principle, Phase 2a, randomized, placebo-controlled, double-blind, parallel group trial will be the first Phase 2a trial to determine the efficacy of NAD augmentation by administration of its precursor, nicotinamide mononucleotide, in older adults, 60 years or older, with type 2 diabetes mellitus and diabetic kidney disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In children, obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is evaluated by overnight polysomnography (PSG) in a sleep laboratory, but these facilities are limited, and the test requires caregivers to spend a night away from home with their child. Home sleep apnea testing (HSAT) is a similar test conducted in the home environment, but it is not currently used in children because it has not been directly evaluated against PSG. This trial will compare HSAT with PSG in terms of its accuracy and impact on therapeutic decision for children being evaluated for OSA, and family factors be assessed to determine if HSAT is a good alternative test to PSG.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hallux rigidus (HR) is a painful form of arthritis of the great toe joint that affects nearly half of all females and over one third of all males older than 60; this joint bears loads greater than body weight with each step, and when it becomes stiff and arthritic, this can be very painful. Patients often find non-surgical (i.e., footwear-based) treatments ineffective, while surgical treatments, which can increase motion of the joint (i.e., remove excess bone), remove the joint (i.e., fuse the two bones comprising the joint), or replace the joint (i.e., implant new mating surfaces), have been found to be less than satisfactory. The proposed study will explore healthy and pathologic great toe joint motion, determine the effectiveness of total joint replacements, including a new design developed by our group, at restoring motion, and develop tools to improve the design of these implants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: The central hypothesis of this proposal is that autoantibodies to histone/nucleosome post-translational modifications could exhibit superior diagnostic potential and pathogenic relevance in lupus. The goal of this academia-industry partnership is to test this hypothesis using a novel, high-throughput, spectrally resolved, fluorescent bead-based screening platform bearing a comprehensive battery of post-translational modified nucleosomes/histones in several well-annotated lupus cohorts. The availability of reliable serum biomarkers that can accurately diagnose SLE and renal involvement in lupus can prompt earlier treatment, which has been shown to improve long-term outcome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This grant applies a combination of microfluidics, microscopy, synthetic biology, and mathematical modeling to study a broad class of bacterial survival mechanisms known as stochastic switches. The research will reveal the impact of stochastic switching on bacterial aggregation and its consequences for antimicrobial treatment, the variety and molecular mechanisms of antibiotic persistence pathways in E. coli, and the interplay of stochastic switches with recombination in the emergence and maintenance of antibiotic resistant bacteria in the human gut microbiome. The project will yield clinically important findings including the ability to control the genetic pathways that underlie cell-cell aggregation, new strategies for combating and controlling bacterial persistence, and a new understanding of how host-to-host variation and dynamics of the human gut microbiota impacts antibiotic resistance and antigenic variation in bacteria.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many children with cerebral palsy have difficulty walking, which contributes to drastically reduced levels of physical activity and lower quality of life. This proposal seeks to address ambulatory impairment in cerebral palsy by investigating the use of wearable ankle assistance for mobility augmentation and targeted ankle resistance for gait training. The long-term goal of this work is to establish a holistic, evidence-based ankle therapy for cerebral palsy that increases physical activity and community participation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Detection of PDAC at an early stage positively impacts survival, and screening in eligible high-risk individuals (HRIs) defined by family history and mutation status is considered best practice. The overall goal of this proposal is to use our accumulated knowledge to considerably enhance use of new blood protein and methylated DNA (MDM) biomarkers for early detection of PDAC. We will leverage our extensive biospecimen resources to test whether a combination of proteins, MDMs, and CA19-9 will accurately identify early stage PDAC in HRIs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The genetic material is packed into the nucleus via the formation of long-range chromatin loops. We propose to examine and control the formation and dissolution of chromatin loops in real time in a variety of biological processes across a range of biological time scales, from minutes (neuronal firing), to hours (exit from mitosis), to weeks (cellular reprogramming). We will develop and apply new live cell DNA and RNA imaging technologies, inducible synthetic architectural proteins, and DNA sequencing to understand the 3D genome's structure-function relationship in living cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Periodontitis is a common chronic inflammatory disease characterized by destruction of the supporting structures of the teeth. Although there is a clear relationship between degree of obesity and periodontal disease incidence, the mechanisms that underpin the links between these two conditions are not completely understood. This application seeks to understand the impact of immature myeloid cells in obesity-associated periodontal disease which will provide mechanistic insight linking obesity and dietary changes with oral bone quality in health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The presence of mild cognitive impairment (MCI) in older adults increases their fall risk. Although reasons for the higher prevalence of falls in MCI are still not clear, neurodegenerative changes observed in this pathology result in cognitive, physiological and functional deficits, which contribute to risk of falls. Despite knowing the benefits of reactive balance training on reducing fall risk, and cognitive training on improving cognitive functions in healthy older adults (OA), the effectiveness of these therapeutic strategies in reducing risks of falls in MCI when administered simultaneously is not yet established. Therefore, this study aims to examine the biomechanics, neuromuscular, and cortical mechanisms involve in reactive balance strategies after gait and stance perturbations, and to test a novel training paradigm including a task-specific reactive balance approach with cognitive training in MCI population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: 8. Project Narrative Current therapeutics are not sufficiently effective to protect lives and brain function following poisoning by highly toxic organophosphates such as nerve agents. A series of novel compounds has shown efficacy as antidotes in promoting survival of laboratory animals poisoned by nerve agent surrogates, and a lead compound has been identified for further development. This project would produce data to further characterize the lead compound with additional survival efficacy tests, and pharmacology and toxicology information in two animal species to support this potential drug proceeding into future advanced development and ultimately FDA approval.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT (Three Sentences) Despite the success of the existing human brain imaging technologies, next-generation imaging tools are strongly desired. We propose to develop fast and ultrafast 3D photoacoustic computed tomography for high- resolution brain activity imaging based on the state-of-the-art technologies. This new modality has the advantages of high imaging speed, high spatial definition, high sensitivity, low background, rich signal contrast, open and magnet-free imaging, bedside and quiet operation, and low maintenance cost.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Cell fate decisions are essential for development and the maintenance of organs throughout life, thus understanding them underlies health challenges ranging from developmental disorders to cancer. This project will develop computational methods using genomic data to study the dynamic gene expression programs that control cell fate decisions. The result will be new tools with which to study dynamic cellular processes in single cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Cardiovascular events, such as heart attacks and strokes, are the leading cause of death in women and occur more frequently in transgender individuals undergoing gender affirming hormone therapy. This project utilizes genomics in women and transgender individuals undergoing therapy to identify sex and gender specific cardiovascular disease genes that will inform clinical screening and therapy in these groups.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Femoroacetabular impingement (FAI) has an etiologic role in up to 50% of hip osteoarthritic cases. While hip bone deformity has been well characterized in FAI, a major knowledge gap exists regarding the molecular and epigenetic events involved in disease progression. The goal of this research project is to identify critical biologic events, specifically transcriptome and methylation pathways involved in progression of hip osteoarthritic disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Impaired postpartum sleep can significantly impact postpartum recovery, maternal health, and the maternal- infant dyad. To characterize postpartum sleep, screen for postpartum sleep disorders and explore the association between sleep and postnatal depression, researchers and services providers need accessible, context-specific, patient-centered, psychometrically sound, and pragmatic patient-reported outcome measures (PROs) that have been developed in racially and socioeconomically diverse populations. The Patient-Reported Outcomes Measurement Information System® (PROMIS®) Sleep Disturbance and Sleep-Related Impairment PROs that will be adapted and evaluated in this proposal will meet that need, enabling postpartum sleep assessment and screening for postpartum sleep disorders in large cohorts of patients, whilst guiding future interventions to improve maternal health and well-being.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: LOUISIANA STATE UNIV A&M COL BATON ROUGE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) is the number one cause of pneumonia in children under five years of age. Globally, RSV is responsible for almost 4.1 million hospitalizations and ~60,000 in-hospital deaths annually with the majority of deaths occurring in infants less than three months of age. This work will define the mechanisms responsible for protective antibody responses to RSV, which are critical to the development of safer and more effective pediatric therapeutics and vaccines against RSV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Tuberculosis (TB) is the leading cause of death from infectious disease worldwide, but can be challenging to diagnose due to the poor performance of current diagnostic tests that require sputum or tissue biopsies that can be difficult to obtain in certain patient populations, including young children, and this situation has worsened due the reallocation of healthcare resources during the COVID-19 pandemic. We thus propose to employ a novel CRISPR-based paper strip point-of-care assay to detect and quantify Mycobacterium tuberculosis-derived cell- free DNA (Mtb-cfDNA) in blood to simplify sample collection for the diagnosis and treatment evaluation of drug- sensitive and -resistent TB cases. Based on our preliminary studies, we are confident that this assay will improve TB diagnosis in all patient populations, including the diagnosis of early disease in young children, and allow consistent evaluation of Mtb-cfDNA changes that should reflect the systemic effects of anti-TB treatment, both of which are required to improve TB control efforts in resource-limited areas with high endemic TB levels.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Tachycardia, or abnormally fast heart rate, is an independent risk factor for adverse cardiovascular events and it is known to induce or exacerbate heart failure. However, the mechanistic understanding of how increased heart rate leads to cardiac dysfunction is very limited. This proposal will capitalize on recent technological advances in stem cell biology, tissue engineering, and multi-omics to address this gap in our knowledge, thereby opening new opportunities for therapeutic interventions for relevant heart diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity is a rapidly expanding epidemic that is arguably the leading cause of cardiovascular disease. Being overweight or obese increases abnormal production of the hormone aldosterone by the adrenal glands, and too much aldosterone production causes damage to the heart resulting in heart disease. This study will evaluate whether blocking the effects of aldosterone in obese individuals using a commonly available blood pressure medication can serve as an effective way to prevent heart disease in this population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The pathogenesis of sepsis remains obscure, but is partly attributable to dys-regulated systemic inflammation propagated by “early” cytokines (e.g., TNF and IFN-γ), but sustained by “late” mediators such as high mobility group box 1 (HMGB1) and sequestosome-1 (SQSTM1). The elucidation of novel intricate mechanisms underlying the regulation of late-acting mediators will significantly improve our understanding of mechanisms underlying microbial infection-elicited dysregulated innate immune responses, and provide clues for the development of novel therapeutic strategies for the treatment of sepsis and other infectious diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Patients with respiratory infections are frequently found to have more than one virus, but the impact of viral co-infection remains poorly understood. This work will examine the interactions between respiratory syncytial virus and human metapneumovirus during infection of the same cell, particularly focusing on key steps in the viral life cycle. These studies will provide molecular insights that will also inform examination of other respiratory virus co-infection, and may lead to novel therapeutic targets and treatment options.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: Project Narrative  The NOURISH-OK Study will identify how food insecurity contributes to insulin resistance, an important surrogate marker of many co-morbidities in HIV disease, using an integrated framework to identify key leverage points for insulin resistance. Drawing from these pathways, this study will adapt and evaluate a community-driven, science-informed “food as medicine” intervention designed to lower insulin resistance through healthy food access, food utilization skills, and other self-care behaviors. Knowledge gained from this study can benefit those living with HIV through the prevention and more effective management of pre-diabetes, diabetes, obesity, and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sepsis remains a significant cause of mortality among critically ill patients. Optimal metabolic and nutritional management for septic patients remains controversial. Understanding the mechanisms behind the protective response of anorexia and associated fasting metabolism to bacterial-induced inflammation will provide critical insights on how best to provide metabolic and nutritional support during sepsis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Regulatory T cells are vital for preventing overactivation of the immune system that may lead to autoimmune diseases. This proposal is expected to increase our understanding of the molecular mechanisms that control regulatory T cell development and function. This research is relevant to public health because it lays the groundwork for developing innovative therapeutic strategies against autoimmune disorders and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Aging is a known risk factor for cancer and various diseases. It is widely accepted that the mechanical properties of aging tissues and cells are significantly different from young tissues, and altered tissue mechanics can contribute to cancer progression and development. In this study, I will test a hypothesis that aging skin tissue, exhibiting distinct mechanical/viscoelastic characteristics, promotes tumor progression of skin squamous carcinomas in elderly patients via p53- and ubiquitin pathways.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Patients with paroxysmal atrial fibrillation (intermittently disordered contraction of the top chambers of the heart) may experience maladaptive changes within the left atrium as a result of repeated episodes of the arrhythmia, impairing overall cardiac performance during exercise and predisposing patients to the development of heart failure. Catheter ablation is an important treatment option that can significantly reduce or even eliminate episodes of atrial fibrillation, but the degree to which it might alter left atrial performance during exercise is largely unexplored. This longitudinal study will leverage the precision of exercise-based cardiovascular magnetic resonance imaging in patients with paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, examining the effects of catheter ablation on left atrial function during exercise, its relationship to left ventricular function during exercise, and its contribution to overall exercise capacity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Project Narrative Ulcerative Colitis is a devastating life-long disease which poses a significant health and financial burden on patients and the healthcare system. This proposal aims to develop a group of microbes, which together dampen aberrant colonic inflammation and explore the specific signals and interactions of intestinal microbes that regulate intestinal neutrophil infiltration and thus inflammation. Upon completion of this project, we will better understand the specific pathways and interactions that maintain intestinal homeostasis, which can be leveraged to develop new bacteriotherapeutic approaches treat ulcerative colitis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative Performing comprehensive spatial distribution analysis of populations of messenger RNAs and proteins in neurons in tissue processed for expansion microscopy holds the promise of profound progress in next-generation basic and translational neuroscience studies such as investigating the effects of aging, understanding neurodevelopmental, neuropsychiatric, neurodegenerative and neurological disorders and diseases, and drug discovery. Our proposed product will be a transformative technology, using a number of technical innovations that, for the first time, will enable researchers to perform these data-rich studies without the need to have a computer scientist on staff to run the existing, lab-based software developed for this kind of complex analysis. This system will allow researchers to make new discoveries based on new studies that are currently not feasible, ultimately providing the basis for developing novel treatments to prevent and fight complex brain diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Pertussis toxin must enter a host cell in order to elicit an effect that contributes to whooping cough. This proposal will help define the cellular events and host proteins that facilitate the passage of pertussis toxin into the host cell. Disruption of this process would protect both the cell and the patient from the effects of pertussis toxin, so the knowledge gained from this proposal could be used to develop treatments for whooping cough.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The use of small animal models and clinical trials using medical imaging have led to improved diagnosis and treatment of human disease. The goal of this work is develop methods and resources for co-clinical trials using PET imaging, and to implement them in a co-clinical trial evaluating immunotherapy treatment for lung cancer. The methods and resources developed to improve the utility of early-phase oncology trials using co-clinical studies with PET imaging will be distributed to accelerate the development of needed effective cancer therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH STATEMENT The proposed research will examine whether a self-administered, web-based intervention designed to promote agency (in combination with or without teacher training to support motivation) can promote immediate and long-term motivation, engagement, achievement, and persistence in a large, diverse sample of college students enrolled in introductory classes required of biomedical science majors. This research has the potential to validate an intervention that could help to increase diversity in biomedical science and is a critical step toward creating a cost-and-time-efficient, scalable intervention to support student persistence in biomedical sciences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative For the brain to function it is essential that large numbers of neurons are interconnected in a highly precise manner, a process which is controlled by the patterns of genes expressed during brain development. Work of this grant focuses on a circuit of the Drosophila brain controlling navigation. We are analyzing connectivity within this circuit with digital connectomes, and use optogenetic tools to record and manipulate neuronal activity in order to develop concepts which are important to understand, and therapeutically manipulate, circuits formed by nerve cells in the human brain.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bilinguals showed remarkable language control abilities in both production and comprehension, but it remains unclear if and to what extent control mechanisms are shared or different across these modalities. The proposed project will adopt ERP measures to conduct a thorough and systematic comparison between them, and it will investigate how syntactic and phonological constraints influence in-context language control in the two modalities. This project will lead to a comprehensive understanding of language control, lay the groundwork to develop theory-driven approaches of the assessment of language and cognitive abilities in bilinguals, and may ultimately foster communication and language learning in an increasingly multilingual society.

PROJECT_TITLE: ERPs reveal the Mechanisms of Bilingual Language Control

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Type 1 Diabetes (T1D) is an autoimmune disease caused by autoreactive T-cell-mediated destruction of islet β cells. This project stems from our recent positive Phase 1 clinical trial results in which R-5280, a modified superior resistant starch, significantly mitigated T1D severity in adolescents. Here, we propose to perform a confirmatory Phase 2 clinical trial to corroborate R-5280 efficacy and safety. Successful commercialization would ultimately provide a profound front-line medical advancement for the treatment of T1D.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study addresses how a chaperone molecule called GRP94 controls cancer and determines the best strategy to target GRP94 for cancer immunotherapy. Significant discoveries have been made regarding the roles of GRP94 in controlling the pathway of transforming growth factor beta (TGFb). Several therapeutic leads have emerged in blocking the GRP94-TGFb pathway; further in-depth study of GRP94 will advance novel therapies for cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Osteoarthritis affects multiple tissues within a joint, causing severe inflammation and tissue degeneration, but current treatment options are inadequate in part due to rapid clearance of drugs injected into the joint and lack of tissue-targeted delivery. This project will modify a promising OA drug by making it positively charged, utilizing its interaction with negatively charged cartilage to enhance cartilage penetration and retention, thereby transforming cartilage from a barrier to drug entry into a drug depot that can enable sustained delivery to cartilage and neighboring joint tissues. The strategy developed through this work can enable clinical translation of a variety of osteoarthritis drugs that are currently limited due to a lack of effective delivery techniques.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The widespread misuse of prescription opioids, addiction, and overdose have underscored the need to better understand how, where, and when opioid receptors’ action alters behavior in various brain regions. Here we will develop novel optopharmacological and precisionmethods for understanding how mu-opioids, like fentanyl, morphine, and others mediate effects in the brain to alter brain function, inhibit pain, and alter motivation. This understanding and these new tools will aid in developing safe and effective medications for pain and opioid addiction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal follows up on our robust finding that valproic acid can upregulate Irg1, the tricarboxylic cycle enzyme producing itaconate, for cardioprotection of donor hearts for transplantation. We will determine how Irg1/itaconate mediates donor heart preservation by identifying the cell type where Irg1 is important, identify novel mechanisms by which itaconate modifies and regulates antioxidant proteins, and confirm its translational role in pig and human hearts. Results from this study will provide novel knowledge that can be directly applied to heart transplant patients to improve donor heart function and improve heart transplant outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The aim of the proposed research is to understand the interactions between cerebral small vessel disease and Alzheimer’s Disease related pathology in the medial temporal lobe, a brain region crucial for cognition and affected by the disease at early stages. The combined use of ultra-high resolution ex vivo MRI, corresponding histopathological serial sectioning, and deep-learning based quantitative measures of MRI and histology is promising to quantitatively and objectively identify these relationships, also inferring the role of potential mechanisms, such as blood-brain barrier leakage and clearance dysfunction. The results will enhance our understanding of the causal links between vascular and AD pathology and produce histologically validated neuroimaging markers of microvascular health of the medial temporal lobe, which could potentially be applied in vivo to monitor the effects of much needed disease-modifying interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: My group develops biosensor tools that enable the visualization of enzymatic processes inside living cells as they move. This is an important area of study in basic biology because it increases understanding about mechanisms that differentiate normal cells (e.g., immune cells) from diseased cells (e.g., tumor cells) as they move and migrate throughout the human body. I will develop molecular imaging tools that enable the simultaneous recording of two different enzymatic protein activities in living cells, which will then allow me to decode the coordination of multiple signaling proteins that regulates cell movement.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Efficient DNA replication at hard-to-replicate sites is facilitated by specialized DNA helicases. Furthermore, proper assembly and regulation of telomeres is essential to maintain chromosome stability in Eukaryotes. Our goal is to understand how these processes function and are regulated. Mutations in DNA helicases in humans and telomere de-regulation are associated with genome instability, a hallmark of several syndromes, cancer and ageing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Interhospital fragmentation of care is an understudied risk factor for poor patient outcomes, including increased mortality, higher costs, and increased healthcare waste. This study focuses on potential causes of and solutions to interhospital care fragmentation among older adults with Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias. Findings from this study will provide additional insight into the impact of interhospital care fragmentation in this population, and could provide novel approaches for directly reducing care fragmentation as well as mitigating the negative effects of fragmented readmissions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD) are now considered global diseases with fastest growing incidence among young patients diagnosed before 6 years of age. The pathophysiology of IBD remains incompletely understood involving the importance of the microbiome and more recently, the virome and available therapies remain ineffective in a large number of patients with IBD. This project will serve to better understand the mechanistic contribution of interferon lambdas (IFNλs) in maintaining intestinal homeostasis, preventing development of IBD and their therapeutic potential.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Lower respiratory infections are the leading infectious cause of death for children younger than five years of age in low-income and middle-income countries (LMICs) like South Africa. Innovations in the identification of severe pediatric respiratory diseases complicated by low oxyhemoglobin saturation levels (hypoxemia) that are suitable for use in rural communities of LMICs are urgently needed to reduce mortality. An affordable mobile phone-based reflectance pulse oximeter with electronic health diagnostic and surveillance capabilities that is also contextually appropriate for LMICs offers an exciting potential for improving outcomes for severe pediatric lower respiratory infections.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Healthcare workers’ (HCWs’) willingness to report to work during pandemics and other public health emergencies and disasters is a foundational prerequisite for national, regional and global health security in the face of an ever-broadening array of emergent population-health threats. Well-documented case reports point to concerning gaps in public health emergency and disaster response willingness, including among low- and middle- income country (LMIC)-based HCWs, and research to date in LMICs and other settings has highlighted HCWs’ self-efficacy as leading predictor of their willingness to respond in these types of events. The purpose of this two-part study is to develop, measure the effectiveness of, and refine a novel mHealth intervention using an evidence-informed approach for building self-efficacy and enhancing response willingness among LMIC-based emergency department HCWs in public health emergencies and disasters.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neurodegeneration, particularly of the basal forebrain, is strongly associated with both cognitive and sensory deficits. Through this research we will develop a mechanistic understanding of how basal forebrain circuits mediate downstream effects on sensory processing, potentially revealing common mechanisms that underlie sensory and cognitive deficits in disease. Revealing these mechanisms will improve our understanding of circuit defects in neurodegenerative disease and may lead to novel, targeted therapies for treating dementia and sensory deficits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Volatile anesthetics induce all stages of general anesthesia including unconsciousness, amnesia, analgesia and muscle relaxation, but we have no satisfactory answer as to how this occurs physiologically. Using novel fluorescent microscopy in C.elegans, we are now able to image neuronal activity in real-time, in vivo, and at resolutions capable of capturing the activity of individual neurons and entire populations of complex neuronal networks simultaneously. Our experimental system, and its progressive extension into higher-order animals, will allow us to measure the activity of the individual identifiable neurons within large-scale neuronal circuits to understand how subtle modifications in discrete neuronal dynamics lead to the gross but reversible functional defects at the level of the overall nervous system that produce the clinical state of anesthesia in both simple creatures and humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol use disorder is a destructive mental disorder that impacts nearly 15 million American adults, but many key risk factors point to developmental perturbations as important contributors to disease. My preliminary data point to a critical developmental role of microglia, the brain’s innate immune cells, and their impact on maturing parvalbumin GABAergic interneurons, in increased voluntary alcohol consumption in adulthood. This proposed study will answer both basic neurodevelopmental questions about microglial sculpting of inhibitory maturation in the frontal cortex and seek to identify a mechanism through which developmental microglial signaling changes influence excessive drinking behavior to improve our understanding of alcohol use disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative:  Recent evidence indicates that sensorimotor changes may precede the onset of AD dementia by up to 10 years. Hearing is an important sense, and compared with other sensory systems, auditory system has the advantage that decline in function over time can easily be quantitatively measured by electrophysiological recordings. In this project, we will assess AD-induced functional and pathological changes in the auditory system and identify the impact of hearing loss on AD and dementia development and progression to identify and characterize early, sensitive, and non-invasive AD biomarkers, which can be expected to have great impact on the early detection and diagnosis of AD and also are desperately needed for prevention and therapeutic interventions of AD/ADRD.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Maintaining a healthy breast microenvironment that supports optimal lactation, as well as the ideal nutrient composition, is important for the growth and development of the human-milk-fed infant. Subclinical mastitis (SCM), an asymptomatic inflammation of mammary tissue during lactation, has been linked with low milk supply, reduced nutritional composition and reduced microbial diversity, yet the prevalence of SCM in the US is unknown. We propose to fill this significant gap by following temporal changes in milk in two lactating US populations to determine the prevalence, as well as the impact on milk composition and infant health, as it relates to the occurrence and severity of SCM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The mortality of the Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) increases significantly with age, an epidemiological trend vehemently underscored by the COVID-19 pandemic. Inflammation and senescence are established aging related processes which may mechanistically contribute to the poor clinical outcomes seen in older adults with ARDS. This proposal will test the relationships between age (biological and chronological), inflammation, and clinical outcomes in ARDS while beginning to define a novel senescent phenotype of ARDS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – Overall The Center for Chronic Disease Reduction and Equity Promotion Across Minnesota (C2DREAM) will reduce disparities in cardiovascular disease (CVD) and the related chronic conditions (RCC) of hypertension and obesity experienced by Black, Indigenous, and people of color (BIPOC) communities including immigrants and refugees across Minnesota. C2DREAM will promote innovative, multilevel interventions that target fundamental causes of chronic disease inequities among BIPOC communities; generate knowledge, analytical and implementation approaches, and community engagement strategies to understand and develop solutions to address racism at multiple levels; develop and support the next generation of health equity researchers; create and sustain a community-engaged and equity-guided dissemination and implementation processes to translate research results and knowledge into action; and employ equity-guided evaluation approaches. Our regional partnership of academic institutions and community stakeholders is poised to understand and ultimately address the ways that racism undermines the well-being of BIPOC communities across Minnesota.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Widely expressed on acute myeloid leukemia (AML) cells, CD33 is of great interest as a therapeutic target for this highly aggressive blood cancer, but current CD33-directed drugs are often ineffective. Using newly raised CD33-binding antibodies, the Walter Lab plans to optimize the efficacy and safety of CD33-targeted therapy, focusing efforts on the delivery of highly potent radioisotopes, a treatment approach called radioimmunotherapy. Dr. George S. Laszlo, PhD, the Research Specialist in the Walter Lab since 2010, has developed all experimental methodologies, approaches, assays, and tools/reagents that build the foundation for this research and will lead studies over the next 5 years that have the explicit goal of bringing new therapy options to patients with AML.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The purpose of this project is to study and promote brain activity patterns that support healthy memory function in healthy aging and in people at elevated risk for Alzheimer’s disease. We will use non-invasive brain stimulation to promote optimal activity patterns and to enhance memory function in healthy older adults and those with mild cognitive impairment. Successful completion of the proposed work has the potential to enhance the efficacy of brain stimulation for treating cognitive disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Children who belong to racial, ethnic, and language minority groups are more likely to die of emergency conditions and, during emergency department visits, are less likely to receive interventions such as antibiotics and pain medication. Such differences in care and outcomes are due, at least in part, to implicit racial bias, yet educational interventions that increase physician awareness of implicit bias are not sufficient to reduce disparities in patient-centered outcomes. This proposal aims to define how implicit bias affects physician behavior in the pediatric emergency department and create a critical foundation for prioritizing behavior change in future bias-reduction intervention research.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative Although genetic disorders and birth defects (which may also be genetic) are the leading cause of infant mortality in the United States, many infants die without a confirmed genetic diagnosis, and this limits our ability to fully understand the genomic landscape of infant mortality in order to provide optimal care and to develop approaches to prevent these deaths. This project presents a plan to identify genetic disorders in infants who die to learn more about which genetic conditions are responsible for infant mortality and to evaluate the importance of this information for the infant's family. What we learn from this research will inform the clinical evaluation and management of these tragic losses and will suggest strategies for their prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative The central nervous system is readily infected by HIV upon systemic infection but represents a separate compartment which only select antiretroviral drugs penetrate, and in which virus evolves independently from the remainder of the body. It also appears that infected cells in the brain contribute to the durable viral reservoir under antiretroviral therapy yet investigating viral dynamics in the brain is almost impossible. Using a macaque model of simian immunodeficiency virus (SIV) that leads to neurological symptoms, we propose to develop new strategies to image SIV in the brain, in real-time, to monitor viral reservoir seeding, persistence and reactivation upon antiretroviral therapy interruption, paving the way for new interventions to minimize neurological damage due to HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative The unprecedented global pandemic has highlighted the digital divide and limited access to alcohol-related treatments among marginalized communities, specifically individuals with lived experience of homelessness. In line with the NIAAA health initiative seeking to integrate technology-based interventions among vulnerable populations, this study directly addresses this mission by proposing innovative methods (i.e., user-centered design + a community based participatory research framework) to adapt an in-person harm reduction for alcohol (HaRT-A) intervention into a telehealth platform (eHaRT-A) that can then be tested and successfully implemented into low-barrier Housing First settings. As healthcare continues to move more services online, it is essential to understand ways to successfully adapt and implement rigorously tested telehealth treatment services for marginalized communities to ameliorate alcohol-related harms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Impaired relaxation of the heart, termed diastolic dysfunction, is a severe condition leading to significant morbidity and mortality with limited options for treatment. Restrictive Cardiomyopathy is a cardiac disease with particularly severe diastolic dysfunction and poor outcomes, for which there are no specific treatments because the underlying mechanisms are poorly understood. In this proposal, I use novel stem-cell models of Restrictive Cardiomyopathy and large-scale functional genomics analyses to define pathogenic mechanisms that will inform the design of therapeutics for this deadly disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Sickle cell disease is associated with inflammation that promotes vaso-occlusive episodes and eventually organ damage. Our recent studies have revealed important functions of the microbiota and sensory nerves in regulating these manifestations. This proposal will shed light on the mechanistic contributions of aged neutrophils, the specific bacterial strains that protect or promote the disease, and their interplay with nerve-derived signals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative The project will develop an innovative magnetic imaging modality for brain magnetoencephalography (MEG) based on the quantum mechanical tunneling of spin-polarized electrons in a magnetic tunneling junction (MTJ). MTJ sensors are the most sensitive room-temperature solid-state magnetic sensors with a large magnetic field dynamic range. Our MTJ-MEG system can become deployed for real-world applications without a magnetically shielded room and specialized nulling coils.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  Neurons in the brain wire together to form circuits that perform the computations necessary for learning, cognition, and behavior. But the brain is composed of thousands of unique cell types that differ in the sets of genes that they each express. We propose to develop a more efficient method to study how these unique cell types connect into neural circuits by employing state-of-the-art tools for visualizing both neuronal activity and genetic identity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Naphthalenones are bicyclic scaffolds found in many natural and synthetic compounds which display a diverse range of biological activities including anti-viral, anti-bacterial, and anti-fungal properties. Through protein engi- neering and directed evolution, I propose to generate enzymes capable of catalyzing dearomatization of planar naphthols into three-dimensional naphthalenone scaffolds via nitrene or carbene insertions. This work will open new avenues of enzyme catalyzed nitrene or carbene chemistries, as well as provide a facile and sustainable method for transforming readily available aromatic feedstocks into intricate pharmacophores.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Trametinib is a targeted cancer therapy that prolongs life in patients with melanoma and is being actively studied in clinical trials for numerous other common malignancies. Trametinib is associated with potentially severe heart injury and heart failure, though the mechanism of that cardiotoxicity is presently unknown. In this proposal we seek to expand upon our recent novel findings that trametinib compromises the ability of heart muscle cells to generate energy and leads to inflammation, potentially important reactions in both the heart and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative The proposed etiologic research utilizes data collected from a longitudinal cohort of U.S. women and men across the past 30 years, as well as newly collected data. This research examines four interrelated pathways by which psychosocial and socioeconomic stressors may lead to poorer bladder health (lower urinary tract symptoms [LUTS] and impact of symptoms): affective, cognitive, behavioral, and physiological pathways. With the ability to analyze stressors across the life course, this novel research has the potential to inform “upstream” approaches to prevent LUTS and promote bladder health (e.g., amelioration of specific stressors shown to serve as risk factors, enhancement of social support and ties shown to serve as a protective factors), as well as “downstream” prevention and treatment approaches (e.g., treatment of depressive symptoms; cognitive training exercises; weight loss; behavior modification, including pelvic floor exercises).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Recent studies show that if preventative dose anticoagulation is provided to outpatients with cancer at high risk for clotting, it reduces the risk of cancer associated thrombosis, which is the leading non-cancer cause of death among this population. While guidelines suggest offering this potentially lifesaving therapy to high-risk patients with an acceptable bleeding risk, it is not routinely done. This study will identify strategies to improve the appropriate use of preventative anticoagulation for patients with cancer in diverse settings and pilot test an intervention to improve the quality of care patients with cancer receive.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Whether attending to the road while driving or trying to find your keys on a cluttered desk, our ability to select relevant information and ignore irrelevant and distracting information is critical for survival. This proposal aims to identify what attentional processes best support the effective ignoring of distractors by comparing experience- based attentional suppression to volitional suppression of irrelevant and distracting information. The results of this proposal will help uncover how variations in the ability to ignore distractions give rise to common cognitive disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mitochondria provide cells with crucial metabolites, and they are hubs in signaling networks that control cell survival or the response to viral attack. To prevent mitochondrial decline and associated diseases, such as cancer or neurodegeneration, cells possess conserved stress responses that detect and either repair or degrade defective mitochondria. This proposal will dissect the function and regulation of the conserved reductive stress response, which senses a deleterious depletion of beneficial reactive oxygen species and in turn activates the electron transport chain. Our work will reveal principles of mitochondrial signaling and lay the foundation for innovative treatments that use mitochondrial activation to combat neurodegenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  It is estimated that the majority of severe head injuries in children under age 2 are due to abuse. Hemispheric hypodensity is a striking pattern of brain damage often resulting from inflicted trauma where tissue damage evolves over hours or days and for which there is no treatment. Understanding the pathophysiology of this severe injury will identify potential therapeutic targets that may result in therapies that reduce the burden of disability and mortality for victims of abusive head trauma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative.………………………………………………………………………………………………. Metastasis remains to be the leading cause of cancer death worldwide including metastatic prostate cancer, which poses poor prognosis for patients diagnosed with it. Understanding how cancer intrinsic signaling, metastatic tissue biological players, and aging contribute to dormancy and reawakening is paramount to improving treatment strategies to control metastasis and extend patients overall survival rates. This research proposal will identify intrinsic and extrinsic regulators of skeletal prostate cancer dormancy in the context of aging to provide a better understanding of skeletal metastasis initiation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Sleep selectively prioritizes information that is emotional, rewarded, and important for future use. Disruption of this prioritization process may underlie psychological disorders such as depression, anxiety, and post- traumatic stress disorder, and may be especially exacerbated by sleep disruption. The proposed research will further our understanding of how sleep selectively prioritizes important information, examining its neural mechanisms and generalization across the cognitive domains of emotional memory and problem solving.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: NARRATIVE Emerging evidence suggests that infants with greater appetitive drive may benefit from different feeding approaches for the prevention of obesity and chronic disease, including slowing the rate of milk intake and improving satiation signaling. The proposed project will, through a mentored training phase, examine infant and mother behavior, as well as their dyadic interaction during feedings with slower milk delivery, compared with faster milk delivery. This will be followed by an independent study to examine how these behaviors develop across multiple feedings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The opioid crisis has exponentially harmed Black Americans in the United States in recent years and this population continues to face significant barriers in access to appropriate treatment for opioid use disorder (OUD) and commonly occurring mental disorders (COMD). Recently the US Department of Health and Human Services’ Overdose Prevention Strategy acknowledged the importance of addressing the opioid overdose crisis through evidence-based treatment and recovery support - two essential elements of this proposal. This study aims to adapt and test the preliminary efficacy of a mobile Health intervention specifically tailored for Black Americans with OUD plus COMD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To reduce disparities in breast cancer survival, there is an urgent need to develop optimal screening strategies for the early detection of aggressive, young onset breast cancers among women at high risk for breast cancer based on inherited risk factors and genetic ancestry. Within the Chicago Alternative Prevention Study for BReast CAncer in Diverse Populations of High-Risk Women (CAPSBRACA), we will refine and expand on our biannual MRI protocol such that it is efficient, feasible and sustainable even in under resourced communities. Through a pragmatic study design, we will improve long-term adherence to screening in young women and establish a longitudinal cohort of high risk women undergoing intensive surveillance for future cancer interception clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Portable, low-field MRI has the exciting potential to dramatically increase the accessibility of MRI for bed-side imaging and use in low-resource settings. However, the most significant limitation of these low-field scanners is the inferior image quality that arises from the lower MR signal amplitude. Our aim is to offset this limitation with novel, stretchable receiver coils that will adapt to the subject to maximize the receiver sensitivity, with the ultimate goal of improving portable MRI image quality and clinical utility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) can induce bladder outlet obstruction (BOO) with associated lower urinary tract symptoms that can interfere with the quality of life and are often difficult to treat. This R01 research will include in vivo and in vitro studies of BOO in a rat model that will provide scientific insights into BOO while also driving the development of a digital twin of the rat bladder that will be used to design and evaluate combined surgical/pharmacological treatments. The successful completion of this work will also provide a translational foundation for developing digital twins for BOO patients that ultimately will enable more effective and patient tailored treatments to avoid the debilitating side effects of BOO.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE HEALTH SCI CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Constipation is one of the most prevalent gastrointestinal disorders in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) and has been associated with their adverse kidney and cardiovascular outcomes; however, little is known about the effects of constipation treatment on clinical outcomes nor on outcome-related biochemical and microbiological parameters in patients with CKD. We aim to test the feasibility of delivering an intervention with constipation treatment and determine its effects on changes in clinical, biochemical, and microbiological parameters in patients with CKD and constipation. The findings of our proposed study will be an important step toward a larger clinical trial to verify the effectiveness of constipation treatment as a novel gut-targeted strategy in the management of CKD, potentially contributing to better clinical outcomes in patients with CKD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Mosquitoes spread pathogens to humans through their behavior of blood feeding and identifying and understanding the neurons that control this behavior would enable new strategies to prevent it. Here, I describe an approach using genomics, transgenic mosquitoes, and behavior studies to identify the neurons that are required for mosquitoes to seek out and bite humans. The identification and genetic targeting of these neurons will create a way to understand what causes the attraction of mosquitoes and open new avenues for its prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative:  The mechanism by which DNA replication completes is essential to genome stability, and is a driver of metastasis when mutated in cancers. We have identified genes that are synthetic lethal for bacteria mutated in completing replication. Therefore, extending these results to characterize the mechanism by which DNA replication completes in eukaryotes will likely to identify novel genes that can be targeted for cancer therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: This proposal, centered on AgRP hunger neurons, investigates circadian control of AgRP neurons and hunger (Aim 1), reciprocal interactions between AgRP neurons and the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal glucocorticoid (HPA) axis (Aim 2), and finally regulatory links between circadian control of AgRP neurons and the HPA axis. These studies will determine the mechanism by which eating is prompted to occur at the optimal time of day, how the stress hormone, corticosterone, activates AgRP neurons and if this is responsible for metabolic disease associated with Cushing’s syndrome and chronic stress, and finally how fasting causes adaptive activation of the HPA axis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because our ability to diagnose and treat neurodegenerative disorders is critically dependent on fundamental understanding of cellular and molecular mechanisms of neurodegeneration in vivo. In an intact brain, neurodegeneration likely involves both intrinsic and extrinsic mechanisms. Research described in this proposal will uncover new and potentially evolutionarily conserved mechanisms governing these processes. If successful, it will have a positive impact on informing the understanding and treatment of neurodegenerative disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The focus of this R35 renewal application is the continuation of our dedicated research on the role of the mutations of chromatin and chromatin’s modifying machineries in human malignancies, specifically COMPASS and BAP1. These epigenetic factors have been categorically demonstrated to be involved in different forms of cancer, and therefore, the study of their molecular function is critical to the development of targeted therapeutics of these cancers. The funding from this R35 will secure the translational path bringing the treatments under study to the clinic which will have a direct and positive outcome on improving the patients’ prognoses and outcomes.
