IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: The goal of the HIV and Alcohol Research center focused on Polypharmacy (HARP) is to design and implement effective personalized treatments for people aging with HIV who are harmed by unhealthy alcohol use and polypharmacy. We will: 1) develop summary estimates of personal health risk based on alcohol and medication exposures and on genetics; 2) pilot risk messages as part of a larger behavioral intervention; 3)use “big data” approaches to identify medications in the context of polypharmacy that might be repurposed to treat alcohol use disorder or prevent alcohol associated liver disease; and 4) pilot the use of these medications in people aging with HIV with Alcohol Use Disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Human B cells actively recombine and mutate their DNA in a controlled fashion to generate a diverse pool of antibodies to defend our bodies from the numerous harmful pathogens we encounter, while the same mutation mechanism can cause lymphoma cancer when it goes awry. Previous evidence suggests that DNA folding and nuclear organization may regulate the mutation mechanism, but how the DNA organization varies between different B cell states in human tissue and between normal and cancer cells are largely unknown. Here we use our new imaging technology to address these important questions of B cell development and lymphoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The iPACES is an interactive Physical and Cognitive Exercise System, innovated to make engaging and effective exercise, affordable and portable for in-home use by patients with neurological conditions at risk for cognitive challenges, in this case tailored for those with Parkinson’s Disease, many of whom are motivated to be proactive in preserving brain health in the fight against cognitive decline toward dementia. Pilot studies of iPACES found significant benefits after just three months of in-home pedaling with an under-desk pedaler that controlled progress down a virtual bike path in a tablet-based videogame that challenges memory for tagging neighborhood errands or tourist destinations. If prior promising findings of cognitive benefit are confirmed in the proposed multi-site clinical trial with Parkinson’s, then we would aim to make this novel neuro-exergame, more widely available to patients, families and health care providers, to add one more tool to curb cognitive decline, preserve brain health and deter dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Electronic health record (EHR) data holds immense potential for the study and care of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRDs) through the development of clinical tools and the study of disease heterogeneity and current care practices. However, selection bias, measurement error, and missing data can all lead to bias in EHR-based studies and tools, especially among patients who face barriers to healthcare access. The proposed training and research plan would lead to EHR analysis methods for ADRDs that address these sources of bias and would provide Dr. Adams with the unique combination of advance computational skills and understanding of ADRD care necessary to make significant contributions to the ADRD precision medicine in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To develop (or regenerate) a complex organ such as a limb, tissues must be able to interpret (or remember) their relative positions, then deploy this positional information to inform appropriate size, pattern and shape. This research program will use the regenerating zebraﬁsh ﬁn to reveal pathways that underlie the morphogenesis of form, focusing not only on the growth and size of the organ, but also the skeletal patterning along the proximodistal axis and the overall shape of the appendage. This research program is expected to inform the logic of fundamental developmental mechanisms, which can open new possibilities in treating congenital limb disorders and help pave the way towards regenerative therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Study of Healthy Aging in African Americans (STAR) is a Black/African American cohort of 764 middle-aged and elderly individuals ages examining lifecourse risk factors on cognitive decline and vascular brain injury. In STAR Cycle 2 study outcomes will include incidence of Alzheimer's disease and dementia, blood-based and imaging biomarkers of neurodegeneration, and neuropathology. The proposed continuation of STAR will help redress disparities in cognitive ageing, and provide much needed public health information on lifecourse risk and resiliency factors for Alzheimer's disease in a population at highest risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Cognitive effort avoidance can undermine planning and decision-making, especially in amotivational disorders like schizophrenia and depression. This project will test a promising hypothesis about what the brain treats as costly during task engagement. Understanding what the brain treats as costly will lay the foundation for future work on the nature of subjective effort, and suggest target mechanisms for promoting desirable cognitive effort.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Germ cells must maintain their identity for the entirety of a species' reproductive lifespan, a task that can last up to forty years in humans. This unique challenge raises the question: What underlying molecular processes govern germ cell identity and prevent reprogramming toward a somatic cell fate? A multiplex approach proposes to answer this question by (i) identifying factors that are instructive for the germline genetic program, (ii) uncovering how the translational repressor Nanos protects germ cell fate and prevents germline to soma transformation, and (III) addressing the role of small RNAs in germ fate specification and genome protection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed work will reveal the basic molecular mechanisms that govern ribosome biogenesis and how they contribute to ribosome heterogeneity. Our work will demonstrate how ribosome production is regulated by cellular signaling pathways and how this alters ribosome composition and functionality. Since ribosome biogenesis is misregulated in several disease contexts, a clear understanding of these pathways is essential for the development of targeted therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed randomized, double-blind Phase N/A clinical device trial seeks to investigate whether we can improve learning and memory by increasing activity in a part of the brain known to be related to memory by using a non-invasive ultrasound device. All participant will have either a confirmed diagnosis of amnestic mild cognitive impairment, a transition diagnosis between healthy aging and Alzheimer’s disease (AD), or be demographically- well-matched healthy aging controls. Through the integration of multimodal neuroimaging and experimental neuropsychological tasks, we aim to demonstrate that LIFUP can (A) successfully target and increase activity in the targeted memory area and other parts of the brain it is functionally connected to (B) improve connectivity of these memory networks (C) improve morphology of these memory networks (d) improve memory for information (e) determine the effect of different doses and a booster session on the effect of ultrasound on the brain and memory and (f) determine the relationship between blood-based AD biomarkers and LIFUP treatment outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project narrative The applicant successfully screened large compound libraries for their ability to delay Alzheimer pathology in C. elegans as a model for proteotoxicity in aging, and for their ability to reduce inflammation in microglial cells, implicated in physiopathology of neurodegenerative diseases. She subsequently carried out a pilot feasibility study with Medicare data to validate the results in humans and proposes to expand those results using Medicare data to assess whether the identified protective FDA-approved drugs lower the risk of Alzheimer’s disease and related diseases (ADRD) in humans with a pharmacoepidemiologic approach. The GEMSSTAR award will allow the applicant to increase and improve her knowledge of pharmacoepidemiology with the help of world class specialists in epidemiology, aging and geriatrics at the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai, helping bridge the gap, thanks to the results of this project, between aging biology and future clinical trials for repurposed drugs in older adults.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE At present, very little information exists on protein abundance, localization, and activity of transporters in human placenta, the developing gut, and the developing brain during pregnancy and after birth. We propose a comprehensive approach to address this significant knowledge gap. Such studies are important for a deeper understanding of transporter-mediated disposition and distribution of nutrients, xenobiotics, and dietary supplement constituents in the developing fetus and neonate/infant that impact early development and efficacy of nutrients, toxicity and efficacy of therapeutics or dietary supplements, in these vulnerable populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Overall Component: Project Narrative Advances in medical sciences led to the elucidation of infectious disease mechanisms and clinical translation of potent vaccines and therapies to reduce the death burden from common infections such as polio, meningococcus, and many others that are now almost forgotten in the US because of these successes. Today, in the early 21st century, we are building on the remarkable advances in our mechanistic understanding of the genomic architecture of cancer and its predisposition. The CAP-IT CRI will focus on recent rapid advances in RNA vaccine technology, cancer immune prevention, and interception vaccines that have the potential to substantially reduce the cancer burden in the 21st century.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our vision is to develop the first safe, real-time and high resolution system for mapping electricity in the human brain. Transcranial Acoustoelectric Brain Imaging (tABI) would transform our understanding of normal brain function and help diagnose, monitor, and treat a wide variety of neurologic, psychiatric, and behavioral disorders. This collaborative project will assemble a world-class multidisciplinary team to overcome major challenges with detecting weak signals in the brain to deliver a revolutionary and mobile imaging tool for human neuroscience and beyond.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Wildfire episodes are increasing in frequency and intensity due to climate change. The proposed work seeks to fill a surprising knowledge gap: cardiovascular risks following wildfire smoke inhalation. Results from this work can be used to determine biomarkers associated with cardiovascular risk, guide emergency medical management, and inform policy decisions surrounding wildfire smoke exposure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Modified Public Health Relevance Section  There is a critical unmet need for a disease-modifying drug for Alzheimer’s disease (AD); of the ten leading causes of death in the United States, only AD cannot be prevented, slowed or cured and is increasing in incidence. This program is highly important because it is designed to fill this need with a disease-modifying drug that, if successful, will have a tremendous impact on the more than 6.5 million Americans who currently have AD (projected to be 12.7 million by 2050) and their caregivers, and will also help reduce the current cost of $321 billion (projected to be $1.1 trillion by 2050) to our nation (Alzheimer's Association 2022 Alzheimer's Disease Facts and Figures). This R44 Phase IIb application is to demonstrate toxicity limiting dosing in animals to enable dosing at sufficient levels to be safe and effective in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Principal Investigator: Schlissel, Gavin Project Narrative Animal development and health require accurate cell-cell communication, which relies on diffusible signaling proteins that travel from sender to receiver cells. Communication through signaling proteins can be regulated by tuning the ability of a signaling protein to diffuse from a sender to a receiver cell, although this mode of signaling regulation is under-explored. Here I will use biophysical and synthetic biology tools to understand how signaling proteins travel from their source to their destination, and to probe how tissue-specific or organism-specific variation in the extracellular matrix contribute to accurate signal propagation. K99/R00 Fellowship Application October 2022

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Preventing chronic post-surgical pain is a public health priority. The purpose of this proposal is to identify a risk phenotype comprised of biologic, psychologic, and social factors for total shoulder arthroplasty. This risk phenotype will be used to predict chronic post-surgical pain so that novel risk stratification and treatment strategies can be developed and tested for this patient population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Current therapies to treat adverse cardiac remodeling after myocardial infarction (MI) are limited, and novel therapeutic targets are needed. Macrophage-mediated inflammation plays a critical role in normal cardiac remodeling and healing, but excessive inflammation as observed in patients with diabetes mellitus promotes adverse remodeling and development of heart failure. This proposal will test whether macrophage metabolism of lactate and ketones limits macrophage-mediated inflammation in healthy and diabetic mice and may provide new therapeutic strategies for treating MI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative  Consumption of a Western diet, characterized by foods that are high in saturated fat and refined carbohydrates, is contributing to the increased global prevalence of obesity. A growing body of research indicates that Western diet consumption, particularly when consumed during early life periods of development, is also causally related to memory deficits and other neurocognitive impairments independent of obesity. This proposal is designed to identify the critical developmental periods as well as the neurobiological mechanisms by which early life Western diet consumption imparts long-lasting neurocognitive dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The next frontier in cancer research is early detection and prevention, and my overarching goal is to apply this to myeloma by defining the first steps of disease development and treating it early before symptoms occur. We will redefine the risk factors of race and chronological age based on underlying biological traits. We will identify ancestry risk scores and genomic signatures that increase the risk of developing myeloma in Black individuals and dissect the molecular mechanisms of “effective age” of the tissue of origin (bone marrow).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Congenital heart defects (CHD) are responsible for $6.1 billion dollars in annual healthcare costs, primarily due to acquired cardiovascular complications. Prevention of tobacco use (e.g., e-cigarettes [“vaping”], combustible cigarettes) is critical for the long-term wellbeing of adolescents with CHD, but there are no interventions to prevent vaping among this vulnerable group. This research will adapt and evaluate the first vaping prevention intervention tailored to adolescents with CHD, which may ultimately contribute to enhanced health and wellbeing for CHD survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Familial hypercholesterolemia (FH) is an important contributor to clinical severe hypercholesterolemia and subsequent coronary artery disease (CAD). While discoveries of key causal genes (PCSK9, APOB, and LDLR) have enabled us to molecularly diagnose individuals with FH and provide preemptive treatment to prevent CAD, the yield of genetic diagnosis is still limited. This proposal aims to extend our knowledge of the causal genes and variants for FH to improve the prevention and management of CAD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: 220.8 PROJECT NARRATIVE Latino men who have sex with men (LMSM) face one of the largest disparities in new HIV diagnoses nationally, likely because they face intersectional stigma towards their ethnic, sexual, and gender identities (i.e. adherence to masculinity norms) which negatively affects both methamphetamine use and PrEP cascade progression. Social network analysis employing longitudinal multilevel structural equation modeling is an innovative method for studying how intersectional stigma is experienced by members of LMSM’s social network and can differentiate between which network members and under what social contexts stigma reduction interventions could decrease methamphetamine use risk and improve PrEP cascade progression to reduce HIV incidence. Through this K01, Dr. Algarin will leverage the UCSD training infrastructure to build his professional independence and skills for promoting HIV prevention in medically marginalized groups, positioning him as a leader among the next generation of under-represented minority scholars to end the HIV epidemic among MSM of color disproportionately burdened by HIV in the US.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Estrogen deficiency and old age are the two most important factors for bone loss and the development of osteoporosis in both women and men, but the mechanisms responsible for this effect remain unclear. The aim of the work proposed in this application is to uncover the underlying mechanisms and this will be accomplished by studying a mitochondrial deacetylase Sirt3 and its downstream effectors in osteoclasts. Knowledge gained with these studies may prove useful for the development of therapies that can treat osteoporosis.

PHR: Project Narrative This multi-method project examines developmental differences in the prevalence and mechanisms of alcohol use among adolescents with diverse sexual orientations and gender identities. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Most Alzheimer’s disease (AD) risk genes, including the R47H mutation of the Trem2 receptor and the APOE4 allele, are found in microglia, pointing to a causal role for microglia in neurodegeneration. This study examines the interactions between risk factors R47H and APOE4 to elucidate the microglial Trem2-APOE pathway’s effects on cellular metabolism and inflammation and to evaluate the mechanistic role of AKT in this pathway. Better understanding the Trem2-APOE pathway will expose mechanisms of microglia-driven neurodegeneration in AD and identify new therapeutic targets for its treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative African American (AA) women who are young (less than age 45) are more likely to develop breast cancer, report poorer quality of life (QOL), and face negative social determinants of health (e.g., low socioeconomic status, limited access to care, discrimination) than young White women. This two-arm study will evaluate feasibility, acceptability, and preliminary outcomes of Y-AMBIENT (a targeted and telephone-based QOL intervention for young African American survivors of stage I-III breast cancer) vs. an enhanced usual care control (scripted socialization). Findings will inform a randomized controlled trial to test intervention efficacy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative We previously established the detailed molecular mechanisms by which the lipid-modified Hedgehog protein signal is exported by producing cells and by which the signal is sensed and transmitted to the interior of other target cells. Here we propose to determine how these activities are powered by metal cation gradients, how the exported Hedgehog signal is packaged, and how its tissue-level activity is inhibited by a disease-associated sponge-like binding protein, Hhip (Hedgehog interacting protein). Our results are expected to provide a basis for new approaches to modulating Hh pathway activity for therapeutic purposes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The objective of this proposal is to understand the role of the tumor suppressor protein p53 in aiding cell fate transitions including cancer. As p53 mutants dominate the mutational landscape of cancer, it is important to understand what functions of normal p53 are co-opted and enhanced by mutants to promote cell fate transitions in order to establish effective therapies that target cells harboring these oncogenes. By studying the role of p53 and p53 mutants during transitions, this work will shed light on early-stage cancers, aiding early- detection of the disease and improving patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: 8. Project Narrative. Changing sedentary lifestyles, and sustaining change, has huge potential benefits to cardiovascular health and well-being; yet it is notoriously difficult. The current proposal tests whether a sustainable first step towards change in a highly sedentary, high-risk population is teaching behavior change techniques within a socially supportive peer-coaching group, with the goal of interrupting prolonged sitting with short, 2-4 minute bouts of moderate physical activity (exercise snacks). The intervention platform is low-cost, highly scalable, accessible, and socially supported, and teaches evidence-based behavior change techniques to empower people with the tools to make and sustain change.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH This project introduces and investigates the scientific premise that age-related reductions in walking performance and economy have been mistakenly attributed solely to muscles spanning the ankle, and instead originate interdependently with unfavorable changes in the active, passive, and structural regulation of foot stiffness and power. Accordingly, the translational purpose of this proposal is to test the efficacy of shoe stiffness modifications to augment foot structure and function in aging and thereby improve gait performance and reduce metabolic energy cost during walking in older adults. Ultimately, this project addresses the need for new and modifiable targets to enhance mobility and independence – paving the way for feasible and cost-effective assistive devices for millions in our aging population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Emerging adults have higher rates of binge drinking, thoughts of suicide, and suicide attempts than any other age group, but very low use of substance use treatment. This project seeks to develop a mobile health intervention guided by an avatar for emerging adults who visit the emergency department and who binge drink and experience thoughts of suicide. Because emerging adults prefer mobile health and self-guided interventions and such technology is widely accessible, the proposed mobile health intervention could offer significant public health benefit in reducing alcohol use disorders and suicidal thoughts in emerging adults.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human papillomavirus (HPV) related oropharyngeal cancer (OPC) is increasing in incidence globally, and is disproportionately higher among people living with HIV (PLWH). Unlike cervical and anal cancers caused by HPV, no screening tests are available for OPC. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Studies from the recent Zaire Ebola virus (EBOV) outbreaks in both Guinea and the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) suggest that the FDA-approved EBOV vaccine can be highly effective. However, emerging data reveal EBOV vaccine failure rates as high as 30% in the DRC, a region of the world where malaria is endemic. Here, we use experimental malaria and Ebola virus infection systems to elucidate the mechanisms by which malaria alters the efficacy of Ebola virus vaccination.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: NARRATIVE Disconnection and physiological dysfunction of interconnected association regions of the cerebral cortex that regulate cognitive functions is thought to be a primary pathology in multiple neurodevelopmental disorders, including schizophrenia and autistic spectrum disorder. This project will determine whether the neurons that interconnect association cortices—layer 2/3 projection neurons—are the target of NDD pathology due to oxidative stress caused by dysfunctional mitochondria. The data will define potential targets for novel therapies to ameliorate mitochondria-related circuit dysfunction and behavioral deficits in a broad range of NDDs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Public Health Relevance. Diagnosis, staging, and treatment assessment of pancreatic cancer is severely challenged by the difficulty to delineate and reproducibly measure pancreatic lesions as a result of low-enhancement from contrast agents. We propose to develop high-sensitivity, low-bias spectral CT technology to enhance low concentration iodine visualization and mitigate system-dependent variability to allow quantitative image biomarkers as additional in- dicators for diagnosis and treatment efficacy. The technology developed in this work can be widely applied to improve quantitative accuracy of spectral CT applications, and facilitate robust clinical translation of novel spec- tral biomarkers for general disease management.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Finding novel therapies for treatment of radiation-induced toxicities is of value to not only patients who are receiving radiotherapy for different conditions, but also to national security due to risk of terrorism attacks. This proposal will use exosomes, from stimulated mesenchymal stromal cells, to develop radioprotective monocytes as a new and innovative cellular therapy for acute radiation syndrome. Using highly innovative modes of in vivo cell tracking and detailed analyses of the mechanism by which these cells stimulate hematopoiesis, we will provide insight into how these cells protect against radiation; efficacy of the radioprotective monocytes will also be validated in 2 different animal models of radiation injury, and success of any of the aims will be a major advance in using cellular therapies for treating radiation injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The reduction of bioinactive N2 by nitrogenase enzyme metalloccofactors is a foundational process for human life, resulting in the production of bioavailable N-sources to be used in the development of proteins, nucleic acids, and other cell constituents. To this end, the mechanism of the biological reduction of N2 remains largely unknown. The work proposed herein involves the synthetic design and reactivity of new low-valent tri-iron clusters which will act as biomimetic models for the metallocofactors of nitrogenase, providing an abiological route toward the elucidation of nature’s N2 fixation process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Infection with HIV increases susceptibility to oncogenic oral HPV infections that are associated with oral and oropharyngeal cancers. The proposed study will investigate the natural history of oral HPV in persons living with HIV (PLWH) participating in the largest HIV cohort study in the United States and will assess the effects of oral bacterial infections (microbiome) and fungal infections (mycobiome) on the risk of oral HPV persistence, an intermediate biomarker of HPV-associated cancers. This study should lead to innovative approaches to reduce the risks of HPV-associated oral and oropharyngeal cancers in PLWH.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The majority of interacting egg and sperm proteins involved in fertilization remain undetermined in humans. The proposed research combines state-of-the-art genomic, proteomic, and structural methods to characterize the interactions of egg and sperm proteins in abalone – a classic animal model of fertilization – as well as identify the effects of potential drivers of infertility in humans. The research will address general questions in reproductive biology, and may provide foundational knowledge towards the design of novel infertility treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although research has produced overwhelming evidence that sexual minority women (SMW) are at substantially higher risk than heterosexual women of hazardous drinking and alcohol use disorders at least partially because of their exposure to minority stress, no studies have tested interventions aimed at reducing this disparity. In the proposed study we will test a remotely delivered transdiagnostic cognitive-behavioral intervention, EQuIP (Empowering Queer Identities in Psychotherapy), to improve minority stress coping and reduce SMW’s hazardous drinking and mental health comorbidities. If successful, this intervention can be implemented in SMW-serving community settings to help reduce hazardous drinking and its negative health consequences that disproportionately affect this at-risk population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project narrative Aggregation of the microtubule-associated protein tau in the brain is one of the two hallmarks of Alzheimer’s disease. Determining how post-translational modifications of tau mediate the formation, propagation and spreading of tau neurofibrillary tangles is important for developing tau-specific compounds to diagnose and inhibit Alzheimer's disease. We propose to use solid- state NMR spectroscopy, electron microscopy and biochemical methods to elucidate the structures and dynamics of tau in the aggregated, membrane-bound and microtubule-bound states to elucidate the structural basis of Alzheimer's disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal describes a novel AD screening platform that combines spatial biology, whole brain imaging, automated histological processing, and advanced image analysis. It will be offered as a fee-for-service platform based on a high-performance cloud infrastructure that can serve, visualize, and analyze multiplexed terabyte datasets. This proposal will allow researchers to apply cutting-edge advances in the fields of spatial biology and deep learning to the latest AD research models, and thus better make informed, clinically translatable decisions that will further the development of AD therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Adenovirus (Ad) vectors are one of the most frequently used vector systems in human clinical trials aimed at ameliorating genetic diseases and treating cancer. Despite many advantages of Ad vectors as potential therapeutics, the potent systemic inflammation that is triggered by intravascular administration of Ad remains a serious barrier to clinical applications. The molecular mechanisms underlying the exacerbation of systemic inflammation are poorly understood. This project is based on our recent discovery that human serum samples that lack Ad neutralizing antibodies are able to activate complement and trigger complement fixation on the virus, leading to a potentiated inflammatory response from human immune cells. We will comprehensively address the origin and function of non-neutralizing immunity to Ad and its role in compromising the safety of intravenous Ad administration.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because it advances an innovative model of hypertension care - community health workers empowered by mobile health technology to identify and manage hypertension - which overcomes the health care workforce limitations not addressed by current approaches in low- and middle-income countries. This model would be widely adaptable to low-resource settings around the world, leading to increased identification and treatment of people with hypertension. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the Fogarty International Center’s vision that pertains to reducing the burden of disease, promoting health, and extending longevity for all people.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE: These experiments are relevant to public health for two reasons. First, they may provide proof-of-concept data for testing an entirely new type of HIV vaccine that could protect against all strains of HIV, and second, that incorporating specific proteins into a vaccine may result in increased rather than decreased rates of transmission due to their pro-inflammatory effects. Here we propose the novel hypothesis that targeting key accessory genes using an innovative MHC-II invariant chain vaccine platform that enhances immune responses to non-dominant peptides, while avoiding responses to dominant peptides, should confer complete protection from HIV infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Maternal smoking during pregnancy is the largest preventable cause of childhood respiratory illness, and children whose mothers smoked during pregnancy show lifetime decreases in airway function and increased respiratory illnesses and asthma. We have shown that vitamin C supplementation to pregnant smokers improves their offspring's airway function through 5 years of age. This project will continue to study these children through 10 years of age to demonstrate if this improvement in airway function persists, if the improvement is due to larger airways, and the potential epigenetic changes that could underlie these improvements.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: African Caribbeans have a one of the highest global rates of high blood pressures, which can lead to abnormalities in the heart muscle and its function. However, there is currently no information from the general population in this geographic region on the health of the heart muscle and its functioning in African Ancestry Caribbeans. Therefore, this study seeks to describe the current burden of abnormalities in heart muscle and its function in African Caribbeans from Tobago and to determine the most important risk factors for these abnormalities, including assessment of culturally unique factors like diet, physical activity, body fat distribution, and circulating factors in the blood.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE More than 80% of individuals with chronic kidney disease have concomitant hypertension and the majority fail to achieve blood pressure control <130/80 mmHg, leading to high risk of cardiovascular diseases and end- stage kidney disease. A stepwise combination of lifestyle modifications and drug therapy is recommended to lower blood pressure; however, adherence to time-intensive lifestyle interventions such as aerobic exercise in patients with chronic kidney disease is poor. This clinical trial seeks to establish the efficacy of high-resistance inspiratory muscle strength training, a novel time-efficient lifestyle intervention, for lowering systolic blood pressure and improving endothelial function in midlife and older adults with moderate-to-severe chronic kidney disease and inadequately controlled hypertension, and to use innovate translational assessments to understand the mechanisms involved.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Ventricular tachyarrhythmias often underlie hemodynamic collapse and sudden death. While ablation can suppress recurrent ventricular tachyarrhythmias, efficacy is limited and major complications, including exacerbation of heart failure. Here we explore a complementary strategy: rather than destroying heart tissue, we seek to modify the substrate using anti-fibrotic exosomes secreted by cardiosphere-derived cells (CDCs).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Only 3% of older adults in the US have proficient health literacy, even less have proficient eHealth literacy, and this is worse for Spanish-preferred older adult Latinos, who are a largely underserved population in the US. eHealth literacy is necessary for engaging in eHealth, which has the potential to improve health outcomes for older adults and is becoming increasingly necessary due to the ubiquity of technology in health as part of living in the post- COVID era. Prior eHealth literacy interventions typically focused on English-language participants, which is important, but the pandemic highlighted health inequities in the use of technology for healthcare that can be addressed by the proposed research on the development, implementation, and evaluation of culturally and linguistically appropriate eHealth interventions that increase eHealth literacy for older adult Spanish preferred Latinos in the US.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Rickettsioses are diseases caused by bacterial pathogens belonging to the genus Rickettsia. Pathogenic Rickettsia are typically transmitted to humans by blood-feeding arthropods (insects and ticks). This project seeks to examine the interplay between Rickettsia felis and the vector fleas, to better understand the epidemiology of an emerging flea-borne rickettsiosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative  Depression is the leading cause of disability worldwide with a lifetime prevalence of ~17% in the United States, with one third of cases developing treatment-resistant depression. Noninvasive neurostimulation therapies such as repetitive Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (rTMS)–where a magnetic coil placed over the cortex is used to focally stimulate the brain–have recently emerged as promising low-risk interventions for treatment-resistant depression, but it is unclear why they work incredibly well for some patients and not at all for others. We propose a bold new approach to personalization of rTMS treatment that uses generative neural networks to learn and then simulate possible treatment response trajectories for depressed patients in order to improve personalization and better understand the mechanisms of accelerated neurostimulation treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement (Project Narrative) The Caltech/UCLA individualized Theranostic Engineering to Advance Metabolic System (Caltech/UCLA iTEAM) is distinct in applying a humanistic approach to integrate training in imaging or sensing coupled with computing to address cardiometabolic disease. The Caltech/UCLA iTEAM is synergistic to provide structured training in research, teaching, recruitment, and retention to enhance diversity and inclusion for our engineering and physical science scholars. In comparison with other comparable bioengineering T32 programs, the added value of Caltech/UCLA iTEAM is our joint mentorship with the biomedical faculty and our partnership with the industry leaders, thus, providing a nurturing ecosystem to inspire, enrich, and empower the under-represented groups to pursue leadership careers in academia or industry.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Diffuse Intrinsic Pontine Gliomas (DIPG) are incurable pediatric high grade brain tumors. This disease is characterized by highly recurrent lysine-to-methionine mutation on the histone H3 genes (H3K27M) that causes alteration in chromatin regulation. The goal of this project is to understand the H3K27M induced chromatin alteration that lead to DIPG in order to formulate a molecular informed therapeutic strategy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Delayed Sleep-Wake Phase Disorder is a Circadian Rhythm disorder that affects millions of people each year representing an important public health issue. We anticipate our findings will be the first step in establishing novel and effective treatment approaches for DSWPD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative This ambitious experimental and theoretical collaboration will investigate how internal states (such as task engagement) influence decision-making, and identify the underlying neural mechanisms. The proposed work will produce an integrated, circuit-level model that explains decision behavior and neural activity in healthy and autism model mice, which show a reduced ability to make decisions that take changing expectations into account. Decision-making is also impaired in addiction and schizophrenia, so a deeper understanding of brainwide decision-making circuitry may contribute to future research on ways to treat or mitigate these disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: RELEVANCE (See instructions): Asymmetric cell division is a vital aspect of both regular human cell progression (e.g. embryonic development, tissue homeostasis) and disease states (e.g. cancer). However, quantitative studies of asymmetric cell division are stymied by the difficulty of systematically perturbing native cell differentiation pathways. This research will use a novel synthetic biology approach to develop experimental and mathematical models for studying asymmetric cell division in multicellular systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rheumatologic disorders are an increasing cause of morbidity and mortality due both to a rising incidence of autoimmunity and to our aging population. The training of physician-scientists who specialize in investigation is essential for scientific discovery and for devising better strategies for treatment and disease prevention. The goal of this program is to educate the next generation of such individuals by providing qualified candidates with advanced training in research methodology and effective mentorship so they develop into our future leaders in investigative rheumatology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Angiogenesis, the process of new blood vessel formation from preexisting capillaries, is associated with the pathogenesis of a number of eye diseases including retinopathy of prematurity (ROP). Understanding how exposure of premature infants to high oxygen levels, to help with their lung development and function, interferes with normal development of retinal vasculature and causes retinal neovascularization is critical for the development of effective treatments to save vision in these patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Current treatment approaches that are designed to prevent atherosclerosis progression by reducing LDL cholesterol levels often fail to prevent the growth and evolution of atherosclerotic plaques in patients’ arteries. Fortiscience, Inc. is taking a novel approach to treating atherosclerosis by developing a drug that inhibits fortilin, a key protein involved in the survival of macrophages, which contribute to plaque formation and inflammation. This novel drug, which is intended to prevent plaque progression, will provide an alternative to lipid-lowering therapies and reduce the risk of life-threatening cardiovascular events in patients with atherosclerosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to conduct a longitudinal epigenomic study of SDH in relation to cardiovascular diseases (CVD) in a large bi-racial cohort, the CARDIA cohort. Our investigation of epigenomic biomarkers associated with long- term exposure to both individual- and neighborhood-level social determinants of health in combination with genomic data and longitudinal CVD risk factors and subclinical and clinical CVD measures will provide important information for the development of a robust CVD prediction algorithm, and enhance our ability to identify at-risk individuals and molecular targets for CVD prevention and to lessen CVD disparity.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) is a chronic and debilitating inflammatory disease of the gastrointestinal tract in urgent need of new therapeutic approaches. The project proposed in this application will reveal an important role for the epithelial-expressed tight junction protein Claudin-23 in the regulation of intestinal barrier function during homeostasis and inflammation. Successful completion of the proposed studies will identify new targets for the treatment of inflammation in IBD and will be pivotal to my development as an independent scientist with interdisciplinary training in cell biology and physiology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Medulloblastoma is the most common malignant brain tumor in children. While patients have tumor histology with a primitive embryonal phenotype with poor prognosis, some medulloblastomas show foci of spontaneous maturation with a brain-like phenotype with improved survival. The objective of this proposal is to dissect the mechanism of medulloblastoma tumor cell maturation and identify targets to induce maturation therapeutically.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because an improved understanding of which cancer patients are most likely to benefit from immune checkpoint inhibitor therapy and why some patients do not respond to treatment will lead to meaningful improvements in therapy selection and new strategies for overcoming therapeutic resistance. Research shows a clear link between elevated immune checkpoint inhibitor clearance and poor response that is decoupled from circulating levels of therapeutic in some patients. A better mechanistic understanding of patient factors governing elevated immune checkpoint inhibitor clearance could have a major impact on cancer related mortality by improving utilization of immune checkpoint inhibitor therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project focuses on understanding how brain circuits critical for memory formation balance the need to preserve prior knowledge with the necessity to continuously learn new information. The balance between stability and plasticity may be disrupted in aging and in brain disorders such as Alzheimer's disease, and this project will provide a quantitative basis for studying such imbalance and its consequences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative We recently discovered a new way of how signalling lipids are transported in cells. We will fully characterize the components of this exciting new mechanism and will expand the investigations to many other cellular lipids. This work will be the basis for determining the relevance of our findings for cellular signalling and will ultimately identify new drug targets for treating diseases such as cancer and multiple sclerosis.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE This project will apply innovative new techniques on very large existing datasets to help discover novel genetic contributors to spontaneous and recurrent pregnancy loss. We will bring together a remarkable team of leaders across maternal fetal medicine and genomics to assemble the largest cohort of pregnancy loss samples in the field and use high-resolution genomics methods to identify genes and variants that are incompatible with life. We will integrate genes associated with PL to those discovered in other developmental disorders to find key putative drivers of normal development and perform lethality screens of the most compelling novel discoveries using CRISPR genome editing in developing mouse embryos.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The findings from this project will determine sex differences and the influence of sex hormones on neural function underlying risk for Alcohol Use Disorder (AUD), as well as how sex differences in neural function influence current and future alcohol consumption. The results will identify novel brain-based targets for sex- specific prevention and treatment efforts for AUD, and will provide information on the optimal timing of intervention for women, based on fluctuating sex hormones. As such, the project is a critical step towards the development of biologically-based, sex-specific interventions for AUD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative As our understanding of calcineurin signaling grows, we are able to elucidate the molecular mechanisms contributing to CNI-induced renal fibrosis. Our project goal is to test the hypothesis that renal CnAα inhibition upregulates NFκB signaling which promotes irreversible renal damage. These findings have clinical relevance and advance the field of renal physiology and pharmacology and pursues the idea that newer CNIs can be developed that effectively blunt the immune response while reducing or preventing kidney damage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cell signaling proteins such as the Erk kinase play a crucial role in embryo development, cancer, and the developmental defects known as RASopathies. A major hypothesis in the field is that cell adopt different fates depending on whether Erk is activated in a short pulse or a long plateau, but studying these dynamics remains extremely difficult. We propose to develop a new class of biosensors for detecting signaling pulses from Erk and other pathways, opening the door to a better understanding of their role in development and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative “Extreme” drinking (roughly a “double” binge) is a significant public health concern, especially among young adults, but almost all information on these behaviors is based on self‐report, which can be particularly unreliable given the memory impairments associated with this level of alcohol consumption. This project will collect data from high risk young adults during drinking events using mobile technology, including real‐time smartphone assessments and portable alcohol breathalyzers, and will be combined with information from other sources (e.g., alcohol outlet density, laboratory collected data). Results of this study can provide unique information critical to developing public health messages and interventions aimed at reducing extreme drinking.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) are the self-renewing population of cells that generate all the blood lineages throughout the life of an organism and are biomedically important as the basic units of bone marrow transplantation, which is used to treat a myriad of malignant and non-malignant hematological diseases. This proposal aims to characterize a family of novel regulators (GPRASPs) of HSCs and their role in HSC transplantation, which will illuminate a new set of molecular candidates that might be targeted for improving current therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  We are transforming our biomedical engineering education by introducing series of courses as part of an educational toolkit for bioengineering design, entrepreneurship, and service learning into our curriculum. This toolkit will consist of four courses, in which students will engage with our local healthcare community to identify healthcare gaps and disparities, learn about entrepreneurship in collaboration with the business school, acquire essential engineering design skills already in their junior year, and inspire the next generation of engineers by mentoring high school pre-engineering students. Our aim is to graduate biomedical engineers who are outstanding stewards of their education, serving their communities, and translating healthcare innovations for a broader impact.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Aggregation of the RNA binding protein TDP-43 is found in almost every age-dependent neurodegenerative disease, including the major dementias. We propose to determine how age-dependent decrease in protein folding chaperone and protein degradation activities contribute to TDP-43 loss of function, cytoplasmic mislocalization, phase separation, and aggregation. We will also develop and refine an approach to generate new/replacement neurons in the aged adult brain by transiently suppressing expression of a single protein, the RNA binding protein PTB. We will develop and use single cell spatial transcriptomics to identify the functionality, localization, cell origin, timing, and molecular pathways of the newly developing neurons.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sexual and gender minority people (including but not limited to people who are LGBTQ+) are at greater risk for substance use, which is related to unique stressors such as stigma and discrimination, and both substance use and this unique stress have biological signatures, suggesting that biological markers of substance use may be developed that could improve substance use treatment. Dr. Flentje proposes to expand her research by integrating hormonal exposures and HIV status into this work, identifying mentees from a range of disciplines including hormonal biology, epigenetics, and HIV, and seeking training to support mentees through financial challenges, loan repayment applications, family building, and emotional hardships. Dr. Flentje will support patient-oriented mentees to identify hormone exposures and stressors relevant to substance use, and identify epigenetic markers of substance use, hormone exposure, and minority stress among people living with or without HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A landmark report from the National Academies of Sciences, Medicine, and Engineering demonstrated the high prevalence of sexual harassment in medicine and science, which they conclude leads to a costly loss of talent. In a cohort of NIH T32 training programs, we will test whether a multi-modal virtual intervention with video game elements, developed from the NASEM conceptual model of sexual harassment, will increase Principal Investigators’ and mentors’ confidence in their ability to intervene and improve the culture and climate of the learning environment for NIH T32 funded mentees. We will also test whether the intervention improves civility, decreases rates of microaggressions and sexual harassment, and leads to a greater sense of belonging, well-being, research productivity, and persistence in a biomedical research career among NIH T32 mentees.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Perioperative neurocognitive disorders (PNCD) affect about a quarter of geriatric surgical patients and increases the risk that those patients will go on to develop dementias such as Alzheimer's disease. However, no interventions exist to prevent PNCD, mostly because the etiology is unclear. We propose to build the foundation for a precision medicine approach for geriatric surgical patients who require surgery with anesthesia – this includes construction of a novel comprehensive database and an analysis platform capable of mining this multidimensional dataset.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal is dedicated to novel experimental and sequencing strategies to quantify pancreatic cancer evo- lution, one aspect at a time. This approach has high potential for clinical relevance because the strategy seeks to resolve individual factors that drive the aggressive evolution of pancreatic cancer. Quantitatively defining these influences will significantly improve efforts to intervene and circumvent this typically lethal cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative The human body contains metabolic microenvironments, such as the bone marrow and brain, that are low in nutrients and oxygen. Eukaryotic cells must adapt to limited nutrients to proliferate and survive in these environments. We will determine the metabolic pathways prioritized by cells in nutrient-poor and hypoxic metabolic milieus using novel techniques of our own design.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This application aims to establish a biomarker characterization center to identify biomarkers in clinically easily accessible samples and to develop them into clinical tests to capture high-grade serous ovarian carcinoma (the most common and deadliest form of ovarian cancer) at the early stages when surgical and therapeutic treatment may still be able to change a patient’s long-term survival. The initial development and testing will be in high-risk women population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The vestibular system located in the inner ear senses the motion of the head, and vestibular loss is a debilitating condition that leads to problems with vision, gait, and balance. A notable recent development is the multichannel vestibular prosthesis, a neural implant that aims to replace the function of damaged vestibular peripheral organs. In order to test the efficacy of the device and understand how the brain interprets vestibular signals during balance, this research aims to establish an animal model of balance control and examine the underlying neural mechanisms of the vestibular contribution to balance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative IgE antibodies interact with two receptors, the high affinity FceRI receptor and low affinity FceRII/CD23 receptor, to mediate different biological functions associated with the allergic cascade. In this proposal, we will investigate the structures and functions of anti-IgE and anti-FceRI antibodies and also probe how CD23 interacts with IgE and CD21 ligands. These studies will provide novel reagents for studying and blocking IgE:receptor interactions that centrally regulate the allergic response and new insights into the biological functions of IgE and its receptors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Women diagnosed with breast cancer-associated brain metastases (BCBM) have an unacceptable median overall survival rate of 10-11 months. A major knowledge gap in understanding brain metastasis biology is the functional interplay between tumor cells and the metastatic brain tumor microenvironment (TME). The current application will advance this field by directly examining novel mechanisms of how the PDGFB–to-PDGFRβ signaling node, which is potentially druggable, promotes BCBM by creating a pro-tumorigenic immune microenvironment and by invoking vascular changes in collaboration with Angiopoietin-1.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Binge drinking can lead to serious health and psychological consequences, especially in a military population where alcohol-related incidents can lead to a court martial and dishonorable discharge from service. Our proposed innovative distance-based option for lowering binge drinking incidents, if efficacious, could open new doors for health in the American military through a cost-effective, easy-to-implement intervention, and benefit both the individual and the military service he or she is part of, as well as providing a roadmap for programs for civilian adults.

PHR: In general, GPCRs activate G protein signaling at the cell surface, which is followed by rapid signal desensitization and receptor internalization by -arrestins. However, recent studies suggest that some receptors continue to stimulate G proteins after they have been internalized into endosomes by -arrestins in an unappreciated conformation. As endosomal G protein signaling is associated with unique physiological functions, this project seeks to understand the underlying receptor/-arrestin properties that drive this mechanism, which can be leveraged for future drug development efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The development of drugs targeting RNA, RNA therapeutics, and our fundamental understanding of biological processes is hindered by incomplete RNA structure and function models. This research program will generate predictive models of RNA conformational dynamics, RNA-ligand binding, and RNA catalysis. This work will transform our understanding of RNA machines, assist in developing new RNA-targeted drugs, and contribute to generating life-saving RNA therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will provide critical new information about the presence and impact of disrupted spatial and temporal nociceptive processing in youth with localized chronic pain and chronic overlapping pain conditions (COPCs). The study will also provide insight into which individuals are more likely to transition from a single pain condition to COPCs, providing an opportunity for early identification by screening for disrupted nociceptive processing and prioritization of these at-risk patients for intensive care, multidisciplinary therapy. Leveraging the current study, our long-term objectives are to reduce the development of COPCs, which closely aligns with the NIH’s Federal Pain Research Strategy and National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke (NINDS) to reduce the public health burden of chronic pain across the lifespan.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/ RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Nearly half of the preventable deaths worldwide can be addressed through rapid delivery of effective emergent care. We propose to establish “Rwanda912” as an innovative mHealth platform to improve the existing prehospital system by accurately locating patients and facilitating communication between dispatch, ambulance and emergency triage staff in Kigali, Rwanda. We hypothesize that this novel platform will be feasible and acceptable to these three stakeholder groups and will improve the delivery of timely and effective prehospital care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Hyperkalemic periodic paralysis causes debilitating attacks of paralysis and weakness in patients, and these attacks last from minutes to days. The only FDA-approved treatment provides only modest relief and can include painful side effects and cognitive disorders. The proposed work is relevant to public health because it uses a novel correlated study design to examine a novel disease alteration and a novel therapeutic, both supported by pilot data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The prevalence of tick-borne rickettsial diseases (TBRDs) has steadily increased worldwide and it has become vital to develop a deeper understanding of the mechanisms that contribute to rickettsial pathogenicity and horizontal transmission of Rickettsia. The studies outlined in this proposal aim to fill significant knowledge gaps pertaining to the rickettsial-induced determinants of horizontal transmission and the basic biology of salivary gland function and tick bloodmeal feeding. These studies are needed to resolve the epidemiology of SFG rickettsioses and identify novel points of intervention to reduce the burden of TBRDs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While bacterial stress responses are essential for adaptation to harsh environments and cell survival, they also contribute to the rise of antimicrobial resistance – an alarming problem of the present and future. To gain a fundamental understanding of the underlying biochemical pathways, our studies will focus on two distinct, emerging classes of regulators – small proteins and epitranscriptomic factors, and their contribution to bacterial stress responses. Our research will provide key insights into bacterial regulatory networks, which will be useful for developing effective therapeutic interventions against multi-drug resistant bacteria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  Multiple sclerosis is a debilitating neurological condition which the NINDS has identified as a high priority target area and the proposed research aligns with the mission as it examines how individual difference characteristics such as race and stress exposure can explain why brain atrophy does not sufficiently predict clinical MS outcomes. Doing so will aid in the diagnosis, prevention, and treatment of MS. In addition to proposing research which will help address racial health disparities, the proposal aligns with the NIH Blueprint and NINDS commitment to supporting a diverse and inclusive neuroscience workforce by supporting innovative translational clinical research training for a highly promising scholar.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project narrative Novel implantable brain devices that can sense neural activity, as well as deliver therapeutic stimulation, have recently become available and may lead to new therapies for brain disorders. However, use of the most flexible and powerful of these neural interfaces requires expertise in software and in device regulatory requirements that is unfamiliar to most investigators. Our group, which has already launched clinical trials using the novel sensing interfaces, here forms a “neural communications consortium” to disseminate technical and regulatory knowledge to new users, which will be critical for launching investigational studies.

PHR: Project Narrative Targeted protein degradation is an exciting new strategy in drug design. These small molecule degraders induce the modification of the target protein with ubiquitin. This proposal investigates new methods of targeted protein degradation that are ubiquitin independent, and thus should avoid the issues that limit current methods of targeted protein degradation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative CD4+ T memory stem cells are long-lived precursor cells that possess the ability to self-renew and differentiate into specific T cell subtypes. T memory stem cells are likely key in prolonged availability of autoreactive T effector cells in autoimmune diseases such as type 1 diabetes and rheumatoid arthritis. Insights into the regulation of these cells in a cell-type- and disease-specific manner can be gained through the investigation of cis-regulatory elements and changes in three-dimensional genome architecture that defines control of target gene expression.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative Worldwide, sepsis is responsible for the majority of deaths in children each year with most of these deaths occurring in low and middle-income countries (LMICs), yet few clinical tools have been developed for identifying, monitoring, or managing children with sepsis in LMICs. The proposed research will develop and validate a mobile health tool which links continuous physiologic data obtained remotely from a wearable device with a standard smartphone and machine learning approach known as personalized physiologic analytics to provide clinicians with accurate assessments of advanced stages of sepsis (severe sepsis, septic shock, multiple organ dysfunction syndrome), and risk of death in septic children without the need for laboratory diagnostics or expensive monitoring equipment. By enabling detection of subtle physiologic changes indicating clinical deterioration, these tools may allow clinicians to intervene earlier, better direct care, and allocate scarce resources, thereby reducing child morbidity and mortality from sepsis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Chronic and diabetic kidney disease are the most significant complications of diabetes. The current project aims to decipher the role of specific lipid peroxides – a selective form of oxidative stress - in kidney injury. We seek to identify the molecular identity, renal cell-specific sources, and production mechanisms of oxidized lipids, in order to be able to design better approaches to prevent, arrest or postpone kidney disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE - This research will be the first to provide a proof-of-principle demonstration that targeting transcriptional initiation and elongation is an effective therapeutic strategy in diffuse intrinsic pontine glioma (DIPG), one of the most devastating childhood cancers. This project will also explore how a novel combination therapy interacts with radiation, which is important due to the frequent use of radiation in treating DIPG patients. The successful completion of proposal study will ultimately lead to improved treatment outcomes for patients afflicted with a currently incurable pediatric brain tumor, that is therefore relevant to public health and the mission of the National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke (NINDS), which is to seek fundamental knowledge about the brain and the nervous system and to use that knowledge to advance cures for neurological diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVES. In the proposed supplement, we will examine whether Native Hawaiian/Pacific Islander (NH/PI) adults, who experience severe substance use disparities, increase their use of two or more substances (cigarettes, e-cigarettes, marijuana and/or alcohol) when experiencing discrimination and cultural trauma. Using daily questionnaires via a smartphone application, we will study in real-time the specific factors that influence substance use by these adults to cope with discrimination-related stress. Our results will reveal the burden of daily discrimination on addiction and unique cultural resilience among NH/PI adults that can reduce this burden.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: FEDERATION OF AMER SOC FOR EXPER BIOLOGY
PHR: Project Narrative The FASEB conference on Genetic Recombination and Genome Rearrangements brings together the world’s leading researchers investigating the mechanisms and regulation of genetic recombination and chromosome rearrangements. This field encompasses several topics directly relevant for the biology of aging, cell senescence, telomere maintenance, as well as to the mechanisms promoting age-related disease, including neurological disorders and cancer. Therefore, a mechanistic understanding of these processes is paramount for an improved understanding of premature aging, of cancer etiology, for the identification of critical biomarkers of various age-related conditions, and for developing novel strategies of treatments that are more efficacious and minimize side effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A major part of the mission of the International Society of Neurogastronomy (ISN) is to promote the study of flavor and its use to enhance the quality of human life, channeling our growing knowledge of neurogastronomy and chemosensory science into translational action needed to overcome the ways in which flavor preferences can contribute to unhealthy eating habits. ISN promotes cooperation between scientists and food professionals towards altering the balance of this equation in our culture. ISN’s annual meeting provides an important mechanism for facilitating the interactions between chemosensory scientists, neuroscientists, clinicians, nutritional scientists, agricultural scientists and food professionals needed to develop strategies for using flavor properly - strategies that are both practical and scientifically sound.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed studies of the visual experience of infants are relevant to public health because impaired vision and visual learning have long term consequences across many domains of a healthy and successful life. Disrupted visual experience in infancy is evident in the continued risk in perceptual, cognitive and school achievements and is implicated in the nexus of disrupted visual learning and motor development of children with more general developmental disorders. Determining the expected and normative early visual input in infancy and its links to infant eye- movements and behaviors is expected to give rise to new diagnostics and behavioral interventions for at-risk infants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Despite the availability of vaccines, diseases caused by Bordetella species continue to have a significant impact on the morbidity and mortality of humans and animals worldwide. There is an imperative need for an improved understanding of Bordetella evolution, diversity, and mechanisms of virulence to guide the informed development of next generation vaccines and therapeutics. The 14th International Bordetella Symposium will provide a forum for scientists, physicians, public health officials, regulators, and industry representatives to collaborate on the shared objective of realizing novel strategies for the control of diseases caused by Bordetella spp. in a diverse, equitable, and inclusive scientific environment.

PHR: Contact PD/PI: Wright, Emily Clarissa PROJECT NARRATIVE In this proposal, I aim to apply these two sensors combined with fiber-photometry to optically measure behaviorally driven serotonin release in an anxiogenic serotonin circuit with high temporal and spatial resolution. This information will be made publicly available and become fundamental data to guide future research with the sLight and iSeroSnFr biosensors. I will use these sensors to answer previously unapproachable questions about functional role of serotonin in an anxiogenic circuit and mechanistically address gaps in SSRI efficacy. IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Pharmacoequity, a term coined by researchers within our Center for Pharmaceutical Policy and Prescribing (CP3), refers to the goal of ensuring that all individuals, regardless of race/ethnicity, socioeconomic status, or availability of resources, have access to the highest quality medications required to manage their health needs. The proposed 3rd Annual Pharmacoequity Conference will feature presentations centered on key research findings, new methodologies, and policy solutions that utilize and apply pharmacoequity principles to ensure the equitable access to pharmacotherapy to all persons. This conference provides a unique platform for which engaged stakeholders from payer groups, health systems, and research communities can gain insight on how to address and apply pharmacoequity principles and tools within their respective fields.

PROJECT_TITLE: Pharmacoequity Conference

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Traumatic brain injury (TBI) and spinal cord injury (SCI) are a major public health burden that often lead to lifelong impairment and disability. The National Neurotrauma Society (NNS), largely through its annual Symposium, is a critical translational research resource for sharing the latest advances in the neurotrauma field, with the ultimate goal of improving the treatments available to patients. Ongoing support for this annual meeting ensures a major national investment in advancing and innovating neurotrauma research and in the career development of trainees, with a focus on opportunities for increasing and retaining diversity in trainees and faculty in the neurotrauma field.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: 2024 AUA OFFICE OF RESEARCH BASIC SCIENCES SYMPOSIUM  “Spatial Biology in Benign and Malignant Urologic Disease” PROJECT NARRATIVE/PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Understanding spatial biology in benign and malignant urologic disease is crucial to advancing urologic research and improving clinical care, and it is essential that the urology community, especially trainees, early- career physician-scientists, and researchers be provided with accessible opportunities to gain understanding of new knowledge and significant recent advances in these fields and leverage it towards improvements for patient diagnosis and treatment. The goal of the 2024 AUA Basic Sciences Symposium is to bring together pioneers in spatial biology to educate and foster interaction between urologists, other physicians, and researchers to provide new insights into epigenetic priming, differentiation, and gene regulation with implications for tumor staging and grading in urologic disease. The uniqueness of the 2024 Basic Sciences Symposium at the AUA Annual Meeting is not only that it brings the latest advancements in research to the world’s largest gathering of urologists and urology researchers, but also that the Program Chairs prioritized consideration of racial, ethnic, gender/gender identity, sexual orientation, nationality, cultural, religious, age, (dis)ability, career stage, and socioeconomic backgrounds in accordance with the Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion Statement of the AUA Office of Research: Research Education Conferences, and Communications Committee (RECCC).
