IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Neurons are remarkable cells that execute functions ranging from simple sensing and reporting on the environment to enabling cognition, functions that neurons must accomplish against unique challenges for shape, connection, maintenance and communication. The devastating developmental and late onset neurodegenerative diseases (including Alzheimer’s disease, Parkinson’s disease, ALS) that result from neuronal dysfunction or loss underscore the critical importance of understanding the mechanisms that underlie and sustain neuron health. The Cell Biology of the Neuron Gordon Research Conferences will have a major impact on galvanizing ideas emerging from state-of-the-art neuronal cell biology technologies and experimental outcomes by: i) broadening mechanistic understanding of the critical roles of internal neuronal functionalities relevant to human aging, health, and neurological disease, ii) inspiring design of novel therapeutic strategies to combat neuronal developmental dysfunction and disease, and iii) promoting the career growth of a diverse population of students and junior investigators through customized training and networking opportunities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative: Deafness is the most common and arguably the most socially isolating sensory impairment, with the World Health Organization estimating that over 360 million people worldwide have moderate to profound hearing loss. Although the physiological causes of most forms of deafness are incompletely understood, it is clear that changes to the delicate structures of the peripheral auditory system, such as the cochlear hair cells normally responsible for the high sensitivity and exquisite frequency selectivity of hearing, are mostly to blame. A deeper scientific understanding of peripheral auditory function at both the structural and molecular level therefore remains critical to reducing the devastating impact of hearing loss on both individuals and society.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The 14th International Kawasaki Disease Symposium will provide an opportunity for trainees and leading scientists and clinicians across multiple disciplines from around the world to present the latest research and clinical care for Kawasaki disease, the leading cause of acquired heart disease in children throughout most of the world. This will lead to further scientific collaborations and improved clinical care worldwide for children with Kawasaki disease. Given that this is a cardiovascular illness that affects children that likely has an infectious cause, and that the International Kawasaki Disease Symposium’s mission is to turn research observations into health solutions, this is in alignment with the priorities of NHLBI, NICHD, NIAID and NCATS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE The prevalence of fibrosis is increasing due to the aging population, advances in diagnostic tools and increased exposure to infectious agents and other environmental factors that impact pathogenesis. Understanding the effect of these factors on the clinical manifestation of different fibrosis pathologies and pursing novel advances in lung regeneration after scarring will have a significant impact on lung health. By highlighting emerging concepts of shared relevance to the fields of lung biology and fibrosis and by addressing strategies to improve translation of scientific advances to reduce the burden of fibrosis and other lung diseases, the 2024 Thomas L. Petty Aspen Lung Conference will promote scientific advances in fibrosis biology, fibrosis resolution and therapeutic intervention, ultimately improving lung health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Poor muscle recovery following disuse is frequent amongst older adults leading to low muscle mass, weakness, and increased disability. We have proposed to test specific mechanisms of a disrupted macrophage metabolic state during recovery from disuse in aged mice and humans. These findings will produce new knowledge of macrophage metabolism that will aid in the development of therapeutic strategies to promote muscle recovery in aged individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative The Neural Control of Movement Society (NCM) will host its 33rd annual meeting in Dubrovnik, Croatia, in April 2024, bringing together several hundred scientists to present and discuss research related to the brain’s control of movement. The meeting covers a broad range of experimental models and modeling approaches, aimed at understanding the neural control of motor behaviors from locomotion, to reaching, to eye movements, to speech. NCM is committed to facilitating trainee attendance at the meeting, and to increasing diversity in terms of gender, underrepresented minorities, and geographical origin, on the podium, in our leadership, and within the NCM society at large.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cocaine misuse is common he heath of the blood brain among people living with HIV (PLWH) and can affect t barrier (BBB), which protects the brain from neurotoxins and pathogens. The disruption of the BBB can lead to higher levels of virus in the brain and poorer cognition. This project combines brain imaging, neuropsychiatric assessments, and blood-based measures of monocyte characteristics, function and reservoir, to understand the role of monocytes play in BBB integrity and health in PLWH who have a history of cocaine misuse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The Academy of Behavioral Medicine Research (ABMR) annual meetings supported by this R13 will provide interactive and engaging forums for established behavioral medicine scientists and thought leaders from diverse scientific disciplines to exchange, discuss, and debate ideas and the latest research advances to promote healthy aging and reduce chronic disease disparities. Topics will include integrative, cutting-edge team science approaches to research as well as dissemination and translational strategies for bringing science to the public and policymakers. This R13 also will support ABMR’s Early-Stage Investigator (ESI) program, bringing a new cohort of diverse ESIs, a majority from groups underrepresented in science and medicine, to the ABMR meeting each year to participate in leadership and career development training, networking, mentoring activities, as well as the full conference program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol use and misuse is the leading global risk factor for attributable burden of disease among young adults. The International Society for Biomedical Research on Alcoholism (ISBRA) is the premier international organization focused on promoting excellence in alcohol research, and ISBRA Congresses provide an important forum for discussion and collaboration among researchers focused on this serious public health problem. This grant provides support for a diverse group of trainees and early-stage investigators to participate in the conference and engage efforts to address the biomedical, psychosocial, and clinical issues related to alcohol use and misuse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to build the national population-based ASPIRE– ASian American ProspectIve REsearch– Cohort with recruitment of 20,000 males and females, ages 40-75, including focused community-based recruitment from California (San Francisco Bay Area, Sacramento, Los Angeles County, Orange County), New York City/north New Jersey, Philadelphia/south New Jersey (these geographic regions collectively represent over a third of the Asian American population in the United States (US)), but also national outreach to recruit from other US regions. We will apply a transparent and equitable process to inform research priorities and data collection, and disseminate timely, actionable, and policy-relevant study data utilizing interactive data visualization methodologies. In building the first national cancer epidemiologic cohort inclusive of all Asian American populations, ASPIRE will address the research priorities of small populations, intersectionality, and the role of structural and social determinants of health in pathways to cancer risk, including social epigenomics of stress embodiment, health behaviors, and healthcare access.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Enteroviruses are a major source for disease and hospitalization, but currently little is known about their mechanism of infection and there is no available treatment. Using recent advances in single-cell transcriptomics and ultra-deep virus population sequencing, we will explore the dynamics of in vivo enterovirus infection and the host response to it across cells and tissues. Combining these strategies with animal models defective in specific antiviral pathways, we will gain mechanistic insights into viral spread and pathogenesis, which is critical to develop effective antiviral drugs and vaccines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Basement Membranes are extracellular matrices that are defective in a diverse array of human diseases. Knowledge of basement membranes and their cellular receptors is fundamental to our understanding of how multicellular organisms and their tissues are put together and function. This meeting will facilitate the sharing of the latest research and knowledge in the field of basement bembranes among investigators from within and from outside the US and will help to promote collaborations that will speed the tempo of research and move the field forward.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The basal ganglia are a group of brain structures involved in movement and motivation, with dysfunction resulting in devastating human diseases including Parkinson’s disease, Huntington’s disease, dystonia, addiction, obsessive compulsive disorder, and Tourette’s syndrome. To better understand and treat these diseases, support for a conference dedicated to basic, translational, and clinical basal ganglia research is sought. A diverse group of attendees will meet to present and discuss recent fundamental discoveries, and to educate and inspire early career basal ganglia researchers to increase understanding of basal ganglia function and dysfunction and facilitate translation of this knowledge to the clinic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: NARRATIVE Classification of cells within human tissues is essential for understanding states of health and disease. In this proposal, we will develop a new class of fluorescent label that increases the number of molecular classification markers for cells by an order of magnitude. These labels function within intact, three-dimensional tissue, an attribute that we will use to map the local environments of adipose tissue immune cells that are thought to determine comorbid outcomes of obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Coccidioides spp. are the causative agents of coccidioidomycosis, also known as Valley fever which is an emerging infection with ~380,000 new cases in the US annually. Many important questions needed to be studied for the development of better therapeutic strategies for the control of this mycosis. It is the first time, we request NIH R13 funds to support travel awards for trainees, travel costs for a keynote speaker, and to defray the cost of live streaming for an annual meeting to reach more researchers interested in Coccidioides and Valley Fever.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Skeletal muscle stem cells, also known as satellite cells, are responsible for the remarkable regenerative properties of skeletal muscle and are of very high interest to the scientific community as their study has produced major insights into muscle biology and stem cell behavior generally. This conference, the only one dedicated to this topic, will bring together international leaders in the field, as well as graduate students, postdoctoral researchers, junior faculty, and stem cell biologists from other systems to present and discuss unpublished work in this fast-moving, cutting-edge field. Therefore, this conference has high relevance for human health, as these advances and new ones that will proceed from them will drive work in muscle growth, repair, disease and aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ACADEMIC CONSORTIUM FOR INTEGRATIVE MEDICINE AND HEALTH, INC.
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Public scientific conferences where new peer-reviewed work is presented and discussed are crucial to the advancement of all research disciplines. These conferences allow scientists, regulators, funders, and researchers-in-training to come together in a focused setting to explore data from important recent work in their respective disciplines, address issues of common concern, and provide much-needed peer review regarding the emerging knowledge and understanding. The general public benefits enormously and is impacted by way of the improved therapeutic and other scientific advances that make their first appearance at these conferences. NIH’s support of this particular scientific conference has been critical in allowing the extension of benefits of attending to a larger and more diverse audience—in particular, students and fellows in training.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dementia is the primary cause of disability and dependency worldwide. In the United States, minoritized populations - including African Americans, American Indians/Alaska Natives and Hispanic/Latino individuals - are more likely to develop dementia than non-Latino Whites and Asian Americans. This is in part due to the historic exclusion of these populations from research into Alzheimer’s and all other Dementias (ADRDs). The proposed conferences and workshops will bring together established and early career researchers to examine these existing disparities through a health equity lens, catalyze vital conversations between researchers at all levels, provide valuable mentorship and networking opportunities and will build on the successes of the previous conferences.

PHR: Project Narrative The goal of the 54th Annual Meeting of the American Society for Neurochemistry (ASN) to be held April 14-18, 2024 in Portland, Oregon is to bring together members of the scientific community to bridge and cross-fertilize the fields of neurochemistry and neuroscience. It is imperative to provide early career investigators and trainees, who will ultimately make up the next generation of investigators, with a forum for the open and free exchange of ideas. This objective, and the stated goal of further reaching underrepresented groups, is fostered by the highly specialized, topical, and interactive organizational format of the ASN meeting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative This project seeks to use hyperpolarized xenon-129 MRI to establish a set of imaging markers capable of detecting the early onset of chronic lung allograft dysfunction (CLAD) in lung transplant recipients before current diagnostic techniques are capable of registering a clinically significant decline in function. Despite dramatically improved rates of early survival, long-term mortality after lung transplantation, of which CLAD is the leading cause, remains distressingly high. Earlier diagnosis of suspected CLAD currently represents the only viable path to extending the window for effective therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative: Substance Use Disorder (SUD) is a brain disorder with increasing prevalence across socioeconomic and generational classes with no effective treatment. The objectives of the proposed research are to determine the role of an underexplored cell-type, astroglia, in the regulation of cue-induced synaptic changes and cue-induced cocaine seeking. The expected results will provide a novel angle to understanding NAc-based addictive behaviors, and a potential cellular target for treating SUD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The overall goal of this project is to develop a highly specific cell targeting technology to selectively eliminate the autoreactive T cells implicated in the destruction of islet beta cells in type 1 diabetes (T1D) , thus removing the source of the autoimmunity without causing systemic immunsuppression. Our approach is to repurpose CAR T cells, which has shown tremendous clinical efficacy against blood cancers, to attack multiple autoreactive T cells through antigen-specific TCR targeting. Successful completion of this work will provide a paradigm-shifting treat- ment for T1D.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) disproportionately burdens elders and African Americans causing substantial morbidity and mortality, and has no effective treatment making it an especially pressing public health concern. This project will take the novel approach of investigating biologic pathways that mediate cardiac resilience in these high-risk populations by relating proteomics (4,931 circulating proteins) to exercise hemodynamics, longitudinal changes in cardiac function, and detailed genomics. In identifying new targets for interventions promoting cardiac health to prevent HFpEF, this project will also support the expansion of Dr Shah's patient oriented research program and enhance the quality and breadth of training for his mentees.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neural circuit and brain function rely upon the complex and distinct biochemical assembly of synapses: structures where neurons transmit information either chemically or electrically. While chemical synapse proteins have been well characterized, the molecules and interactions that build electrical synapses remain largely a mystery. This proposal will investigate the biochemistry of an electrical synapse scaffolding protein to reveal a model of electrical synapse development and build a foundation to understand this critical piece of human health.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal seeks to investigate qualitatively and quantitatively inequivalent (non-Q1/Q2 equivalent) levonorgestrel (LNG) intrauterine system (IUS) formulations to understand the impact of critical pharmaceutical processing, formulation variations and physical structure of the device on the in vitro drug release characteristics. This research aims to facilitate the development of bioequivalence recommendations for generic IUS products through an in vitro only approach and hence simplify the development of such generic products. As a consequence of the proposed research, the regulatory burden will be reduced and clinical studies will be minimized without sacrificing product quality and safety while delivering cost-effective generic intrauterine system products to the public with minimal delay.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Development of Real-Time and Accelerated Dissolution Methods for a Long-Acting Levonorgestrel Intrauterine System

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Midfacial anomalies like orofacial clefts are commonly found in newborns, but our understanding for how they occur is limited. The overall objective of this proposal is to decipher the molecular underpinnings of midface development and associated disorders from the perspective of the neural crest, an embryonic stem cell population that gives rise to the facial skeleton. Findings from this research will illuminate the developmental basis of midfacial disorders, which will contribute to future strategies for their treatment and even prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to the public health because it aims to understand a basic mechanism of how aberrant signaling by an endocrine hormone FGF19 can drive a subset of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), which is the most common type of primary liver cancer with no effective treatments. We will explore if FGF21 can be utilized as an antagonist against these cancers and present a novel therapeutic strategy for HCC and other FGF19-driven cancers.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Substance use during pregnancy is associated with negative maternal and infant health outcomes and numerous barriers impede delivery of well-coordinated and high-quality pregnancy and postpartum care for pregnant women with substance use disorder. In a recent pilot study, Project Nurture, a clinical model designed to combine maternity care, substance use disorder treatment, peer / doula support and case management in a single setting, was associated with reductions in child maltreatment, placement of children in foster care, and increases in both prenatal visits and maternal lengths-of-stay in the hospital. This proposal leverages Oregon's expansion of Project Nurture to five rural / frontier and underserved counties, offering an ideal opportunity to assess the effectiveness of this promising clinical and to identify how it is implemented in order to foster replication to other regions and states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative During the perioperative period hemodynamic instability is the norm rather than the exception; the ability of clinicians to manage this instability has been associated with postoperative complications affecting more than 15 million Americans and costing more than $165 billion each year. There are no current risk scores that predict instability in real time, however the recent widespread adoption of electronic medical records and creation of genomic biobanks creates unique opportunities to develop scores that are both accurate and precise. We will use machine learning techniques to create risk scores for perioperative cardiorespiratory instability – specifically hypotension and arrhythmia – using combined electronic medical record, genomic and physiologic waveform data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Methylation is the newest component of the “Tubulin Code” that directs the dynamics and function of microtubules. This modification is made on microtubules by the same machinery that methylates chromatin, and its discovery has opened a new area of biology focused on identifying “dual-function” enzymes that read, write and erase methyl marks on both chromatin and the cytoskeleton. Here I propose to explore a new function for the histone methyltransferase NSD3 writing methyl marks on neuronal microtubules using a C. elegans model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Crohn’s Disease (CD), a chronic inflammatory autoimmune disease of the digestive tract, is associated with distinct changes in gut microbiome composition known as dysbiosis. The gut microbiome is known to modulate host gene expression in a microbial composition-dependent manner. The aim of this project is to characterize the interplay between host genetic variation and the gut microbiome occurring in CD which may provide insight into its pathophysiology and potential new therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Natural products are an invaluable source of and inspiration for pharmaceuticals and agrochemicals. This project proposes to study the biosynthetic pathways of bioactive nonproteinogenic amino acid secondary metabolites that contain unusual vinyl N–O bonds. Understanding the synthesis of these small molecules and the biochemical mechanisms underlying their formation will enable our search for similar bioactive compounds and expand the toolbox of biocatalytic oxidative enzymes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Relevance: Adult brain cancer continues to be a significant challenge to clinicians, with over 20,000 cases diagnosed per year, and the mortality rate still among the highest of all cancers. Because the prognosis for individuals with the most common types of brain cancer remains poor, it is of critical importance that new therapies be developed. This proposal requests funds to support a training program that takes promising young investigators and trains them to understand brain tumor biology and therapy as an integrated whole. Investigators trained in this stimulating, translational and comprehensive manner will provide competent leadership for future research efforts aimed at improved treatments and outcomes for brain tumor patients.

PROJECT_TITLE: Training Program in Translational Brain Tumor Research

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project narrative Pathogenic bacteria such as Vibrio cholerae utilize a variety of secretion systems to transport effector proteins and toxins to their environment, but a subset of these is retained on the cell-surface. Some of the cell-surface retained proteins have a novel domain that allows for a unique membrane attachment. Study of this apparent transferable domain could be used for technology development and will shed light on conserved mechanisms of membrane retention.

ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: This renewal application proposes to conduct a randomized controlled trial to examine how interactive, gamified micro-learning promotes knowledge retention and fosters behavior change with regard to child abuse and its reporting, and to establish that implementation of this intervention is feasible. After completing the online iLookOut for Child Abuse Core training, early childhood professionals will receive brief (5-10 minute) gamified learning exercises that they can complete on their smart phones or computers. These micro-learning exercises are designed to promote skill-building, provide opportunities to practice decision-making, reinforce learning and behavior change, and be easily and sustainably implemented.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Despite considerable efforts to eliminate pediatric HIV-1 using antiretroviral treatment (ART), more than 150,000 infants continue to acquire HIV-1 infection annually. Alternative strategies, such as maternal/infant HIV-1 passive or active vaccination to achieve broadly neutralizing antibody (bnAb) activity in plasma, will be required to end the pediatric HIV-1 epidemic. We have identified maternal antibody responses that predict reduced risk of MTCT, yet determined that viral escape of maternal neutralizing antibodies against mothers' own circulating viruses is common in infant infections, including escape of plasma bnAb activity. We now seek to define the role of maternal plasma bnAb responses in MTCT and whether viral escape of bnAbs is a risk factor for vertical virus transmission. Understanding the impact of pre-existing bnAb activity on MTCT risk is important to design immunologic strategies that will synergize with ART to eliminate pediatric HIV infections.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA GREATER LOS ANGELES HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: The rapid expansion of virtual care adds complexity to the provision of same day access to Primary Care- Mental Health Integration (PC-MHI) among newly referred patients. Given the important role of PC-MHI as an entry point to mental health care, and ongoing widespread virtual care use in VA, there is an urgent need for effective strategies to maximize same day access for patients who initiate PC-MHI services via virtual care. This study addresses a significant knowledge gap by evaluating mutable predictors of virtual PC-MHI same day access and identifying strategies for effective interdisciplinary care coordination. Improving virtual PC-MHI same day access can reduce burden for VA Patient Aligned Care Team (PACT) medical providers by facilitating rapid assessment and treatment of new mental health patients. The information gained from this pilot study will contribute to the development of interventions to improve virtual care coordination in integrated healthcare settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The overarching goal of this proposal is to understand how and why an actin mesh that fills the developing egg of Drosophila (fruit fly) contributes to polarity establishment. The oocytes of many species, including mammals, have analogous structures, suggesting structural and functional conservation. Thus we anticipate that what we learn about Drosophila egg development will be applicable to our understanding of cellular organization, fertility, development, and health in animals, ranging from Drosophila to humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Chemotherapy-induced neuropathy (CIN)—pain, numbness, and/or tingling distributed in the hands and feet— produces persistent symptoms affecting sensation and balance in cancer survivors. Up to 50% of cancer survivors still suffer from CIN 6 years after treatment, with a 1.8-fold increased risk of falls which negatively impacts quality of life. We propose to test auricular point acupressure (APA)—a non-invasive and nonpharmacological patient managed strategy—as an innovative solution for CIN.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) and Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder are two of the most common neurodevelopmental disorders and have a surprisingly high rate of comorbidity of up to 70%. Features in early infancy have been associated with both ASD and ADHD diagnoses, such as social communication deficits, atypical attention processes, and motor skill challenges, but understanding of the transdiagnostic and differential features of these disorders is limited. This study will investigate the association between social communication, attention, and motor skills in infancy and symptoms of ASD and ADHD to elucidate early mechanisms underlying the development of these disorders.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Cutaneous wounds create significant health problems for Veterans, including wartime trauma, diabetic foot ulcers, and pressure ulcers. More than 100 million new skin wounds appear annually on patients, and most skin wounds heal with a fibrotic scar. Scars themselves may also cause severe emotional distress, skin tightening, and physical disability. Although many products are marketed for scar prevention or removal, their results are modest. We aim to develop new therapeutic approaches to tissue repair based upon a deep understanding of the molecular mechanism and a firm commitment to the clinical/translational mission. In our preliminary data, we discovered that the deletion of a cell surface receptor increases the efficiency to induce scarless wound healing in mouse skin. We will dissect molecularly how this receptor regulates scarless wound healing and test whether blocking this receptor also promotes scarless wound healing in human skin.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: There is growing evidence that disruptions in redox biology and oxidative stress mediated by oxygen free radicals (as well as other reactive oxygen and nitrogen species) are causally involved in initiation, growth, invasion, metastasis, and treatment of cancer. Free Radical Biology also has strong mechanistic links to radiation biology, cancer biology, inflammation, and degenerative diseases associated with aging. Given the rapidly expanding importance of these concepts in translational biomedical research, the unique Training Program in Free Radical and Radiation Biology meets a national need for scientists to develop novel mechanism based approaches to reduce the health effects of cancer and educate the next generation of leaders in this field that spans both basic and translational science.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Antimicrobial resistance is one of the most pressing public health crises of the 21st century. Carbapenem-hydrolyzing -lactamases are a particularly concerning resistance mechanism to our last line antibiotics, the carbapenems. The proposed research on antimicrobial resistance in environmental microorganisms will inform physicians of potential novel -lactamases that may threaten human health before their emergence in the clinic, which is entirely in line with the mission of the NIH and NIAID.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative (3 sentence limit) In mouse genetic models of Down syndrome (DS), enhanced inhibitory efficiency limits hippocampal synaptic plasticity thus negatively affecting cognition. Here we hypothesized that these changes occur during early postnatal periods as a compensatory reaction to excessive neuronal hyperpolarization, caused by increased signaling through Kir3.2 channels, preventing neonatal neurons from “seeing” each other during the formation of nascent neural circuits. While testing this hypothesis, we will examine the therapeutic potential of antagonists of the GABAB receptors as cognitive enhancers in DS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative HIV-1 initiates infection by fusing with cell membranes through a process mediated by the viral envelope glycoprotein. Several host factors incorporate into virions and inhibit their fusion with new target cells through a poorly understood mechanism. We will use a panel of cutting-edge imaging techniques to delineate the mechanism by which these host proteins disfavor HIV-1 fusion and to inform new antiviral strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this proposal, we will test the central hypothesis that an upregulation of the B cell immune compartment in lung and blood correlates with the extent of emphysema in COPD independently of the severity of airflow limitation. We will use immunostaining and image mass cytometry techniques, next-generation sequencing with a single-cell approach, in vitro and ex vivo approaches to test our hypothesis that changes in the B cell transcriptomics are associated with an upregulation of the B cell pool in both blood and lung of COPD patients, contributing to lung tissue destruction and emphysema. The successful completion of these studies will help define the clinical phenotype (likely emphysema) that could benefit from therapies targeting B cells or B cell products, leading to earlier and more personalized therapeutic intervention which will greatly alleviate the burden of COPD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative Currently, the factors that determine the effectiveness of chemotherapy for AML are poorly understood. We recently discovered that some Normal Karyotype AML patients, who had very long first remissions with chemotherapy alone, had unexpectedly high frequency of pathogenic MYC mutations in the dominant leukemia clone at diagnosis. In this proposal, we will systematically explore the molecular mechanisms by which AML- specific MYC mutations sustain leukemogenesis and increase the AraC sensitivity of AML cells, which may lead to new approaches for risk stratification, and novel approaches for therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative RFA-AI-19-037 The Mice Against Ticks project seeks to prevent new cases of Lyme disease by heritably immunizing the white-footed mice that are most responsible for infecting ticks. Engineering local mouse populations to carry naturally occurring immunity elements isolated from other mice in a reversible fashion may be the safest and most minimal intervention capable of preventing Lyme disease for many decades. Our open and community-guided approach has generated considerable interest and apparent enthusiasm from the residents of Nantucket and Martha’s Vineyard, suggesting that it may be widely adopted to protect communities suffering from Lyme disease throughout the Northeast and Upper Midwest.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE During heart failure, the integrity of T-tubules, specialized cell membrane structures essential for normal heart function, deteriorates making heart contraction less efficient. It is not known whether T-tubules can be repaired as a potential treatment for heart failure. This proposal examines how different activities of a potential membrane repair protein, MG53, contribute to heart disease and whether they can be leveraged toward improving T-tubule structure and overall heart function.

PHR: Project Narrative  This FASEB conference will address the emerging field of how gene expression is mediated by various molecular machines in the cell nucleus. Collectively termed nuclear bodies, these machines play key roles in the final production of transcripts destined either for translation into proteins or for regulatory roles within the nucleus. Research in this field has recently uncovered links between nuclear bodies and cancer, which will be a major focus of this meeting, including two Keynote Lectures and many other talks.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is a growing health burden worldwide. This disease encompasses liver steatosis that may progress to steatohepatitis, and ultimately, to life threatening conditions such as cirrhosis and live cancer. However, despite more than 15 years of research, the main unmet medical need remains the identification of specific therapies against this disease; this Keystone Symposia conference will review the latest research in the field so that attendees can establish new collaborations to aid in the search of precision therapeutics based on NAFLD disease diversity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer immunotherapy, a collection of approaches that coax patients’ immune systems to target cancer cells, has been a lifesaving advancement for certain patients and cancers. While many approaches in this area have shown remarkable effectiveness, the technologies do not apply to all cancers. This conference takes a “bedside- to-bench” approach that brings together clinicians and basic researchers from across academia and industry to take a critical look at clinical trial failures so as to glean insights that will guide novel research efforts to improve future cancer immunotherapy treatments and outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As we emerge from the COVID pandemic, there is an urgent need for the TB research community to re- engage in scientific interactions, to exchange ideas and to establish new collaborations. As the community rethinks ways to prevent and treat TB, everything begins with a thorough understanding of the fundamental biology of TB immunopathogenesis. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is a significant cause of death worldwide, claiming the lives of 17.9 million people annually. By bringing together key opinion leaders in the cardiac and vascular epigenetics communities, as well as external experts in other related fields such as systems genetics, this conference creates a unique opportunity to cross traditional disciplinary boundaries in the cardiovascular field. This will be the first time that this group has come together for a meeting and creates an opportunity to forge new collaborations and to initiate crosstalk in the growing field of cardiovascular epigenetics and gene regulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Antibodies carry an enormous potential in the treatment of human disease, across ages, genders, races, and geographic locations. For example, in cancer, effective antibody therapies are evolving rapidly, providing opportunities for specific targeting of the broad range of malignancies in different disease stages; in infectious diseases, particularly emerging infectious diseases, investigators can rapidly identify therapeutic antibodies for lifesaving treatment or prophylaxis. This Keystone Symposia conference aims to provide the platform for sharing and integration of knowledge for experts and trainees alike to learn about the newest developments in antibody engineering that will be applied to prevent, treat and cure important human diseases.

PROJECT_TITLE: Antibodies as Drugs: The Art in Antibody Engineering

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immunology has rapidly become one of the most promising scientific areas associated with cancer research and treatment. This Keystone Symposia conference is intended to unite the fields of inflammation, microbiology and cancer and will enable researchers in innate immunity, adaptive immunotherapy, cancer vaccines, microbiome and immune metabolism to interact on an international scale. The conference will be instrumental in shaping basic and translational research in these overlapping fields, with an aim of advancing novel cancer treatments.
